story:
How Are You Spending Our Money?

Valid question.  Very valid. 

Do you know how much goes into producing a play? 

We didn't either. 

Turns out it's a lot.  

A.  Lot. 

Let's break it down for you.

The Rights: The rights to a Pulitzer winning play for Los Angeles with four performances in a 0-49 seat theatre?  A hundred a night.  That's 400.  Thanks David Auburn.  We appreciate you letting us attempt to bring your words to life.  

Rehearsal space:  Let's say we want to rehearse for five weeks.  Three times a week at least in the space.  Three hours a rehearsal.  We're gonna put aside roughly 1,000 for that.  We need to rehearse.  We're professionals, but the process is key.  

The Theatre: We found the COOLEST little theatre on Santa Monica boulevard.  The owners of OhMyRibs!, Lisa and Matt are absolutely the most awesome and kindhearted people I was introduced to during this process.  They're letting us put the show up in their theatre and helping with the marquee, and ticket sales, and promoting us on their website even.  But hey, theatre space ain't free.  They've been more than generous with us but...Thursday-Sunday entirely in the space is 1,175 big ones.  But the seats are actually super comfy, and they even have built in cup holders.  You know, for your water.  Or adult beverage.  

The Crew:  Sound, lighting, stage designer...these people have all generously offered to help us out of the kindness of their hearts.  I can't wait to brag about them in the program and on social media.  They saw a project we were passionate about and wanted to help make it the best version it could possibly be.  We love these people.  We want to pay them for their time, as much as we can possibly afford.  We're looking at a grand here...but hey, if you give them more we won't complain.

The Extras: Concessions, programs, props, costume necessities, water and food for poor starving actors during tech, publicity, all the little things that go into making this production as professional as possible for those working on the show, and those coming to see it.   We're trying for 500 here.  Again, if you're feeling generous, high fives all around. 

And so, that's why we're humbly asking you for $4,000 to bring this production to life.

Indiegogo's gonna take a small portion of that, but hey, they helped too, so that's fine by us.   

 

What's the Point, Guys? 

Keelin and I met in the BFA acting program at USC.  We had dreams and aspirations and futures and hopes.  We were bright-eyed.  We were excited.  We graduated, and started to see that the real world wasn't the easiest place to have a career in the arts. (Who'd have thought?)   
But we were still excited. 
We still wanted to create and play and remind everyone that some really beautiful things happen at the core of our humanity. 
Guess what?
It isn't that hard to create your own opportunities.  It isn't that hard to take some risks.  It isn't that hard to summon up all the passion you have for this art form and try to create something beautiful.  
We're here to show you that.  Hopefully again, and again, and again.   
In a society where so much darkness exists, we want you to know that you can create your own light.  

But I Have No Money...

We get it.  We're all broke. (I'm probably going to be eating a LOT of Ramen during this next month and a half.) And we're asking a lot.  If you don't have the means to donate, we would never hold it against you.  But PLEASE, share our page!  Come to our show!  Offer us words of support and love!  Give us a hug if you see us!  Start your own project and tell us we inspired you!  Any positive encouragement helps and means the world. 

THE CAST:

Effie Antigone - Catherine/Producer


Charles Howell - Robert


Melissa Ciesla - Claire


Michael Hanna - Hal


Keelin Shea Woodell - Director

story:
Synopsis: 

Emily has been living with Olivia her whole life.  Olivia is her best friend and roommate, her protector and her downfall.  She can be extraordinarily difficult and time consuming but she is always there.  Olivia is Emily's Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.  

Living with Olivia Cadence Donovan is a play about not just surviving but living with OCD.  

Tickets now on sale!: 

https://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/3414967

Website:

https://livingwitholiviacadencedonovan.com

What We Need & What You Get:

After the successful run of the show @ the Hudson Guild Theatre in NYC, it is time for the Canadian premiere and we are looking to the artistic community to help us get there! We've got a heck of lot of passion and drive and we are ready to take Canada by storm.  

For this particular production, our main concerns are raising funds in order to pay for a week long run in a Toronto Theatre, audition/rehearsal space, costumes, set, and artistic stipends. Our goal is to pay everyone involved for their hard work, talent, and time.

We are so beyond grateful for you, as you are a huge part of making this happen – so we want you to benefit as well! There are a long list of perks, but every dollar counts (truly every single one) 

Once you've contributed, you are a part of our Living with Olivia family–should you choose to provide your email, we will keep you posted every step of the way on this production and future ones! 

 

A little about the Playwright: 

I am so excited to debut my first full length play in my home-town.  I am an NYC/Toronto based-Actor, Singer, and Playwright who is a recent grad from the New Studio on Broadway's Acting and Musical Theatre program at NYU Tisch.  Most recently I performed in the full-length play I wrote/produced: "Living with Olivia Cadence Donovan" as part of  New York Theatre Festival.  Shortly before that my One-Act play: A-Door Me advanced to the Semi-Finals of the New York New Works Festival. My other favorite roles include: Hope Cladwell (Urinetown), Audrey (Little Shop of Horrors), Jeanie (Hair), Maureen (RENT), and Hattie (Kiss Me Kate). For updates or more info head to: www.allisonsheareed.com 

 

A Letter from the Playwright: 

I wrote this play because I am tired of people saying “I’m so OCD” or claiming to understand what OCD feels like.  My parents found 7 year old me in tears on the floor of my bedroom, in the middle of the night, holding the door against the wall.  When they asked why I told them very matter of factly: “I can’t sleep unless the door is right up against the wall.”

My parents picked me up off the floor, told me everything would be okay, and set up an appointment at Sick Kids Hospital in Toronto.  After filling out questionnaires and talking with different doctors, I was diagnosed with OCD and although the diagnosis temporarily provided my family with some relief, it was only the beginning of what would be a long and extraordinarily difficult journey.  What a lot of people don’t know about obsessive compulsive disorder, despite its horrific and oversimplified use in the media, is this:

 

OCD never fully goes away, it is something sufferers will deal with for their entire lives.  Whether it’s through therapy, medication, etc.  it is something that needs to be constantly handled.   It is a lifetime diagnoses and there’s no cure in sight.

 

OCD is a lack of serotonin in your brain, serotonin is what regulates thoughts, essentially what allows you to let things go. 

 

 

It isn’t just needing to clean or compulsions, it is constant worrying. It’s worrying that something someone said will get stuck, that a random thought that pops into your brain is true, and the inability to let a thought/idea go. 

 

When I was younger my OCD manifested physically, I was unable to have anyone in a space I considered my own or touching something of mine without it feeling contaminated.  I would have to do things an even number of times, which resulted in my whole family crashing their bikes on a vacation because I took one hand off the handle, the other hand off, and then needed to take both hands off.  I was leading the bike trip so when I crashed into a mailbox and fell, so did my sister and my parents.  I was unable to lend anyone anything, my sister would want to read one of my comic books and I wouldn’t be able to let her take it without feeling like it wasn’t mine anymore or contaminated.  This resulted in a lot of confusion for my parents as they worked hard to raise kids that were good at sharing and not selfish; I as a person learned those values, my OCD did not. 

That’s the problem with my OCD in general: it doesn’t match my personality.  I am someone who wants to give everyone anything I can in order to make them happy or better, I automatically offer up my belongings when someone else is in need completely forgetting about my disorder and then shamefully have to retract the invitation or suffer through an OCD episode.  As an extreme empath and severely sensitive person, when someone is in pain, I feel it with them and want to fix it. 

 

When I was younger my disorder was easier to explain. My OCD was more visible, it was something you could see.  My family tried to keep up with me; they learned which spoons they couldn’t use, what chair they couldn’t sit in, and not to put their bare feet on the couch or on me. 

As I’ve gotten older, it’s easier to hide as most of it rests in my head.  Unless I told you, you would not know how hard I am working and fighting against the lack of serotonin in my brain. 

Just this morning I was in rehearsal with two friends of mine, who I logically know care about me a great deal, and out of nowhere my brain said:  “No one would notice if you weren’t around, everyone hates you.”  Now you might be thinking “oh no no I’ve had intrusive thoughts or worries like this, I totally get what you mean, I’ve definitely been there.”  And truthfully, you might’ve.  There are a lot of undiagnosed people in this world.  But I’m sitting there looking at my two friends, acting in a scene and this thought pops into my head.  At first I think, that sucks that you’ve decided to show up now OCD but these people care about me, that’s silly.  Then the thought circles through another 50 times, I continuously tell my OCD that it’s wrong and it needs to shut up but it becomes hard to hear anything anyone is saying or be present in the room. 

I look at my scene partner and tears fill my eyes: they would not even notice or care if I wasn’t around.  I don’t matter to them.  I don’t matter to them.  I don’t matter to anyone.  I don’t matter.  I don’t matter.  I don’t matter.  I don’t matter.  The thought envelopes my mind and suddenly I believe whole-heartedly that what my head is saying is true.  Now this is my almost 25 year old self, so I know how to handle such circumstances, it happens 4-5 times, at least, on a good day. 

 

The way I generally know if someone has it or not is by the way that they say it.  If they have it, there is a sparkle, a tiny glint of recognition that the person across from them has experienced the same level of torture.  There’s generally a: Have you ever had such and such happen?  And even if your “things” aren’t the same, the constant terror and sick-to-your-stomach feeling is the same.  When someone thinks they have OCD generally they say things like:  “Sometimes I need things to be clean, I have been worried a lot lately, I like things to be very specific and I’m pretty type A.”  They admit things that are surface level and normal, sure they could land in generalized anxiety world but they are not OCD. 

Obsessive Compulsive Disorder is not just obsessive or just compulsive: it’s both.  The only way out of it is through.  Your OCD will tell you that the only way to get rid of a thought is to act out the corresponding compulsion but the only way to actually take the power away from the thought is to do nothing or do the opposite.  For example, I will think if I don’t get up and double check that my door is locked someone will come in here and kill me.  If I get up and check the lock, I firstly feel an excessive amount of shame and then it sends a signal to my brain that the OCD was right and this thought will come up many more times.  If I sit with the thought, even though it feels like I will die, it proves to my brain that there is some flaw in the OCD thinking and maybe it’s okay not to listen. 

 

What I’ll ask when someone confides in me and tells me they think they have OCD is if they don’t do the thing they claim makes them have OCD do they feel like they’re going to die?  Not like kind of uncomfortable, like every bit of your body is screaming and in full fledged fight or flight mode?  No? Not OCD. 

 

OCD will make you so angry you can’t see straight, you’ll feel like you’re standing over your body watching someone else ,who definitely isn’t you, scream at someone you love and say terrible, terrible things because that body is so overwhelmed with emotions that screaming is the only way to get it out. 

The nice thing about OCD is that it tires, the more you exhaust yourself, the closer you are to being free.  It’s not the healthiest of strategies but tiny Allison sure was a big fan of the use all your energy in the biggest scariest way and then you’ll be free of this feeling a whole lot faster because you’ll be too tired to care anymore.  Can you imagine being terrified you’re going to die if you don’t check the door an even number of times or until it feels safe and only feeling better when you’re so exhausted you don’t care if you die?  That’s my OCD and what I hope Living with Olivia Cadence Donovan will help open up for audience members.

story:
Classical Theatre Company is the only professional theatre company in Houston, TX that produces year round classical drama. We were honored last season to be one of only 7 companies in the country to be first-time recipients of the prestigious National Theatre Company Grant Award by the American Theatre Wing (the same folks who run the Tony Awards). Now entering our 10th season, CTC looks to expand its programming with more free readings, single night events, a Lecture Series, and more to celebrate its 10th anniversary! But in order to keep our readings free and our ticket prices low, we need your support!

Additionally, on the night of June 27th, CTC was burglarized and all of our computers were stolen, leaving us in chaos as we tried to deal with the damage that was done. So, we have an additional burden to try to replace our lost technology on top of celebrating our landmark 2017-2018 10th Anniversary Season. 

Lastly, CTC was impacted by Hurricane Harvey from a number of leaks that damaged the floors, walls, and ceiling in our lobby, offices, and studio space.

Upcoming, we have a slate of topical and entertaining plays: running in October will be G.B. Shaw's witty drama Mrs. Warren's Profession. Then this winter, Henrik Ibsen's drama An Enemy of the People. Finally in April will run Nikolai Gogol's ridiculous farce, The Government Inspector.

Please help us provide a terrific season of plays for our audiences, educational programming for our students, and jobs for our talented artists and technicians. It's only through your support that we can achieve our lofty goals.

story:
Overlooked Latinas Summary

We thank you for helping us raise the $5,285.00 for the 3 week run at Brava Theater!

I am now raising $1,000 in less than 4 weeks to cover my costs and that would take my Indiegogo number to $6,285.00.  Please keep in mind crowd funding takes a small percent. And thanks to Indiegogo, there are so many artists like myself that have gained support and help! 

For those of you who don't know me I'm Tina D’Elia. I’m a mixed-race Latina lesbian/queer feminist and I’ve been making work about queerness and since 1996, winning awards, playing wildly diverse (and sometimes dead) characters and making you all laugh. My fierce Latina Lesbian award winning director Mary Guzmán and I had great success with our 3 week run at The Brava this past winter (February 16-March 3rd, 2019), and we thank you for helping to make it happen! Mary and I are proud to share that our west coast premiere of Overlooked Latinas had 4 sold out shows and 5 standing ovations. 

 In 2015, Mary and I won Best of Fringe and Best of Sold Out Shows at the San Francisco Fringe festival with my solo show The Rita Hayworth of this Generation.

"Tina D’Elia’s newest one-woman show celebrates queer culture, friendship and Latinx history.

    It also defies all theatergoing expectations of what makes a quality experience."

-Annie Berman, Mission Local Newspaper

Overlooked Latinas is about two queer Latinx best friends directing a tv show focusing on Latinas of the silver screen who were overlooked during the era of the Red Scare and McCarthyism.

Shows that are outside of the mainstream box rely heavily on crowd funding because, let’s face it, if no one puts funding towards Latina feminist queer stories and the stories of our trailblazing Latina icons, then I believe in doing it ourselves. I love to create and co-produce my own work with my fabulous team and I feel blessed to bring the Bay Area this new show again to a new and exciting venue. By supporting my $1,000 dollar crowd funding goal you are also supporting a LBTQ and Women of Color team of professional artists I hire to help make my show a big success.

While the Marsh covers one Tech person day of show to run lights and sound, I need to pay for my director, stage manager, technical sound design person, videographer, and for costumes.

The full amount of my productions costs are $1,400. I’m hoping to raise $1000.00 to cover a portion of my costs.

As a contributor, you are personally making a great deal of difference in a mixed-race Latina queer/lesbian’s life and artistry, which means the world to me and I thank you!  To be a San Francisco artist also means for me working many jobs and living with the stress of the high costs of living here. I am honored to contribute my artistry and labor of love with all of you.

Major donors giving $100.00 and up, will get free tickets to see Overlooked Latinas,  on the main stage at The Marsh in San Francisco as a Rising Star featured performance.  Next month, Wednesday June 5th, 2019, 7:30pm show, one night only.  If you cannot attend, I would be happy to provide online video access to the entire whole show via YouTube link, within 3 weeks post show.

I want you to know that I highly value the contributions of sharing my campaign video or posting on Facebook that you are “Saving the Date” to come see my show. I truly believe that every dollar makes a difference, so I welcome all contributions whether it’s $1.00 dollar or $10.00 dollars, or $1,000.00 dollars. If you cannot contribute financially to my show at this time, I would be thrilled if you could share the Indiegogo link to spread the word and send my crowdfunding campaign to someone you know who could make a donation. 

If you are also a struggling artist/student/parent/hard working human – here’s what you can do --- use the Indiegogo share tools!!! Yes!!! It’s so helpful when you post on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, google, email, etc. Tell your friends – Tina says donate any amount - $1.00 goes a long way!

Spreading the word will help make this dream become a reality & support my team of artists that I am working with as well.

See you at the The Marsh SF, Wednesday June 5th, 2019 7:00PM! 

We are honored to be part of the National Queer Arts Festival. 

With Much Gratitude & Con Abrazos – Tina D’Elia
story_txt: Overlooked Latinas SummaryWe thank you for helping us raise the $5,285.00 for the 3 week run at Brava Theater!I am now raising $1,000 in less than 4 weeks to cover my costs and that would take my Indiegogo number to $6,285.00.  Please keep in mind crowd funding takes a small percent. And thanks to Indiegogo, there are so many artists like myself that have gained support and help! For those of you who don't know me I'm Tina D’Elia. I’m a mixed-race Latina lesbian/queer feminist and I’ve been making work about queerness and since 1996, winning awards, playing wildly diverse (and sometimes dead) characters and making you all laugh. My fierce Latina Lesbian award winning director Mary Guzmán and I had great success with our 3 week run at The Brava this past winter (February 16-March 3rd, 2019), and we thank you for helping to make it happen! Mary and I are proud to share that our west coast premiere of Overlooked Latinas had 4 sold out shows and 5 standing ovations.  In 2015, Mary and I won Best of Fringe and Best of Sold Out Shows at the San Francisco Fringe festival with my solo show The Rita Hayworth of this Generation."Tina D’Elia’s newest one-woman show celebrates queer culture, friendship and Latinx history.    It also defies all theatergoing expectations of what makes a quality experience."-Annie Berman, Mission Local NewspaperOverlooked Latinas is about two queer Latinx best friends directing a tv show focusing on Latinas of the silver screen who were overlooked during the era of the Red Scare and McCarthyism.Shows that are outside of the mainstream box rely heavily on crowd funding because, let’s face it, if no one puts funding towards Latina feminist queer stories and the stories of our trailblazing Latina icons, then I believe in doing it ourselves. I love to create and co-produce my own work with my fabulous team and I feel blessed to bring the Bay Area this new show again to a new and exciting venue. story:
Who We Are

Representation matters, but it is twofold. For too long queer stories have lived on the periphery of narratives explored on stage and in film. It is not enough to just tell the stories of queer individuals, it is imperative that we are included in the creation of them.

Here. strives to champion the work of LGBTQ+ artists, by presenting traditional narratives through a queer perspective. We invite audiences to break down the boundaries within their imagination and experience a world in which our narrative is ever present.

Our inaugural production, Paramour, is a multi-generational LGBTQ love story that examines the intricacies of queer love through the use of heightened language.

Piera Van de Wiel (Co-founder and Producer), Jennifer Parkhill (Co-founder and Director), and John Anthony Loffredo (Co-founder and Playwright)

What We Need & What You Get

We are very excited to bring our first production to life, but we will need your help to fully realize our vision. Funds we raise will go towards:

  • Renting rehearsal space
  • Renting a premiere performance venue in NYC
  • Unique costumes that fit the timeless/surreal style of the show
  • A unit set to encapsulate three separate locations
  • Paying the professional actors

With your contribution you will be supporting LGBTQ+ artists as we share our voices and our art with the world.

The Impact

All too often queer artists are left out of the telling of our own stories and we are trying to change that. Here. hopes to bring LGBTQ+ art made by LGBTQ+ artists to the forefront of our society. Your support, in the form of a campaign contribution or social media shout out, brings us one step closer to our ultimate goal--changing the way our culture values LGBTQ+ artists. 

Risks & Challenges

Paramour is our first production, so  we are bound to hit some bumps in the road. However, we are confident, that as a team, we will be able to meet challenges with creative solutions. 

Our art is personal, and is therefore very precious to us. Putting it out there for the world to see is a big step, and want to present it in the highest quality possible. That is why your support is so important.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, please share our campaign! Sharing this campaign on social media, in LGBTQ+ advocacy groups, artist groups, and on your personal pages would be a big help in getting our mission out into the world! 

If you read this campaign and know of artists in your community who may wish to be involved, please pass this along. We hope to expand our network of queer artists of every discipline and would appreciate your help in connecting us.

With heartfelt gratitude and much love,

Here. Artist Collective

story:
The Play

HOPE IN CHAOS is the extraordinary true story of one average New Yorker who found herself as a relief worker amongst the chaos of Ground Zero in the days immediately following September 11th. She would remain there working amongst the rubble with an unlikely team of civilian relief workers for four months. HOPE IN CHAOS explores the struggles – both political and emotional, and triumphs of a group of young New Yorkers who answered a call and found their strength in a city that had been shaken to its core. Directed by Broadway's Holly-Anne Ruggiero, it will be performed in a special limited engagement run at the Richmond Shepard Theater to coincide with the 10-year Memorial of September 11th.

The Message

Hope in Chaos is about action. It's about how each of us holds the potential for greatness through our choices, and - perhaps most importantly - it's about how many small acts of kindness add up to something both enormous and extraordinary.  From it's very beginnings this play was a journey that depended not just on a playwright, but on a team of peers, mentors, actors...dozens of people.  People who helped and worked and supported the project - for free - because it was something they believed in.  That journey so far has reinforced that message of the play - that little things add up.  That greatness is many people, but it can start with one - you.

The Goal

It's simple, really.  This truly is an extraordinary story with an amazing message, and we want this 10-year Memorial premiere production to reach as many people as possible. To do that, we need your help. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this. Post this. Tweet this. Follow us. Tell your friends. Tell your family. Tell your boss. Tell that guy you met that used to live in New York. Tell your cousin who knew that woman that worked in the World Trade Center. Tell everyone.

story:
Our Story

Hello folks! I am 27 years old and have been dancing for many years, it is one of my passions in life.

In the past i have always been part of the classical dance world e.g... The Royal Ballet School where i studied for 8 years and San Francisco Ballet where i danced for 7 years. 

Recently i have been moving away from this classical background and finding inspiration in different forms of movement and art.

This year i am all about learning and growth. In order to move forward on a new path creatively i feel it is necessary for me to be in situations unknown.

When i saw the Batsheva dance company perform 4 years ago on tour in sf my jaw hit the ground!

Over december time Batsheva Dance Company offer a 9 day course in Tel Aviv for 75 dancers 18yrs+ to go and workshop with the Director Ohad Naharin and his dancers. 

Opportunities like this do not come around so easily and it is a dream realized for me to be part of this environment.

Even though this happens between december 25th and january 2nd (holiday time) I feel this is a very important step for me and will inevitably help me grow as an artist.....i just want to learn and create damn it!


The Impact

This workshop is something i have to go through, its that simple. 

I would love to translate this gaga language into my body, my mind and create on this level.

so in the future when working on new material and new work i will have a whole different side to movement by way of expressing myself. 

To share art and life is what makes the world go round! 


What We Need & What You Get

After looking at the sum for the workshop and flights and accommodation i realize that in total it will cost $2000 dollars or more.

I am asking for help here guys, i would love to raise $1100 so instead of being a complete starving artist i am just an average poor artist instead.

I realize that in this world money can rule us but this is just one opportunity i cannot let pass me by. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please if you are friends reading this and would like to offer some help to promote my case please feel free to share this page on any social media network you have at your disposal. peace

story:
What is Yuva Ekta?

Yuva Ekta:Youth Unite is a theatre group based in New Delhi, India- that works with young people from privileged and marginalised backgrounds, bridging the gap between them through the medium of theatre and arts. Over the past 8 years, the group has conceptualised street and stage play performances to raise awareness about socially relevant themes that they feel passionately about.

The group is representing India at the Tin Forest Festival, a project of the National Theatre of Scotland in association with Scottish Youth Theatre, which is a major new arts festival, part of the Glasgow 2014 Cultural Programme Inspired by the book by Helen Ward and Wayne Anderson. 

Theatre groups from Commonwealth Countries will all come together in Glasgow from 22nd to 29th July to perform pieces based on the theme " From Nowhere to Somewhere"

We Need Funds!

We are looking to raise funds in order to make this performance happen in July! The group needs to be able to pay for TICKETS, VISAS, PER DIEMS and to cover production costs for COSTUMES, STAGE AND ART DESIGN, MUSIC and PROPS.

We have to raise 10 Lakhs INR (approximately 17,000 USD) to reach our goal, of which we are hoping to raise 10,000 USD with YOUR help and the rest from corporate funding. We believe we will be successful in raising our target fund but if we fall short we WILL still go ahead with the performance but we will need to take a few loans.

The Impact

Most of the group has never traveled abroad and performing in Glasgow and representing our country is a truly priceless opportunity for us!

The most special part of the Yuva Ekta: Youth Unite group is the diversity of the group. People from starkly different socio- economic and professional backgrounds, have come together with their diverse stories and experience to create a rich performance.

This opportunity to perform at Glasgow, to facilitate and be part of other youth workshops will be a huge learning experience for the group, one that they will share with other youth groups when they return to India!

Some of our earlier projects are here: www.yuvaektafoundation.org


WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

- Contribute a small amount to make this big dream come true
- Spread the word about our project so more people like you can help us make this happen

story:
Founded by Artistic Director Shaily Dadiala, Usiloquy Dance Designs is a contemporary Bharatanatyam company creating unique works that cross cultural boundaries and build bridges between diverse communities. Usiloquy works to create a conduit between the age old dance form that originated in the temples of Southern India with schools and concert halls of the 21st century. The company has served over 15,000 people through performances and education programs at more than 50 venues in Pennsylvania, Delaware, New York and India. Arts education has faced cuts across the board. In response, we have built partnerships to keep providing high quality programming in Philadelphia neighborhoods and we are getting raving reviews! Philadelphia Dance Journal wrote: "With each of the pieces presented by Usiloquy Dance Designs, there was a continual shift in the music moving from the traditional to more modern songs. However, the defined structure of physical and musical complexity never faltered. The percussive elements within the music synced with how the dancers beat the floor with different parts of their foot. Each piece brought new characteristics and story lines, exhibiting an artistry and dexterity with dynamic statuesque positions transitioning into smooth and graceful feminine movements" 


And so...

On Saturday, July 26th, 2014, Usiloquy Dance Designs will feature a 45 minute original Indian classical dance production with 6 dancers, followed by an interactive segment engaging audience members, demonstrating dance techniques and providing information about the commemorative sculpture by Glenna Goodacre. The dance consists of pieces touching on the following themes: Early textile industry populated by Irish immigrants in the Kensington area of Philadelphia, 18th century Sanskrit texts written by Indian poet Muthuswamy Dikshitar to Irish reels, and a ballad played by contemporary Pennsylvania-based Celtic Band, Burning Bridget Cleary. These free of charge showings of 'Ragas and Airs' will be a cross-cultural, site-specific and multidisciplinary partnership between two Philadelphia organizations. 

However, WE NEED YOUR HELP to make this event free of charge so that anyone who wants to, can join us. Your contribution will make it possible to pay the dancers and technical staff who are working tirelessly to make this event a success. Also, we want to educate our audiences, so we want to design and print study guides for ALL program participants. Your contribution allows us to do that. Moreover, your contribution will allow hundreds of people of ALL AGES and backgrounds to experience a one-of-a-kind performance!

story:
About the Project

In 1996, audiences gathered near Brucemore’s pond to enjoy a play.  With blankets and chairs in hand, they claimed spots across the sloped performance space, curiously anticipating the show. Brucemore had already established itself as a setting for cultural happenings; however, a multi-performance, outdoor theater production was without local precedent.

The program was born from inspired conversations between Peggy Boyle Whitworth, Brucemore’s founding Executive Director (pictured above), and Jim Kern, a distinguished leader in the region’s theater community.  They developed the idea with a select group of local performers, including Leslie Charipar and Scott Humeston. In that first year, they attracted 741 people to see the Greek tragedy, Medea.  From those modest beginnings, the Classics at Brucemore emerged.

Today, the Classics at Brucemore is part of a year-round menu of cultural offerings that re-define the historic site experience for museum goers. In addition to the Classics, audiences this year will gather for the Cedar Rapids Opera Theatre, Brucemore Outdoor Children’s Theater, Cabaret in the Courtyard, the Brucemore Garden and Art Show, Revival Theatre Company, and Brucemorchestra VII.

Peggy retired as Executive Director in 2008, after 27 years leading the organization.  Last fall, Peggy lost her battle with cancer, only weeks after helping to select Hay Fever as this year’s play.  While she will be conspicuously absent from the audience this season, her impact is undeniable. (Read more about Peggy's life and legacy.)

Next year marks the twentieth anniversary of the Classics at Brucemore.  To celebrate the milestone, Brucemore staff is planning improvements for the stage and performance area, to be renamed in Peggy Boyle Whitworth’s honor. 


What We Need & What You Get

While Peggy was passionate about many causes, outdoor theater at Brucemore was especially important to her. With your help, we can honor her memory and celebrate her legacy. 

When outdoor theater at Brucemore began in 1996, contractors built a temporary stage each year as part of the set design.  The 2007 production of Macbeth benefited from a permanent stage built to reduce expenses and foster more frequent use of the area (pictured below with that season's cast and crew).

After seven years of exposure to the elements and general wear, the stage needs maintenance.The extent of work to be completed will depend on the amount of money raised by you. The Brucemore staff envisions improvements to the stage’s physical structure, backstage area, and electrical configuration.

To complete the full scope of work, Brucemore needs to raise $20,000. While the crowdfunding goal is set lower than the end objective, successfully reaching at least $10,000 will allow staff to show community support for the project when applying for other funding opportunities.


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute but still want to help?

  • Help us spread the word by sharing this with friends and family who were inspired by Peggy, have or would enjoy a show in the outdoor amphitheater, or simply love Brucemore
  • Indiegogo makes it easy! Use the share tools to send this campaign to your favorite social media sites


What is Brucemore?

Brucemore is an unparalleled blend of tradition and culture located in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. At the heart of the historic 26-acre estate stands a nineteenth-century mansion filled with the stories of three Cedar Rapids families.  Brucemore’s mission is to engage the public in the history, traditions, resources, and on-going preservation of Brucemore for the enrichment of the community. Each year, over 25 distinct programs enliven the site and celebrate the heritage of a community.

the historic site experience for museum goers. In addition to the Classics, audiences this year will
gather for the Cedar Rapids Opera Theatre, Brucemore Outdoor Children’s Theater, Cabaret in the Courtyard, the Brucemore Garden and Art Show, Revival Theatre
Company, and Brucemorchestra VII.
Peggy retired as Executive Director in 2008, after 27 years
leading the organization.  Last fall,
Peggy lost her battle with cancer, only weeks after helping to select Hay Fever as this year’s play.  While she will be conspicuously absent from
the audience this season, her impact is undeniable. (Read more about Peggy's life and legacy.)Next year marks the twentieth anniversary of the Classics at Brucemore.  To celebrate the milestone, Brucemore staff
is planning improvements for the stage and performance area, to be renamed in
Peggy Boyle Whitworth’s honor.  
What We Need & What You Get While Peggy
was passionate about many causes, outdoor theater at Brucemore was
especially important to her. With your help, we can honor her memory and
celebrate her legacy. When outdoor theater at Brucemore began in 1996, contractors
built a temporary stage each year as part of the set design.  The 2007 production of Macbeth benefited from a permanent stage
built to reduce expenses and foster more frequent use of the area (pictured below with that season's cast and crew). After seven
years of exposure to the elements and general wear, the stage needs
maintenance.The extent of work to be completed will depend on the amount
of money raised by you. The Brucemore staff envisions improvements to the
stage’s physical structure, backstage area, and electrical configuration. To complete
the full scope of work, Brucemore needs to raise $20,000. While the
crowdfunding goal is set lower than the end objective, successfully reaching at least $10,000 will allow staff to show community support for the project when applying
for other funding opportunities.     Other Ways You Can Help Can't contribute but still want to help? 
Help us spread the word by sharing this with friends and family who were inspired by Peggy, have or would enjoy a show in the outdoor amphitheater, or simply love Brucemore
 Indiegogo makes it easy! Use the share tools to send this campaign to your favorite social media sites
What is Brucemore? 
Brucemore is an unparalleled blend of tradition and culture located in Cedar
Rapids, Iowa. At the heart of the historic 26-acre estate stands a
nineteenth-century mansion filled with the stories of three Cedar Rapids
families.  Brucemore’s mission is to engage the public in the
history, traditions, resources, and on-going preservation of Brucemore for the
enrichment of the community. Each year, over 25 distinct programs enliven
the site and celebrate the heritage of a community.

story:
What happens when a director and a playwright have a Facebook showdown?
That becomes a long conversation-
That becomes a creative idea-
That becomes a play?

From the brilliant Diversity Diva, Michelle T. Johnson, playwright of the oft produced Wiccans in the Hood, comes a World Premiere Play,

Trading Races: From Rodney King to Paula Deen 

What if you reduced all black people to one person and all white people to one person and put them in the ring to verbally slug out how both races would continue to co-exist in America? This play explores with humor and uncomfortable truths just how racial tension has led this country to where we are-and how many uncomfortable truths have to unfold for it to continue. Will Billy and Eve fight it out and save our country’s future? Or will Weeping Hawk make America have the ultimate do-over? 

Selected as a World Premiere for the Planet Connections Festivity in New York City before beginning a run at The Walnut Street Theater Studio 5 throughout the month of June!

Transporting these wonderful actors (and one brilliant Stage Manager) to New York City can get expensive and we are asking for your help in alleviating those cost with a donation big or small! 

For a donation of $1 to $100 you will be given a credit as a “peacemaker” in our production! Helping to unite the races as one!
For a donation of $100 and up you will receive 2 free tickets to the NYC or Philadelphia production (your choice!) and a credit as “peacemaker”!
For a Donation of $250 and up you will receive all of the above PLUS your very own “Trading Races” T-Shirt! 
For a Donation of $500 and up you will receive all of the above PLUS a set of “Race Cards” Featuring our multi-cultural cast and crew’s images on a set of playing cards-so next time you want to play a race card-you will have them on hand!
For Donations of $1000 or more-you will receive all of the above, plus a pair of tickets to ALL NYC and Philadelphia Performances AND a credit as Producer! 

Help this cast get to NYC and deliver the performance of a lifetime!

story:
THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR SUPPORT. Unfortunately we didn't reach our target figure, but the funding nver stops so if your want to contribute to the project please visit our page at www.sponsume.com .


Ninth Life WILL be going to Edinburgh, only YOU can allow the project to run at its true potential! Please give generously. Thank you.




This summer, Ninth Life Theatre Company will be performing their brand new play The Questionnaire in Edinburgh, UK, as part of the infamous Edinburgh Festival Fringe. The Edinburgh Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world which last year attracted over 400.000 visitors. Ninth Life will be jostling for space as one of literally hundreds of shows on offer, and so need a play that will stand out from the crowd...

The Questionnaire

"Jack, a man in his early twenties, finds himself locked in a room with only a desk and chair. He suspects a cult, and Jack is relishing the chance to engage in a much-longed for fierce debate and prove his hosts to be all wrong. The reality is quite different, and soon it is his own world view that comes under fierce scrutiny. ‘The Questionnaire’ explores the failure of current British society to acknowledge modern historical, philosophical and political theory, and in particular the effect that this failure has on individuals who attempt to live their lives by these theories. ‘The Questionnaire’ taps directly into the current climate of student dissatisfaction, putting a proudly university-educated young man under the microscope before dissecting and casting him aside. Is knowledge alone enough to break the shackles that our perceived norms have cast upon us?"

The piece is a bizarre, intense and comical descent into Jack's personal crisis of self. As a company we are heavily inspired by the British theatre movement of the 60s & 70s, enjoying their rich text-driven nature and courageous, subversive attitude. The Questionnaire is an attempt to revive that tradition, but critically an attempt to claim it for the disenchanted present. Stylistically we will be enhancing Jack's isolation, a sparse set making him completely exposed to the scrutiny of both the unseen voice interrogating him and the audience. With nothing to hide behind, Jack has only his words with which to defend himself.

How will Ninth Life do it?

The Questionnaire is the first play from Ninth Life, written by company members Christopher Birks and Robert Neumark-Jones. The company is extremely passionate about new writing, and consequently are determined to impress with their first play.

The company has already secured their theatre for the festival. We will be performing for two weeks in 'theSpaces on the Mile', a 55-seat theatre right on the Royal Mile, the artery of the festival. For the final week we will be moving just next door to the 105-seat venue at Nidry Street. We also have arranged our accommodation for the duration.

The play is in excellent shape. being constantly refined and tweaked by writers and performers. It was previewed in December and it is the excellent audience response from that event that has fuelled our journey to Edinburgh. Our director, Tom Spencer, is an accomplished Director with a number of Edinburgh successes to his name and so we are excited about unveiling the finished result.

Ninth Life has formed a collaboration with Tom's company Fine Chisel, meaning that many of the project's costs can be shared. This initiative will not only enable The Questionnaire to be a more cost-effective production, but will also enhance our ability to publicise due to our association with an already proven company.

What's the money for?

Ninth Life is an entirely new company that has formed at a time when funding for the arts in the UK is at its worst in recent history. With no previous income to turn to, nor public funding available, we are having to find all of the money required for the project. Your money, should you be kind enough to exchange it for our rewards, will pay for:

The theatre hire costs
Accommodation for artists
Publicity
Rehearsal room hire
Transport
Set costs
Costumes
Props
...and any other bright ideas that our producer has!

The project will cost £4000 altogether, though our projected income from tickets will be just over £2000. We're therefore looking primarily to cover our £2000 deficit, and all the help that can be offered would be hugely appreciated. While Ninth Life are of course pursuing all funding avenues available to them, it would be wonderful and in tune with the company's ethos if we could be entirely funded by pledges from supportive individuals. The more we raise through methods like Indiegogo means the less we have to raise through less ethical means, i.e. sponsorships. In these times when the arts are increasingly overlooked by the UK government and councils, funding from individuals goes a long way to making a statement about the value of the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Using our Facebook and Twitter, please do keep in touch with us and point us out to your friends. Student/graduate communities are particularly welcomed, as Ninth Life as disenchanted graduates making work that discusses our issues! Beyond that, 'The Questionnaire' appeals to anyone concerned with how to live our lives, and so anyone with an passion for politics, literature, history or even positive-thinking would be interested in our project.

Last but not least, COME TO THE FRINGE, and take literally hundreds of shows from extremely talented emerging artists at the world's largest arts festival!

story:
Thanks for all the support. We had a successful premiere of BOAT at Incubator Arts Project in December. Magnus, Miller, & Truman will continue to develop BOAT for future production. Your contributions were essential in letting this grassroots art happen. We still appreciate any support as the production expenses exceeded expectations. 

Magnus, Miller, & Truman look forward to sharing our future productions. Much thanks to everyone!  


The Company, The Show

Magnus, Miller, & Truman is a collective of artists: Eric Magnus, Tavish Miller, and Nathan Truman. The company is currently focused on creating an art theater piece. MMT conducts work from The Market Hotel, a D.I.Y. establishment in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

BOAT is set on a small ship far out at sea, depicted as MMT imagine this surreal world behaving. The boyish man sailing the boat solo responds to his lonely circumstances by engaging in a series of unrelated performances. He speaks half-remembered conversations, fragments of description, the last words of dreams, prayers and lists while exploring physical strategies to resonate and be received.

MMT developed this unique theater experiment as a way to stage original writings in an environment of exciting theatrical visuals, letting these elements relate compositionally without thematic connection. The boat is the most conjuring setting we could think of, and enlivens the disparate text with wild visions and involving rhythms.

BOAT also features special guest actors who harmonize with the solo man's actions and give separate performances of their own.

Magnus, Miller, & Truman are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas.

BOAT will be premiered December 16th, 17th, and 18th through residency at Incubator Arts Project.

Eric Magnus / Director, Writer
Nathan Truman / Lead Writer, Asst. Director
Tavish Miller / Lead Performer, Writer
Gina Murdock / Performer
Rafael Sanchez / Performer

Dec. 16-18.
16th 8p
17th 8p & 10p 
18th 8p & 10p

Incubator Arts Project,
St. Mark's Church (NYC)
131 East 10th St. at 2nd Ave.
tickets at:http://incubatorarts.org & at the door before show.


Impact

As a young company without any previous credentials as a collective we face funding challenges due to our obscurity. All of us are struggling to live in New York City during this recession, making the consequence of underfunding a big risk. Taking risks, however, is what motivates this project; challenging ourselves through literal experimentation in making a wholly original performance. A little help goes along way and is a vote in support of new emerging work in American performance. 


Double Rewards, Double Rewards

Fortunately, we have been able to keep the overall cost as low as possible. Through the generosity of Incubator Arts Project and Materials for the Arts, we have obtained fabrics and other raw materials to make our densely scenic boat set. We will be using your donations to cover the remainder of material costs (hardware, rigging, wood and electrics), space rental, publicity materials (posters and cards), and importantly, to pay for our skilled Technical Director and Master Electrician who are so crucial to the success of our show. 


All donations come with the satisfaction of helping facilitate a bold experiment in performance. What we receive is the opportunity to make a stimulating piece of art work, impossible without support, which in these hard times is a special privilege.  


Do It With Others

We feel a necessity in art making is COMMUNITY. We have nothing to take, no profit to make. We'd like to involve you in this fulfilling process so please spread the word about this project and come see the show if possible!

story:
*5% OF FUNDS RAISED THROUGH THIS CAMPAIGN WILL BE DONATED TO ADDACTION (www.addaction.org.uk) TO HELP COMBAT DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE AND DEPENDENCY*


Why we need you

HeadFirst Productions is asking for your support in the form of financial sponsorship. We are a new theatre company with a compelling creative and social vision and the people to make it happen. We need your help to fund our inaugural production of Puccini’s masterpiece, La Bohème, and to establish our ambitious Education & Outreach Programme.

This production of La Bohème has been in development since October 2012. Over the past year and a half we have planned, re-evaluated and fine-tuned every aspect of our proposal. Being awarded a grant from the Arts Council England reinforces the value of this project and has reaffirmed our determination for it to be the best it can be. Rehearsals start at the beginning of August, with workshops running throughout the rest of the year. In order to pay our artists’ fees and hire or buy services to make this production happen, we need to raise the remainder of our budget. This is where your support could help substantially.


What is HeadFirst Productions?

HeadFirst Productions is a UK-based, touring theatre company that tells relevant stories, and is committed to developing an Education & Outreach Programme. Our work will consist of both opera and theatre. We are supported by leading theatre and opera director, Jonathan Kent, who has agreed to act as patron to the company.

At HeadFirst Productions we dig deep into classic works of drama to find new perspectives and insights into characters, their situations, and the choices they make. We make theatre for a modern-day audience, by which we simply mean the people who are watching now. Theatre is ultimately made to be seen, be it by an audience of one or by one hundred thousand. All thesocial and cultural ‘noise’ of every day life is integral to how we understand and receive art as well as how we make it. This does not mean that we will update everything to a contemporary setting, rather that we intend to acknowledge shifting perceptions and paradigms whilst we develop our work. 


What people have said about us:

  • “I thought your opera evening was wonderful, a real feast and totally inspiring; really brilliant idea.”
  • “We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and thought the entertainment was of the highest quality.”
  • “Amazing! I laughed, I cried. Can't wait until La Bohème!”
  • “What a great evening, and such amazing talent.”
  • “Completely awesome event. The young (Sevenoaks School) singers in Act One were great. How wonderful to watch a seamless, pacy show without any of the agonising, clunky gaps between individual performances that seem to be the feature of school events. Every performer engaged the audience, and found meaning and heart in every song / aria. Real performances! Note to school: your students can do it if you create the conditions! Act Two was awesome - fabulous voices delivering an hour of opera magic with pace, charm, and emotion. No props, no scenery, no costumes - just blistering talent.”


La Bohème: Our version

HeadFirst Production's inaugural touring production will be Puccini’s La Bohème. Sung in Italian and updated to a contemporary setting, this classic tale will be re-imagined in the 21st century.

Set in a degrading, urban environment where Mimi’s illness is not tuberculosis but Heroin addiction, and her friends are ‘recreational’ drug users, this will be a gritty, harsh retelling of one of the greatest tragic love stories. We aim to make La Bohème easily accessible to opera newcomers and challenge those who know it to experience it afresh. The futility and horror of Mimi’s drug-induced death will make Puccini’s soaring score all the more heart-rending.

Mid-scale opera with an updated English libretto is extremely popular in and around London. However, there is a scarcity of productions sung in the original language. We aim to fill this gap. We will use the inherent musicality of the Italian language in La Bohème to enhance the audience’s emotional engagement, and hook their involvement by making the story vividly relevant; tuberculosis is rare in the modern world, but recreational drug use and dependency on addictive substances is widespread and devastating.


Touring our work

HeadFirst Productions will produce a mid-scale touring production of La Bohème. There will be a minimum of four performances in two venues in the Southeast of England, extending the tour further if possible. So far we have established relationships with The LOST Theatre in Wandsworth and Trinity Theatre in Tunbridge Wells, and are in the process of devising a series of educational workshops with the local communities.


Why our Bohème is needed: Outreach work

Due to the nature of the subject matter of this interpretation, we will be working closely with leading drug and alcohol rehabilitation charity, Addaction (www.addaction.org.uk), to run workshops and develop awareness around substance abuse. These workshops will enable the charity’s service users to take part in discussions and practical workshops exploring opera, lead by a professional animateur.

We are also currently establishing a relationship with the educational music hub, SoundHub, based in Kent, to run a summer holiday workshop programme that will allow students to develop their skills, write music with the help of a composer, and to perform on a professional theatre stage to an invited audience. We hope to be able to provide participants of all of our outreach workshops with heavily discounted – or ideally free – tickets to our shows to allow them to have a full, rounded experience of opera, but this will depend on securing additional funding to cover deficit from the box office return.


Where the money goes

The grant from the Arts Council England will cover just over half of the artistic fees but further sponsorship will cover the costs of hiring the venues, marketing our project, developing our outreach programme, and realising the design.

We have set a target of £2000 on Indiegogo. This money will go directly towards the costs of the costume and set. If we raise more than our target, the extra money will cover fees for the few artists who have offered to work for free until we raise enough money to pay them, on the understanding that this might not happen at all. If we do not raise our full target, everything we do raise will still go towards set and costumes. The Institute of Human Development has agreed to underwrite any loss, so your money will never be in jeopardy.

With your assistance we will produce a fully staged and costumed production of Puccini’s La Bohème, as well as widening access to the arts for children and adults in low-engagement communities.

Please have a look at the right to see what we can offer in return for your help.

In addition to the rewards listed, your donation will:

·  Have an immediate, significant and tangible effect on our work

·  Be the start of a new relationship with a young company

·  Be a valuable way to help to start to engage new audiences


Risks and Challenges

Of course there are always risks when mounting a production at any scale but we are confident that HeadFirst Productions has the skills and experience to overcome any challenges we may face. In the year and half of planning this production we have dealt with various issues and adapted to changing circumstances. This may be our first full scale production but the company comprises individuals with extensive experience of making large and small scale work. We are confident that we have the means to preempt the majority of challenges that will come our way and the flexibility to solve any problems that may arise that we have not already forseen.


Long term ambition

Over the next few years we intend to develop a diverse programme of work from opera to theatre and occasionally combinations of the two. Sometimes we will perform in theatres, sometimes in found spaces. Sometimes the audience will be seated; sometimes they will have to move around. We hope to build a reputation as a theatre company that engages and moves our audiences, producing excellence by questioning the status quo. In the long term we aspire to be regularly programmed for national tours by the country’s leading regional theatres and arts centres.


How else you can help

We know that many of you are not in a position to make a financial contribution, but you can still help. Do please spread the word about our project to people you think may be interested, and even (particularly?) those who have never seen an opera before. If you share this page on social media, someone just might click and donate.

You can also buy tickets for the production by following either of the following links.

For The LOST Theatre, Stockwell: http://losttheatre.co.uk/index.php/whats-on/calendar/11-current-shows/249-la-boheme

For Trinity Theatre, Tunbridge Wells: http://www.trinitytheatre.net/Whats-On/9960-/La-Boheme

To sign up for our mailing list, click here: http://www.headfirstproductions.org/#!contact/c1jns

Say hi on facebook (www.facebook.com/HeadFirstProductions) or twitter (@HeadFirstProd).

To see our biographies, see here and click on the names: http://www.headfirstproductions.org/#!productions/c14o2


If you’d like any more information about us, if you have any questions, or if you just fancy a chat about our work, you can email us at sponsorship@headfirstproductions.org, or write to us as at The Old Inn, Old Eridge Road, Eridge Green, Tunbridge Wells, Kent, TN3 9JF

Company number: 04339882 | Charity number: 1092760

www.headfirstproductions.org


*5% OF FUNDS RAISED THROUGH THIS CAMPAIGN WILL BE DONATED TO ADDACTION (www.addaction.org.uk) TO HELP COMBAT DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE AND DEPENDENCY*

HeadFirst Productions is asking for your support in the
form of financial sponsorship. We are a new theatre company with a compelling creative and social vision and
the people to make it happen. We need your help to fund our inaugural production
of Puccini’s masterpiece, La Bohème, and to establish our
ambitious Education & Outreach Programme.
This production
of La Bohème has been in development
since October 2012. Over the past year and a half we have planned, re-evaluated
and fine-tuned every aspect of our proposal. Being awarded a grant from the Arts Council England reinforces the
value of this project and has reaffirmed our determination for it to be the
best it can be. Rehearsals start at the beginning of August, with workshops
running throughout the rest of the year. In order to pay our artists’ fees and
hire or buy services to make this production happen, we need to raise the
remainder of our budget. This is where your
support could help substantially. 



What is HeadFirst Productions?
HeadFirst
Productions is a UK-based, touring theatre company that tells relevant stories, and is committed to
developing an Education & Outreach
Programme. Our work will consist of both opera and theatre. We are supported by leading theatre and opera
director, Jonathan Kent, who has
agreed to act as patron to the company.
At HeadFirst
Productions we dig deep into classic works of drama to find new perspectives and insights into
characters, their situations, and the choices they make. We make theatre for a
modern-day audience, by which we simply mean the people who are watching now. Theatre is ultimately made to be
seen, be it by an audience of one or by one hundred thousand. All thesocial and
cultural ‘noise’ of every day life is integral to how we understand and receive
art as well as how we make it. This does not mean that we will update
everything to a contemporary setting, rather that we intend to acknowledge shifting perceptions and paradigms
whilst we develop our work. What people have said about us:
“I thought your opera evening was
wonderful, a real feast and totally inspiring; really brilliant idea.”“We
thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and thought the entertainment was of the highest quality.”“Amazing!
I laughed, I cried. Can't wait until La Bohème!”“What
a great evening, and such amazing talent.”“Completely
awesome event. The young (Sevenoaks School) singers in Act One were great. How
wonderful to watch a seamless, pacy show without any of the agonising, clunky
gaps between individual performances that seem to be the feature of school
events. Every performer engaged the audience, and found meaning and heart in
every song / aria. Real performances! Note to school: your students can do it
if you create the conditions! Act Two was awesome - fabulous voices delivering
an hour of opera magic with pace, charm, and emotion. No props, no scenery, no
costumes - just blistering talent.”
La Bohème: Our version
HeadFirst Production's inaugural touring production will be
Puccini’s La Bohème.
Sung in Italian and updated to a contemporary setting, this classic tale will
be re-imagined in the 21st century.
Set in a degrading, urban environment where Mimi’s
illness is not tuberculosis but Heroin addiction, and her friends are ‘recreational’
drug users, this will be a gritty, harsh retelling of one of the greatest tragic love stories. We aim to make La Bohème easily accessible to opera
newcomers and challenge those who know it to experience it afresh. The futility
and horror of Mimi’s drug-induced death will make Puccini’s soaring score all the
more heart-rending.
Mid-scale opera
with an updated English libretto is extremely popular in and around London. However, there
is a scarcity of productions sung in the original language. We aim to fill this
gap. We will use the inherent musicality
of the Italian language in La Bohème
to enhance the audience’s emotional engagement, and hook their involvement by
making the story vividly relevant; tuberculosis is rare in the modern world,
but recreational drug use and dependency on addictive substances is widespread
and devastating.
Touring our work
HeadFirst
Productions will produce a mid-scale
touring production of La Bohème.
There will be a minimum of four performances in two venues in the Southeast of
England, extending the tour further if possible. So far we have established relationships with The LOST Theatre in
Wandsworth and Trinity Theatre in
Tunbridge Wells, and are in the process of devising a series of educational
workshops with the local communities.
Why
our Bohème is needed: Outreach work
Due
to the nature of the subject matter of this interpretation, we will be working
closely with leading drug and alcohol rehabilitation charity, Addaction (www.addaction.org.uk), to run workshops and
develop awareness around substance abuse. These workshops will enable the
charity’s service users to take part in discussions and practical workshops
exploring opera, lead by a professional animateur. 
We
are also currently establishing a relationship with the educational music hub, SoundHub, based in Kent, to run a summer
holiday workshop programme that will allow students to develop their skills,
write music with the help of a composer, and to perform on a professional
theatre stage to an invited audience. We hope to be able to provide
participants of all of our outreach workshops with heavily discounted – or
ideally free – tickets to our shows to allow them to have a full, rounded
experience of opera, but this will depend on securing additional funding to
cover deficit from the box office return.Where the money
goes
The grant from
the Arts Council England will cover
just over half of the artistic fees but further sponsorship will cover the
costs of hiring the venues, marketing our project, developing our outreach
programme, and realising the design. 
We have set a
target of £2000 on Indiegogo. This money will go directly towards the costs of
the costume and set. If we raise more than our target, the extra money will
cover fees for the few artists who have offered to work for free until we raise
enough money to pay them, on the understanding that this might not happen at
all. If we do not raise our full target, everything we do raise will still go
towards set and costumes. The Institute of Human Development has agreed to
underwrite any loss, so your money will never be in jeopardy.
With your assistance
we will produce a fully staged and
costumed production of Puccini’s La
Bohème, as well as widening access
to the arts for children and adults in low-engagement communities.
Please have a
look at the right to see what we can offer in return for your help.
In addition to
the rewards listed, your donation will:
· 
Have an immediate, significant and tangible effect on
our work
· 
Be the start of a new relationship with a young
company
· 
Be a valuable way to help to start to engage new
audiencesRisks and ChallengesOf course there are always risks when mounting a production at any scale but we are confident that HeadFirst Productions has the skills and experience to overcome any challenges we may face. In the year and half of planning this production we have dealt with various issues and adapted to changing circumstances. This may be our first full scale production but the company comprises individuals with extensive experience of making large and small scale work. We are confident that we have the means to preempt the majority of challenges that will come our way and the flexibility to solve any problems that may arise that we have not already forseen. 
Long term ambition


Over the next
few years we intend to develop a diverse
programme of work from opera to theatre and occasionally combinations of
the two. Sometimes we will perform in theatres,
sometimes in found spaces. Sometimes
the audience will be seated; sometimes they will have to move around. We hope
to build a reputation as a theatre company that engages and moves our
audiences, producing excellence by
questioning the status quo. In the long term we aspire to be regularly
programmed for national tours by the country’s leading regional theatres and
arts centres.
How else you
can help

We know that
many of you are not in a position to make a financial contribution, but you can
still help. Do please spread the word
about our project to people you think may be interested, and even
(particularly?) those who have never seen an opera before. If you share this
page on social media, someone just
might click and donate.
You can also buy tickets for the production by
following either of the following links.
For The LOST Theatre, Stockwell: http://losttheatre.co.uk/index.php/whats-on/calendar/11-current-shows/249-la-boheme
For Trinity Theatre, Tunbridge Wells: http://www.trinitytheatre.net/Whats-On/9960-/La-Boheme
To sign up for
our mailing list, click here: http://www.headfirstproductions.org/#!contact/c1jns
Say hi on facebook (www.facebook.com/HeadFirstProductions)
or twitter (@HeadFirstProd).To see our biographies, see here and click on the names: http://www.headfirstproductions.org/#!productions/c14o2
If you’d like any more information about
us, if you have any questions, or if you just fancy a chat about our work, you
can email us at sponsorship@headfirstproductions.org,
or write to us as at The Old Inn, Old Eridge Road, Eridge Green, Tunbridge
Wells, Kent, TN3 9JF
Company number: 04339882 | Charity
number: 1092760
www.headfirstproductions.org*5% OF FUNDS RAISED THROUGH THIS CAMPAIGN WILL BE DONATED TO ADDACTION 
(www.addaction.org.uk) TO HELP COMBAT DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE AND 
DEPENDENCY*

story:
OUR MISSION

Watts Village Theater Company nurtures and produces original works of
theater and educational programming that inspire action and dialogue about contemporary social issues to honor the rich history, cultural diversity and
under-served populations of South Los Angeles.

OUR HISTORY

Watts Village Theater Company (WVTC) is a 501c3 nonprofit arts organization founded in early 1996 by actor and Watts community activist, Quentin Drew, and actor/playwright, Lynn Manning.  From its inception, a core facet of Watts Village Theater Company’s mission has been to promote literacy and greater self-esteem among the youth of Watts and South Los Angeles through internships, volunteer opportunities, and education in the theatrical performing arts. In 2011 WVTC was the recipient of the "American Theatre Wing National Theatre Company Award" as one of the top 10 most promising small theatre companies in the country.

THE PROJECT

We are seeking your help to support not only our site-specific production of Follow by Michael Patrick Spillers, but helping us enter our 19th Season of plays and educational programming. 

Follow is taking place site-specifically at the Watts Coffee House inside of the historic Mafundi Building. The show has opened to rave reviews, here is a collage of our some production stills.

Here is our promo for Follow.


2015 is going to be a year of great artistic accomplishment, including the fully staged production of Riot/Rebellion in honor of the 50th anniversary of the Watts Riots, and the continued growth of our educational programming.

THE NEED

We rely on individual donations for roughly 35% of our production budget. As our mission is to make theater accessible, and provide tickets at only $10,  these donations allow us to pay our artists, provide educational programming for local South Los Angeles schools including tickets to the show, in-class residencies, internships, and after school programming. 

Your gift will allow us:

  • Provide accessible ticket prices for Follow @ only $10
  • Secure materials and production supplies for WVTC's next arts education program in Winter 2014/2015
  • Help Hire Professional Teaching Artists for arts Education programs
  • Assist in securing rehearsal and performance spaces for 2015 performances and educational classes
  • Guarantee the commissioning of  our next workshop: Krip Hop Nation

To thank you for your generous support, we are offering a fun range of unique perks. In addition all giving levels will be added to our website and all production programs moving forward. Another great way to help is to share this page with all your friends via your social media outlets. All gifts are tax deductible and you will receive a receipt upon your donation. 


For nearly 20 years, Watts Village Theater Company has been the leader in providing arts and theatrical opportunities to the under-served communities of Watts and South Los Angeles.  We provide inexpensive and free programming to those most in need of it and who have no other access to the performing arts.  We can only do that with the generous support of our friends and partners. 

Thank you for investing in South Los Angeles’ cultural community and we look forward to seeing you at the theater!

story:
The Plan:

For more than 2 years I've wanted to share my love of dance with fellow Montclair residents so I began planning this event.  Some wonderful people in the community have signed on and donated their services (Toni’s Kitchen, Studio042, TonyTurnerPhotography and Imani).  But before these services were arranged, I reached out the fabulous artists on the roster pleading with them to perform without pay -- they said YES!  This did not sit well with me so I've begun this campaign to help raise funds to pay them.  I ask humbly that you please help to make this exciting plan be realized and equally important, that you help me raise funds to pay the wonderful artists by donating here!

What We Need & What You Get

  • 99% of funds will go directly to the artists.
  • 1% will go to the start ups (domain name, web hosting, Gaffer's tape, ice, water for dancers, gas to pickup the Marley floor, microphone & speakers on loan from the very generous folks at The Wassaic Project [2 hours away], and the other very generous folks of The Spoon Group, lead by Maria Balboa who donated the platforms/stage!
  • Check out the "PERKS" as you consider your dollar amount!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, whatever is raised will go to the artists.

Your Impact

REMEMBER:  The artists agreed to perform without a fee, so your contribution is it! 

(Update as of 9/5) The 2014 Lineup:

Montclair's Mayor Robert Jackson will open the event!

National Director of AileyCamp & Former Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Company Member - Nasha Thomas-Schmitt will host the event! AND 14 year-old Newark dancer, Christopher Taylor joins the roster!

Seán Curran Company, Brice Mousset’s Oui Danse, Maurice Chestnut, Donna Scro’s Freespace Dance, Randy James' 10 Hairy Legs, Nancy Turano’s New Jersey Dance Theater Ensemble, Sharron Miller’s Academy for the Performing Arts’ Performance Workshop Ensemble, and Kathy Costa’s DanceWorks & Company.
  • Montclair residents love dance - BUT - Montclair does not have a free outdoor dance concert.
  • As the lead curator of dance at The Wassaic Project, and co-curator at Harlem Stage's acclaimed dance series - EMoves, more and more companies reach out to me every year for a platform to present their work - Montclair is a fine home for dance
  • After you've given here, you will be proud knowing that you were there from the beginning!

Risks & Challenges

At this last minute (24 days before the show goes up), and after applying for a grant to pay the artists, and to help offset the start up costs just last month, I am worried that we may not receive funding.  The artists deserve to be compensated and I realized that this campaign must happen.   

  • I've secured a great deal of support from Toni’s Kitchen, Studio042, TonyTurnerPhotography and Imani, but nothing financially other than the grant submitted under Imani (a 501c3) to help pay the artists. 
  • We will not know if we received the grant until days before the event.
  • If we receive the grant it will come after the event.
  • We want to pay the artists on the day of the event no matter what.
  • There are individuals who have shared their verbal commitment to making the event happen, so launching this crow funding campaign is a must!
  • Your help is crucial!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, please do consider helping by:

  • Spreading the word in any way you can!
  • Where possible, use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
