story:
Help us bring this historic play to the historic city of New Orleans this November!

About us!

L'illusion Comique is a 1636 play in verse by the French playwright Pierre Corneille. While being popular in French speaking countries, it is rarely performed in English speaking ones. Though other versions exist, and though the play has influenced many other works, Pierre's original is hard to come by this side of the Atlantic.

In this fresh adapted translation, Corneille’s masquerade of buffoonery, betrayal, magic, masks and murder is set in the mysterious bayous of Louisiana. This production captures all the farcical intrigue of the original play, while adding a dash of Cajun spice to create a rollicking evening of theatre.

We were fortunate enough to produce the show once before, at Pace University. But we, we the cast, designers, crew and creative were so passionate about sharing this story and the opportunity to bring this beautiful and exciting theatrical experience to life, that we are now producing the show when and where ever we can! We are currently in the midst of producing the show off-off Broadway October 18th-20th at Under St. Mark’s in the St. Mark's/Astor Place area of New York City; we have appected to the New Orleans Fringe Festival and will be performing the show as part of their 5th Annual Festival!

For more information on the show, us, etc please log on to www.lillusioncomique.info.

What We Need & What You Get

$14,500 is an interesting number. While it is quite a large amount and sometimes seems insurmountable on our end, we know that with your genrous support and word of mouth we can raise it as easily as if it were $14.50.
 
What that $14,500 will go towards is:
*Paying off our venue(s)
*Transportation for our scenary, costumes etc.
*Production value (ie costumes, make-up, set, music etc.)
*If we are accepted to the New Orleans Festival it will help provide housing and travel for our actors and crew as well as other costs
*Marketing
*Transportation/easing the cost of our outreach to high schools
*Miscelaneous other costs including, but not limited to printing costs, rentals fees, application fees for the various opportunities we are looking into, etc.
 
In return, we have some really wonderful "Thank You" perks to offer, as well as all the love and gratitude we have for helping us tell this story again!
 
With your generous support we can bring this forgetten theatrical gem to a whole new audience, here in New York and elsewhere.
 

The Impact

This play is really something unlike anything else. It is funny, provacative, heartwarming, inspiring and above all: entertaining.

In the forward to the 1636 publication of M. Corneille’s manuscript for L’illusion Comique, addressed to the mysterious Madame M F D R, Corneille describes the play as <<un estrange monstre>> translating into English as “a strange monster”.  And that is exactly what the play is. It is at once confined to the French Academy’s criteria for drama: one setting, one day, real time; but it also takes us far from Alcandre’s lair, backwards in time and the illusions we see take place over a period of two years.  It is Baroque in its aesthetic and language, but timeless in its story and themes of love, loss, despair, hope and a theatrical good time.

M. Corneille’s play is full of enough themes and motifs to fill an entire semester of a philosophy class (dealing heavily with Carl Jungian theories of the universal unconcious [centuries before Jung was born!], cognitive disonance, the expectations of parents and of an audience are just a few to name). Ultimately though, the play is about the balance between reality and illusion. The human condition will always be in the balance of what we perceive (illusion) and what is real (truth).  If storytelling is the greatest gift the human race will leave behind (which it is), we will always be victims of our own good stories. Especially living in the technological age, where illusions are so readily available and easy to manipulate upon a computer screen to be told over a cloud to listeners all over the globe, the balance of reality and illusion and human connection is one we shall teeter on forever.

This play speaks to all on a personal level as well: like Clindor, we all eventually leave our father’s home (on more amicable terms, perhaps) and we all like to hope that after all these years and all our separate misadventures, our fathers and we can still look past our own illusions and find each other in the bayou.

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are very difficult. It is a tempestuous world in which we live. We gladly understand if you are unable to contribute to our campaign. We do, however, still need your supprt. Even if you can't, youself, donate, we ask that you help us by spreading the word about our adventure. Perhaps you know someone who really enjoys classical theatre, or you have a friend that loves French literature? Passing the word on is as valuable as the $14,500 we are hoping to raise.
 
Merci Beaucoup. Thank You.
Laissez les bon temps rouler! (Let the good times roll!)

Other Ways You Can Help
Times are very difficult. It is a tempestuous world in which we live. We gladly understand if you are unable to contribute to our campaign. We do, however, still need your supprt. Even if you can't, youself, donate, we ask that you help us by spreading the word about our adventure. Perhaps you know someone who really enjoys classical theatre, or you have a friend that loves French literature? Passing the word on is as valuable as the $14,500 we are hoping to raise.
 

Merci Beaucoup. Thank You.

Laissez les bon temps rouler! (Let the good times roll!)

story:
On May 10th and 11th, a group of thirteen talented actors from The New School's Eugene Lang College will produce a piece of work at La MaMa's Experimental Theatre Club that will challenge and surprise audiences with it's examination of America's obsession with gender, murder and violence.


Reza Abdoh, an Iranian-born playwright, was considered "the next great artist of the theatre world" before his tragic death of AIDS in 1995 at the age of 32. We think the themes in his play "The Law Of Remains" are as relevant today as they were in 1991, when the play first premiered in New York City. We want to continue to push boundaries, challenge ourselves, and redefine what theatre can do to motivate and change lives. Under the direction of Zishan Ugurlu we hope to combine Abdoh's creative mind with our diligent process and fresh insight, to pinpoint some of the ideas that define our generation and our country.


As you are aware, during these times of economic hardship and uncertainty, arts funding has been severely reduced nationwide. We have been allocated $2,000 dollars from our institution to put together a multimedia theatrical event that includes lights, costumes, sets, advertising, and myriad other expenses.  We hope to make our senior thesis a memorable and moving experience for our community as well as a testament to our own commitment to honoring Reza Abdoh's unquestionable effect on New York City's performance world. Whatever you can give will make a critical difference in our success. Whatever you can afford will make a critical difference in re-imagining this fascinating work by Reza Abdoh. We thank you in advance for your generosity and we'll see you at the show!

story:
Short Summary

First of all, thank you so much for checking out this campaign! This project means a lot to us and we appreciate that you took the time out of your life to give us a read.

Front of House Productions was created by Hayley Carr, Megan Powell, and Iain Stewart to provide a creative and co-operative environment for any artist that has had to compromise or sacrifice their work in order to pay the rent. Our goal is to create challenging and risky theatre, by giving artists the freedom to explore and produce work that inspires them.

For our inaugural production we will be putting on John-Paul Sartre’s classic play “No Exit,” adapted by Paul Bowles, and this is where we need your help. All the funds from this campaign will go towards making this show a reality, and launching Front of House Productions. 

Though written in the 1940s, “No Exit” remains extremely relevant and provocative today. Set in an unassuming room, we encounter three recently deceased characters that are fated to spend eternity locked in a room together. They enter expecting fire and brimstone, yet it is slowly revealed that, in fact, “Hell is other people”, that their fellow prisoners will serve as the judge and jury for their sins on Earth.

In this era of Youtube, Twitter, and Facebook, where the all-seeing eye of a globalized media community never blinks, we believe this story is universally relevant. We are no longer able to hide our embarrassing slip-ups or dirty little secrets when camera phones are everywhere and reality television demands a constant stream of scandal and villains. The questions that Jean-Paul Sartre asks in “No Exit” are still vital today; Are we responsible for the choices we make? If we truly have free will to make these choices do we really feel remorse? And finally, if there is no divine judgment where do we find absolution for the demons that live behind our public faces?

By donating to our campaign you will be helping us put on this amazing show and launching a new theatre company, providing emerging artists with the opportunity to make theatre that is challenging and interesting, and allowing us to have more creative control over the entire process. In the end you will be helping to make theatre more engaging for you, the audience!

What we need

This is our first endeavor as a production company, and with no government funding we have been working for over a year, fundraising and networking to get the money to cover the initial expenses, now we need your help to cover the last leg of the journey. All of the costs broken down below are the BARE MINIMUM of what it takes to get a show up and running in Toronto, every dime of our proposed goal would be going towards our debut production of “No Exit.” If we exceed our goal (which would be amazing!) all the extra proceeds would go directly towards funding Front of House Production’s future projects.

Our Budget

Rehearsal space: $700

Performance space: $1300

Performance rights: $525

Sets and costumes: $250

Video equipment: $250

Marketing and publicity: $500

Lighting and set designer: $200

Actors, director, and crew: $275

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate money to our campaign, we understand, although there are many other ways to help us out! Word of mouth is a powerful tool in our media dominated world; share our campaign on Facebook or Twitter, tell your friends through your blog. We greatly appreciate any help at all, and encourage you to patronize the arts. Help up-and-coming and unique theatre thrive in our community!

fohtheatre.com

frontofhousetheatre@gmail.com

 

This is a Canadian Actors' Association Production under the Artists' Collective Policy.

story:
O, Fallen One: Our Story

"It shall be so, Madness in great ones must not unwatched go."

Jaymie Bellous and Megan Ruble, co-producers, co-creaters, and the director and leading actress for O, Fallen One are both recent graduates of UC, Irvine.  While there, they both studied both Shakespeare and UCI's particular brand of movement, which stems from modern dance and mime technique. Out of the college world and into the real one, they stumbled upon the Hollywood Fringe Festival.  Brimming with excitement, knowledge, and creativity they thought "Why not?" and embarked on the journey that led to this project's creation.

O, Fallen One is the result of this communion of creativity.  On the surface, Ophelia has always appeared to be the perfect image of fairness and beauty. Slowly losing control of her own life, Ophelia is left to find her own escape from a world of restraint, deceit, and loss. Through movement, sound, and poetry, O, Fallen One explores what Shakespeare’s fallen damsel would dream, imagine, and recall as she descends to her death.

What We Need & What You Get

Your assistance will help us make this a reality.  Funds will be appropriated to the following areas:

  • Theatre Rental            
  • Advertising              
  • Costumes          
  • Posters
  • Fringe Participant Fees    
  • Props                    
  • Programs            

While some of these are just needed to make our show happen, budget items such as working with the Fringe and advertising are needed to make our show a success.  If the Indiegogo community is incredibly supportive and we exceed our goal, we can continue to develop the show after Fringe.  Your support could even help us create new works after the success of O, Fallen One.  

Don't forget to check out the perks we offer!  We have some unique gifts to offer that will enhance your experience of our show before and after.  Most notably, we have premium seats: a HUGE perk or a convenient tool if you're play-hopping during the Festival.  

For the Doubtful

We truely believe in this project not only as a great artistic feat but as a necessary experience.  The Shakespeare lovers of the world will love our piece, but it is the women of the world, especially those struggling with abusive relationships, emotionally damaging families, suicidal thoughts or those that are held back from independent thought by ANY person, that will benefit most.  To see the story told of a young woman whipped about by the winds of the men in her life, and to see how her future may, or may not have been played out would be a tribute to the struggles of every woman.

For them, this story needs to be told.

I Love This! But I Can't Donate

We completely understand if a donation doesn't fit into your budget at this time- BUT you can still help!  Share us on Indiegogo, Facebook, Twitter- we have sites on all three.  Spread the word amongst your artist friends or Shakespeare-loving friends.  We'd love it if you spread the word about Hollywood Fringe Festival as well- we're only a part of one incredible festival.

Every and any contribution is greatly appreciated.  Thank you for helping to turn this spark of creativity into a great flame.  We hope to see you at the theatre!

Jaymie Bellous & Megan Ruble

Curlicue & Co.

story:
What we're doing.

SHE KILLS MONSTERS by Qui Nguyen, presented by Buzz22 Chicago as part of the 2013 GARAGE REP: three productions presented in rotating repertory at The Garage at Steppenwolf from some of Chicago's most innovative, young theatre companies.

The story.

Agnes' life is turned upside down when she stumbles upon her late sister's  Dungeons & Dragons notebook. As she embarks on an action-packed quest to save her sister’s soul, Agnes comes face to face with homicidal fairies, raunchy ogres, and blood thirsty cheerleaders, discovering a side of herself she never knew existed. Qui Nguyen’s touching comedy combines real life, fantasy and 90’s pop culture in the search for the badass in us all. 

Why we're doing it.

Buzz22 Chicago stages stories to explore the constant coming of age: the ever-occurring moments that challenge who we are and who we want to be.

From the first time we came in contact with this heartfelt & adventurous script, we knew we had to tell this story. We couldn't be more grateful for the opportunity to share something so immediate, joyful and unique.     

Why you should help.

SHE KILLS MONSTERS is the largest project we've tackled yet. Your donation will directly contribute to bringing each design element - from our fight weapons to our fantasy costumes - to their peak potential of epic-ness. Please help us tell this story how it's meant to be told! Check out the video for some design renderings from costume designer, Rachel Goldberg; set designer, William Boles; and during the "badass" montage, the musical stylings of our composer, Matt Deitchman. 

More info at: buzz22chicago.com

 Thanks so much - can't wait to see you in the audience.

story:
Hi! My name is Rachel, and I am the producer of Arts Alliance's spring mainstage, Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, coming to the Norris Center of Northwestern University May 16-18. This "in your face" rock musical is entirely student produced... and it needs your support to help fund it!

-----

"My name is Andrew Jackson, and I'm here to speak with you about the future of this incredible country!"

Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson redefines America's seventh President as an emo rock star—spiky hair and 'guyliner' included! With angsty anthems and lusty ballads, Jackson and the rest of the band will lead us through his struggles with populism, the Indian Removal Act, and his relationship with his wife Rachel. Ninety minutes of self-cutting, dick jokes, political idealism, and screamo music, Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson is the loudest, wildest, and bloodiest concert you'll see this spring.

-----

"These are complicated times, and today we're going to need to make some complicated decisions!"

Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson is the event of the season—and it's completely student-produced! To make this show as big as it can possibly be, we as a team must raise at least $5000. Although ticket sales will help us recoup a portion of these funds at the end of our process, we have many more aspects to pay for before the show even opens! These include the set, lights, sound, costumes, props, hair & makeup, advertising, and the coolest theatrical element of all... blood! (Fake, of course!)

We have a bunch of awesome perks to offer to the right of this page for every person who donates money to the show. However, every donation is appreciated, from $5 to $5000, because it means we're one step closer to putting on an incredible show.

-----

"But we're gonna make those decisions together! I'm promising you transparency, accountability, and open collaboration between you and me."

Arts Alliance, the oldest and largest student arts group at Northwestern and in the country, is committed to providing diverse, accessible, and fulfilling artistic experiences in order to enrich the Northwestern University and Evanston communities. In truth, Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson could not be funded without the generous donations from the people who matter most to the entire cast and team—our families, our friends, our teachers, our mentors, etc. We appreciate every donation we receive, no matter how large or small!

-----

"Because I'm the people's president, and I'm here to be your friend, to be your advocate, to be your voice."

Do you know someone involved in the show? We have over 50 students in the cast and production team alone, and each member is as valuable as the next.

CAST/BAND: Juanita Andersen, Ben Barker, Sarah Cartwright, Matt Dial, Scott Egleston, Gaby FeBland, Michael Kaish, Conor Keelan, Aubrey McGrath, Dylan Pager, Dylan Pickus, Jeff Sachs, Jon Schneidman, Ari Shapiro, Laura Winters

TEAM: Kendall Beeman, Anna Civik, Justin Connolly, Elizabeth Dauterman, Nick Day, Juli Del Prete, Shannon Desmond, Matthew Filak, Sam Garrott, Alex Gold, Josh Gordon, David Griffin, Claire Gutermuth, Janice Johnson, Michael Kaish, Matt Kania, Grace Kennedy, Gavi Keyles, Daphne Kim, Jessie Klueter, Katherine Koller, Kyle Largent, Rachel Marchant, JJ Marquis, Meghan McCarter, Bridget McNamara, Parker Murphy, Maia Nowack, Charlie Oh, Catherine Reid, Polina Senderova, Alex Shaffer, Bex Siegel, Matthew Silverman, Jared Sprowls, Brennan Suen, Jacob Trauberman, Mahek Tulsiani, Nathan Villa, Alex Wolfe

-----

"It's morning again in America, and I'm your President: Andrew Jackson!"

Is donating just not enough? Come see the show and hang out with us this spring! Our show times are:

  • Thursday, May 16th @ 11PM
  • Friday, May 17th @ 8PM and 11PM
  • Saturday, May 18th @ 8PM and 11PM

All shows will take place in the Louis Room of the Norris University Center (1999 Campus Dr, Evanston). General admission to the show is $5 for students (with valid ID) and $10 for the general public.

-----

Thank you so much for your time, and thank you for your endless support of Northwestern student theatre. I hope to see you at the show!

Sincerely,

Rachel Marchant
Producer, Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson
BBAJ@u.northwestern.edu
(215) 290-6164

Lyrics of each subheading are from "Crisis Averted" (music by Michael Friedman, lyrics by Alex Timbers).

Sincerely,
Rachel MarchantProducer, Bloody Bloody Andrew JacksonBBAJ@u.northwestern.edu(215) 290-6164

story:
Short Summary

Pallas Theatre Collective is excited to be producing a staged reading of the new Poe-inspired musical Usher, on June 22nd in Washington DC, directed by artistic director Tracey Chessum. In July, we offer The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love, short scenes by Anton Chekhov selected and directed by Ty Hallmark, at the Capital Fringe festival in DC and at two locations in Maryland.

Please help support our Table Read of Usher. Based on Edgar Allan Poe’s story “The Fall of the House of Usher,” this new show asks: how far would you go to keep those you loved from leaving? When painter James Cleary is summoned to the Usher mansion to paint a portrait of his ailing childhood friend, he falls in love with his friend’s sister Madeline only to uncover a sinister vein running through the Usher family line that rocks the house to its foundation. We are excited to announce that lyricist Molly Fox and composer Sarah Hirsch will be joining us for rehearsals and this special performance.

Please help support The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love, too. Some marriages are farcical, some are tragical, but all are challenging! Famous nineteenth-century playwright Anton Chekhov wrote a series of amusing short scenes about love and marriage. Our actors trace the course of surprisingly modern relationships as they flow from courtship to family duty – not forgetting the experience of dealing with the in-laws. From “The Proposal” to “The Wedding” to “The Anniversary,” Chekhov’s work examines the human impulse to make melodrama out of life events.

What We Need & What You Get

Making good theatre isn’t easy – or cheap. Pallas is careful with our pennies, but we need help to our ambitious summer season fly.

Here’s what our funds, and your donations, make possible:

Printing: We print musical scores for Usher and scripts for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love, which adds up to $365. We need to make sure potential audiences know what’s going on, and although we can do a lot of social media outreach, we still have to print posters and postcards for events at a cost of $205. We also need about $115 to print playbills and flyers so our audiences have something in hand identifying the show and the work of the artists.

Design and Production: Our productions are deliberately spare. Instead of focusing on tricky scenery or glorious fabric, our actors focus on their performance and our audiences can focus on the story. But we still need to create an environment that will support the story so our scenic budget is $150 with an additional $100 to cover props. Our actors have to look and feel in-character on stage; we’ve budgeted $250 to cover everything from petticoats to shoes for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love.

Spaces: The Capital Fringe participation fee of $575 ensures we have a great performance space for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love in Washington DC. Usher will be presented at Studio 1469 in Washington DC. One night at this unique multipurpose venue costs us $250, plus an additional $250 refundable deposit.

Personnel: Our artists love theatre but they are also trained professionals who deserve to be paid for their work – or at least to cover the gas money they spend going to and fro. We want to take care of our people, so we estimate needing $1900 to pay our artists. How did we reach this figure? Paying 7 actors just $50 each for their work in Usher will cost $350, and offering 9 actors a $100 stipend for weeks of work on The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love adds up to $900. For the musical, we also need to hire a professional accompanist for four days, and we offered a $250 award to the creators of Usher for having the winning submission in our selection process.

What you get: Donors get the immense satisfaction of helping a small theatre company produce interesting new work with great artists. Is that not enough? Well, we have some other great perks! Our audience is our biggest asset and we want everyone to experience a Pallas show, so we’re giving away tickets to all our shows, as well as limited edition Pallas t-shirts, special event invitations, and (for those over age 21) we offer a donor gift of wine hand-picked by our artistic director.

The Impact

There are lots of great little theatre companies, so what makes Pallas Theatre Collective special? Pallas is committed to producing new works, especially musicals. America has a great tradition of creating innovative, beautiful Musical Theatre works, but today it can be a challenge for creators to find a place for new shows. Most theatres want to see a proven track record before they will produce a musical. Pallas Theatre exists to bridge this gap. Here, creators workshop their musical in front of a live audience and have the opportunity for the show to evolve into a full production. America also has a great tradition of revisiting and reimagining classic dramas. Pallas provides a home for creative artists to reinvent older works that speak to us in new ways.

Pallas already has a record of producing creative new works and adaptations. Pallas’s first production in 2011 was The Many Women of Troy, a new musical inspired by Euripides’ Trojan Women and written by Michael John Boynton and Brian Allan Hobbs. The Many Women of Troy time-traveled to specific eras, exploring how violence affects women’s lives across history. Tracey Chessum adapted Shakespeare’s Comedy of Errors as The Comedy of Mirrors. Following this, Pallas offered the gender-bending Criss-Cross Cabaret, original pieces developed by actors. Recently, Tracey helmed a dark journey through the psychological underpinnings of The Tempest: Such Stuff as Dreams are Made On. We’ve produced at the Hollywood Fringe in LA and the Capital Fringe Festival in DC, as well as at Bus Boys & Poets and in found spaces in Maryland.

Other Ways You Can Help

Although we need funds to support our projects, your presence is also a gift. Regardless of donation size, you can continue to help us by attending our shows and bringing your friends! Our full schedule for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love can be found at: http://www.pallastheatre.org/season/marriage

You can also let others know about our fundraising campaign at Indiegogo by using the “share” tools.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Pallas Theatre Collective is excited to be producing a staged reading of the new Poe-inspired musical Usher, on June 22nd in Washington DC, directed by artistic director Tracey Chessum. In July, we offer The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love, short scenes by Anton Chekhov selected and directed by Ty Hallmark, at the Capital Fringe festival in DC and at two locations in Maryland.
Please help support our Table Read of Usher. Based on Edgar Allan Poe’s story “The Fall of the House of Usher,” this new show asks: how far would you go to keep those you loved from leaving? When painter James Cleary is summoned to the Usher mansion to paint a portrait of his ailing childhood friend, he falls in love with his friend’s sister Madeline only to uncover a sinister vein running through the Usher family line that rocks the house to its foundation. We are excited to announce that lyricist Molly Fox and composer Sarah Hirsch will be joining us for rehearsals and this special performance.
Please help support The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love, too. Some marriages are farcical, some are tragical, but all are challenging! Famous nineteenth-century playwright Anton Chekhov wrote a series of amusing short scenes about love and marriage. Our actors trace the course of surprisingly modern relationships as they flow from courtship to family duty – not forgetting the experience of dealing with the in-laws. From “The Proposal” to “The Wedding” to “The Anniversary,” Chekhov’s work examines the human impulse to make melodrama out of life events.
What We Need & What You Get
Making good theatre isn’t easy – or cheap. Pallas is careful with our pennies, but we need help to our ambitious summer season fly.
Here’s what our funds, and your donations, make possible:
Printing: We print musical scores for Usher and scripts for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love, which adds up to $365. We need to make sure potential audiences know what’s going on, and although we can do a lot of social media outreach, we still have to print posters and postcards for events at a cost of $205. We also need about $115 to print playbills and flyers so our audiences have something in hand identifying the show and the work of the artists.
Design and Production: Our productions are deliberately spare. Instead of focusing on tricky scenery or glorious fabric, our actors focus on their performance and our audiences can focus on the story. But we still need to create an environment that will support the story so our scenic budget is $150 with an additional $100 to cover props. Our actors have to look and feel in-character on stage; we’ve budgeted $250 to cover everything from petticoats to shoes for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love.
Spaces: The Capital Fringe participation fee of $575 ensures we have a great performance space for The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love in Washington DC. Usher will be presented at Studio 1469 in Washington DC. One night at this unique multipurpose venue costs us $250, plus an additional $250 refundable deposit.
Personnel: Our artists love theatre but they are also trained professionals who deserve to be paid for their work – or at least to cover the gas money they spend going to and fro. We want to take care of our people, so we estimate needing $1900 to pay our artists. How did we reach this figure? Paying 7 actors just $50 each for their work in Usher will cost $350, and offering 9 actors a $100 stipend for weeks of work on The Tragical Mirth of Marriage and Love adds up to $900. Our audience is our biggest asset and we want everyone to experience a Pallas show, so we’re giving away tickets to all our shows, as well as limited edition Pallas t-shirts, special event invitations, and (for those over age 21) we offer a donor gift of wine hand-picked by our artistic director.
The Impact

America has a great tradition of creating innovative, beautiful Musical Theatre works, but today it can be a challenge for creators to find a place for new shows. Most theatres want to see a proven track record before they will produce a musical. Pallas Theatre exists to bridge this gap. Here, creators workshop their musical in front of a live audience and have the opportunity for the show to evolve into a full production. America also has a great tradition of revisiting and reimagining classic dramas. Pallas provides a home for creative artists to reinvent older works that speak to us in new ways.
Pallas already has a record of producing creative new works and adaptations. Pallas’s first production in 2011 was The Many Women of Troy, a new musical inspired by Euripides’ Trojan Women and written by Michael John Boynton and Brian Allan Hobbs. The Many Women of Troy time-traveled to specific eras, exploring how violence affects women’s lives across history. Tracey Chessum adapted Shakespeare’s Comedy of Errors as The Comedy of Mirrors. Following this, Pallas offered the gender-bending Criss-Cross Cabaret, original pieces developed by actors. Recently, Tracey helmed a dark journey through the psychological underpinnings of The Tempest: Such Stuff as Dreams are Made On. We’ve produced at the Hollywood Fringe in LA and the Capital Fringe Festival in DC, as well as at Bus Boys & Poets and in found spaces in Maryland.
Other Ways You Can Help
Although we need funds to support our projects, your presence is also a gift. Regardless of donation size, you can continue to help us by attending our shows and bringing your friends! story:
Welcome to Can't Stand Sitting Productions!


Who We Are


Can’t Stand Sitting is a new Theatre company designed to create new works and adaptations that challenge the status quo. We seek to create work that is affordable without sacrificing quality and to give both young and experienced actors a place to grow and perform together in a variety of ways.

Already this company has hired over 50 creatives this year, and with your help, we are hoping to be able to continue this trend well into the new year. 

This year we are seeking to produce one new comedy, one well-loved classic show, three shadow-box shows to feature a large group of talented musical theatre performers throughout the city of Toronto (and beyond!) and a few cabarets designed to tickle the souls of those who attend. 

To do this, we require your help. 


What do you really want?

On September 20th-22nd, we will be performing our premiere show, Killer Diction. In order for us to be able to perform this show, we need to be able to raise $2500 to cover the costs of our lights, our set, paint, and to replace our drunken coffee table that we have affectionately named "Ping". (Ping isn't what we call, stage-ready) 

Plus, I would love to be able to actually guarantee my actors some form of loving payment. (A pittance of what they really deserve mind you, but this is the life of a theatre company after all) 

For those of you who need the hard numbers:

  • Our space will cost us $1,200 dollars
  • Sets and Costumes go for $500 - (including paint and glue- glue is important!) 
  • Props (Not including bananas) - $197
  • Props- (Bananas) $3
  • Lights- $400
  • Theatre Renovations - $300
We are currently working out a beautiful theatre on Gerrard st east called "Big Picture Cinema", formerly known as "The Projection Booth" and various other incarnation over the past century. This building has been operating since 1911 and is Toronto's oldest continually-operating


cinema. We have taken pride in our space and have committed to help bring it up to a exciting and dynamic new space while embracing it's rustic roots.

Help us! Aide us! Fix us!



Killer Diction

Killer Diction is a new script by Matti McLean and the first production of Can't Stand Sitting. It is a story of love, loss and limbs and features a talented cast of 10 performers.

Jacob lives a quiet life. A humble job, with easy work and good friends. But everything changes when he accidentally picks a fight with the god of death. His life is turned upside down by raining cats, friends turned enemies and a mutilation or two.  Full of memorable characters and quick dialogue, “Killer Diction” promises to be a fast-paced and exciting production.


It will premiere September 20th (to rave reviews) at Big Picture Cinema at 1035 Gerrard St. E.

Starring:
Michael Musi as Jacob
Matthew Ryan as Seth
Kari Kinnear as Maggie
Jada Rifkin as Penny
Kevin Leask as William
Brandon Knox as Albert
Ari Leask as Sparks
and featuring Katrina Weisz as Clifford and Matti McLean as Aunt Jesse

Our Future

Without you: NOTHING! We will wither away and die like a husk of stale bread!

But with you, we can CONQUER THE WORLD!

Or at least put on a really amazing and kick-ass show. 

We have a huge variety of amazing perks including buttons, (Literally HUNDREDS of BUTTONS!) drinks, popcorn, reserved seating, signed posters, private shows and of course, tickets to our shows! 

As a preview, check out some of our fancy-pants buttons here!


Our Upcoming Shows!

October 27-29 : Nightmare Before Christmas : The Shadowbox
November 15-17 : Moulin Rouge : The Shadowbox
December 4: Insignificant Me: The Cabaret
December 6-8 : South Park: Bigger, Longer, Uncut, Shadowboxed
December 13-15 : Importance of Being Earnest

story:
Short Summary

Hello lovely humans! My name is Faeryn and my hoop sister here is Ahni Radvanyi. Together we are the Electric Fairies, two hoop dancing fairies who live to share our dance! We are so excited to have been chosen to be a part of the Electric Forest 2013 Hoop Troupe of the Electric Forest festival in Rothbury Michigan. However, The Electric Fairies are based in Venice CA and the festival can't pay for our travel expenses to get out to Michigan. Neither can we, unfortunately. But rather than let this extraordinary opportunity to launch our professional dance careers slip from our hands, we open it up to you, our beloved fans, friends and family, to help us share our art and our love for hoop dance with the folks back East. Give what you can, get some fun perks in exchange, and help the Electric Fairies move forward on our journey toward success!

What We Need & What You Get

We need two roundtrip plane tickets to Michigan which right now are running about $550.

The last bit of change (about $100) we need to help pay for gas on a rideshare between the airport and the festival and back to the airport.

Our perks are little tokens representing the Electric Fairies spirit and flare. Our wrist fluffies and tails are costume pieces we wear for each of our performances and videos. Of course, we love hoops of all styles and sizes and would love to place your very own hoop in your hands! We can't wait to see you discover the magic of hoop dance too! Our Hoop Journey Starter kit, consisting of your very own hoop plus one private hoop dance lesson, is the best way to launch into your new hoop and begin your journey into hoop dance!

If we do not reach our goal, we might not make it to our performance in the Forest, but we will use the money you contribute to move forward on the goals of the Electric Fairies performance duo. We need to pay for the creation of a professional logo, promotional materials, and performance reels. We also would love to accuire professional facepaints to expand our event offerings. 

The Impact

By supporting our campaign you are stupporting the expression of our art and our ability to share this art with a new audience. We live to share the art of hoop dance and desire so deeply to share our unique expression of this art to the folks back east in Michigan. We havn't ever had the chance to see our countrymen and women in the far East but we are sure they will be touched and inspired by the California freedom and outrageous spirit the Electric Fairies bring. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you so much for taking interest in our campaign and our story! We understand that right now might not be the best time for you to contribute money so if you still want to help us reach our goal please share this link and our video with your friends! Use Indiegogo's share tools as this is the best way to direct them back to this page. THANK YOU so much for your help and your support in our efforts. We love you and send you a thousand fairy blessings!!

story:
SOS-ATELIER

/QUI IN ITALIANO // BELOW IN ENGLISH

CHI SIAMO

L'Atelier Teatro Fisico è un'associazione culturale no-profit nata per promuovere il concetto di teatro fisico e per sviluppare un programma di formazione delle arti performative (teatro, mimo, danza, musica, le arti circensi e altro) innovativo e unico nel suo genere in Italia.

Fondato nel 1995 da Philip Radice, L’ATF è un luogo di aggregazione dove i professionisti e gli aspiranti giovani artisti possono incontrarsi per un reciproco e stimolante scambio artistico e culturale. Con il tempo L’ATF è diventato un'eccellenza riconosciuta sul territorio piemontese, in Italia e all’estero, e assieme ad altre realtà cittadine, scuole di circo e di teatro, abbiamo contribuito a rilanciare Torino come importante centro culturale e artistico.

La nostra Associazione non si limita alla formazione di attori e artisti di arti performative, ma dà la possibilità ad ogni giovane di esprimere il proprio talento e la propria unicità mettendosi costantemente in gioco tramite laboratori, spettacoli e rassegne organizzati da noi. 

ESSERE O NON ESSERE

Dal 9 marzo 2013 le nostre attività sono a rischio! A seguito di un'ispezione del Comune di Torino, la parte seminterrata dei locali dell'Atelier é stata chiusa, in quanto non idonea alle normative di legge. Ciò ha comportato un impedimento del normale svolgimento delle attività, mettendo a rischio la sopravvivenza stessa dell'Atelier e in difficoltà tutti i giovani artisti che lo frequentano.

Per la ristrutturazione dell'Atelier abbiamo bisogno di circa 45.000-50.000 euro, cifra assolutamente fuori portata per la nostra associazione. È per questo che ci rivolgiamo ad ognuno di voi, agli appassionati sostenitori delle arti performative, spettatori, amici teatranti, e artisti, a chi crede nell’arte come parte indispensabile dell’esperienza umana: non lasciate che l'Atelier Teatro Fisico Philip Radice chiuda.

L' Atelier Teatro Fisico Philip Radice è uno spazio in cui ogni giovane può trovare la propria identità, grazie all’incontro con persone capaci di guidarlo verso una crescita artistica e personale. Un luogo dove ogni individuo, nell'incontro e nella scoperta della diversità dell'altro, trova il proprio originale talento ed una personale "idea di teatro". Un luogo libero, stimolante, creativo, ma anche economicamente accessibile a tutti.

AZIONE – Entrate in scena

La vostra donazione* ci aiuterà per rimettere a norma la parte seminterrata della scuola, adeguando gli impianti di areazione, il sistema elettrico e il riscaldamento. E’ prevista anche la ristrutturazione di una sala al piano superiore, dove verrà allestito un piccolo teatro nel quale poter organizzare i nostri Performing Party, serate di cabaret in cui i giovani dell'Atelier si misurano col pubblico presentando i loro numeri. Inoltre, sarà così possibile realizzare la sesta edizione della rassegna di teatro comico POTPOURRI, momentaneamente sospesa. Tale rassegna è rivolta ad artisti professionisti emergenti e vanta tra le sue collaborazioni artisti quali: Rita Pelusio, Antonio Rezza,Flavia Mastrella, Eugenio Allegri, Arturo Brachetti, Johnny Melville, le Sorelle Suburbe, Claudia Penoni e molti altri.

*La donazione può essere detratta dall’irpef, chiedeteci la ricevuta.

Per info: segreteria@teatrofisico.com | +39 3481026073

***************************************

ENGLISH

ATELIER TEATRO FISICO PHILP RADICE

In 1995, Philip Radice founded the no-profit cultural center, ATELIER TEATRO FISICO to promote the concept of physical theatre and develop in Italy an innovative and unique educational program for the performance arts. Today the Atelier Teatro Fisico is a center of creativity and education where young artist can encounter qualified teachers and professionals for reciprocal stimulating exchanges. Overtime we have become well known in the region Piedmont, in Italy and abroad alongside other artistic realities like circus schools, which have contributed to the rebirth of Turin as an important cultural and artistic center. 

TO BE OR NOT TO BE

After almost 20 years of continuous activity, following controls by the city of Turin, the semi-underground spaces of the building used for teaching and rehearsals, were closed down because they did not meet the new building codes. Consequently, an ordinance was issued immediately blocking their use, which effectively halted normal activity, putting at risk the survival of the ATELIER, and making it difficult to continue the studies of the young artists who are enrolled.

The cost of renovating and adapting the spaces to the norms which would permit us to reopen the space and, thus, to continue our normal activities, would amount close to €45.000-€50.000 ($59,000-65,000,00 dollars). An expense unsustainable for our limited resources! 

ACTION – Enter on Stage

We are turning to you, the passionate supporters of the performing arts, theatre goers, theatre lovers, actors, actresses, street performers, circus performers, technicians, and all who believe in the arts as an indispensible human experience, to support us with a personal donation, and help us realize the renovation necessary to meet the building codes and give new life to our performance activities!

Your donation will pay for the renovation of the underground spaces, provide a state of the art air maintenance system required by city code, update electrical and heating systems, and guarantee that fire and safety codes are met. In addition, a room at the ground level can be converted into a small theatre space fit for performances to the public giving our students the possibility to play more often before an audience. It will be able to host our small theatre festival, POTPOURRI, dedicated to emerging artist and their original work.

Please give us a hand to reopen the ATELIER TEATRO FISICO and begin anew our artistic activities. In this way, you will give young persons the opportunity to continue their art education and development, and offer support in fostering an artistic community. 

For further informations: segreteria@teatrofisico.com | +39 3481026073

PERKS

€ 1 WANNA HELP BUT…

For anyone that sympathizes, but really doesn’t have the means to help, and might find themselves in a similar situation as ours! One euro and we’ll work to keep you laughing!

 

€ 5 TEXT ON THE STAGE…
For anyone that has ever seen theatre and knows the ups and the downs. Receive a melodramatic text message of thanks from the director Philip Radice.

 

€ 10 SEE YOUR NAME ON THE CREDITS…
Donate €10 or more and see your name on the websites donor page!

 

€ 30 YOUR NAME DISPLAY ON OUR WEBSITE WALL
Donate € 30 or more and your name will be displayed on our contributors wall on the website:
www.sos-atelierphilipradice.com!

 

€ 50 IMMORTALIZED: NAME ON THE DONOR’S WALL
Donate €50 all of the above plus your name be engraved permanently on the wall dedicated to donors in the Small Theatre!

 

€ 100 AUTHOR’S PEROGATIVE
Contributing €100 plus you’ll receive all of the above, and we will add your name permanently with a short quote of your choice from a play displayed on a “real” wall in the school.

 

€ 250 THE DIRECTORS SEAT
Donate 250,00 all of the above and we’ll add a chair in the theatre with your name on a plaque, dedicated to you.

 

€ 1000 LEADING ROLE
Donate €1000,00 or more, all of the above plus the students will create a comedy sketch with the roles played with the donors’ name send in a personalized video.

 

€ 10.000 PERFORMING ARTS OSCAR
Awesome! If this happens, our spaces now named after famous comedians will display your name on a special plaque, and will be named after you if you so wish! (Or named after your favorite actor/comedian). Largest contributor after €10.000 will have the theatre named after them. What more could you ask!!!

 

Exchange rate: 1 euro = $1.30 approx
example: €10.00 euros => $13.00 dollars

Con il tempo L’ATF è diventato un'eccellenza riconosciuta sul territorio piemontese, in Italia e all’estero, e assieme ad altre realtà cittadine, scuole di circo e di teatro, abbiamo contribuito a rilanciare Torino come importante centro culturale e artistico.
La nostra Associazione non si limita alla formazione di attori e artisti di arti performative, ma dà la possibilità ad ogni giovane di esprimere il proprio talento e la propria unicità mettendosi costantemente in gioco tramite laboratori, spettacoli e rassegne organizzati da noi. 
ESSERE O NON ESSERE
Dal 9 marzo 2013 le nostre attività sono a rischio! A seguito di un'ispezione del Comune di Torino, la parte seminterrata dei locali dell'Atelier é stata chiusa, in quanto non idonea alle normative di legge. Ciò ha comportato un impedimento del normale svolgimento delle attività, mettendo a rischio la sopravvivenza stessa dell'Atelier e in difficoltà tutti i giovani artisti che lo frequentano.
Per la ristrutturazione dell'Atelier abbiamo bisogno di circa 45.000-50.000 euro, cifra assolutamente fuori portata per la nostra associazione. È per questo che ci rivolgiamo ad ognuno di voi, agli appassionati sostenitori delle arti performative, spettatori, amici teatranti, e artisti, a chi crede nell’arte come parte indispensabile dell’esperienza umana: non lasciate che l'Atelier Teatro Fisico Philip Radice chiuda.
L' Atelier Teatro Fisico Philip Radice è uno spazio in cui ogni giovane può trovare la propria identità, grazie all’incontro con persone capaci di guidarlo verso una crescita artistica e personale. Un luogo dove ogni individuo, nell'incontro e nella scoperta della diversità dell'altro, trova il proprio originale talento ed una personale "idea di teatro". Un luogo libero, stimolante, creativo, ma anche economicamente accessibile a tutti.
AZIONE – Entrate in scena
La vostra donazione* ci aiuterà per rimettere a norma la parte seminterrata della scuola, adeguando gli impianti di areazione, il sistema elettrico e il riscaldamento. E’ prevista anche la ristrutturazione di una sala al piano superiore, dove verrà allestito un piccolo teatro nel quale poter organizzare i nostri Performing Party, serate di cabaret in cui i giovani dell'Atelier si misurano col pubblico presentando i loro numeri. Inoltre, sarà così possibile realizzare la sesta edizione della rassegna di teatro comico POTPOURRI, momentaneamente sospesa. Tale rassegna è rivolta ad artisti professionisti emergenti e vanta tra le sue collaborazioni artisti quali: Rita Pelusio, Antonio Rezza,Flavia Mastrella, Eugenio Allegri, Arturo Brachetti, Johnny Melville, le Sorelle Suburbe, Claudia Penoni e molti altri.
*La donazione può essere detratta dall’irpef, chiedeteci la ricevuta.
Per info: segreteria@teatrofisico.com | +39 3481026073
***************************************
ENGLISH
ATELIER TEATRO FISICO PHILP RADICE 
In 1995, Philip Radice founded the no-profit cultural center, ATELIER TEATRO FISICO to promote the concept of physical theatre and develop in Italy an innovative and unique educational program for the performance arts. Today the Atelier Teatro Fisico is a center of creativity and education where young artist can encounter qualified teachers and professionals for reciprocal stimulating exchanges. Overtime we have become well known in the region Piedmont, in Italy and abroad alongside other artistic realities like circus schools, which have contributed to the rebirth of Turin as an important cultural and artistic center. 
TO BE OR NOT TO BE
After almost 20 years of continuous activity, following controls by the city of Turin, the semi-underground spaces of the building used for teaching and rehearsals, were closed down because they did not meet the new building codes. Consequently, an ordinance was issued immediately blocking their use, which effectively halted normal activity, putting at risk the survival of the ATELIER, and making it difficult to continue the studies of the young artists who are enrolled.
The cost of renovating and adapting the spaces to the norms which would permit us to reopen the space and, thus, to continue our normal activities, would amount close to €45.000-€50.000 ($59,000-65,000,00 dollars). An expense unsustainable for our limited resources! 
ACTION – Enter on Stage
We are turning to you, the passionate supporters of the performing arts, theatre goers, theatre lovers, actors, actresses, street performers, circus performers, technicians, and all who believe in the arts as an indispensible human experience, to support us with a personal donation, and help us realize the renovation necessary to meet the building codes and give new life to our performance activities!
Your donation will pay for the renovation of the underground spaces, provide a state of the art air maintenance system required by city code, update electrical and heating systems, and guarantee that fire and safety codes are met. In addition, a room at the ground level can be converted into a small theatre space fit for performances to the public giving our students the possibility to play more often before an audience. It will be able to host our small theatre festival, POTPOURRI, dedicated to emerging artist and their original work.
Please give us a hand to reopen the ATELIER TEATRO FISICO and begin anew our artistic activities. In this way, you will give young persons the opportunity to continue their art education and development, and offer support in fostering an artistic community. 
For further informations: segreteria@teatrofisico.com | +39 3481026073
PERKS
€ 1 WANNA HELP BUT…
For anyone that sympathizes, but really doesn’t have the means to help, and might find themselves in a similar situation as ours! One euro and we’ll work to keep you laughing!
 
€ 5 TEXT ON THE STAGE…For anyone that has ever seen theatre and knows the ups and the downs. Receive a melodramatic text message of thanks from the director Philip Radice.
 
€ 10 SEE YOUR NAME ON THE CREDITS…Donate €10 or more and see your name on the websites donor page!
 
€ 30 YOUR NAME DISPLAY ON OUR WEBSITE WALLDonate € 30 or more and your name will be displayed on our contributors wall on the website:www.sos-atelierphilipradice.com!
 
€ 50 IMMORTALIZED: NAME ON THE DONOR’S WALLDonate €50 all of the above plus your name be engraved permanently on the wall dedicated to donors in the Small Theatre!
 
€ 100 AUTHOR’S PEROGATIVEContributing €100 plus you’ll receive all of the above, and we will add your name permanently with a short quote of your choice from a play displayed on a “real” wall in the school.
 
€ 250 THE DIRECTORS SEATDonate 250,00 all of the above and we’ll add a chair in the theatre with your name on a plaque, dedicated to you.
 
€ 1000 LEADING ROLEDonate €1000,00 or more, all of the above plus the students will create a comedy sketch with the roles played with the donors’ name send in a personalized video.
 
€ 10.000 PERFORMING ARTS OSCARAwesome! If this happens, our spaces now named after famous comedians will display your name on a special plaque, and will be named after you if you so wish! (Or named after your favorite actor/comedian). Largest contributor after €10.000 will have the theatre named after them. What more could you ask!!!
 
Exchange rate: 1 euro = $1.30 approxexample: €10.00 euros => $13.00 dollars

story:
A cultural enrichment program exposing Middle Eastern dancers and audiences to the culture from which it ermerged in its finest setting To create a communityeffort of presentation.

Middle Eastern dance is very wide and diverse. There is a wonderful array of talent but also a great lack of education. After living in San Diego for 15 years I realize that what is lacking is a strong feeling of community. Most dancers and dance studios work by themselves. I have looked at other areas of the dance world wide to see how they pull their communities together. Through this research I realize that what is missing is base education in this field. We do have good people, with great talent in the area who are willing to share their knowledge. There is a vast wealth of knowledge just waiting to be tapped into.

For one time each year I will conduct a concert to be held in a theater setting. This will include three (3) or four (4) of the finest performing groups in the area. The first concert to be held August 12th 2012.The money raised by this campaign and this concert will fund future concerts in other areas around the country and south of the border. The funds will be used to pay rent, backdrops, insurance, programs and printing plus any fees related to putting on and running a production. Money after expenses will be allotted to the performers and towards the next concert in 2013. All the bills relating to this venue are the responsibility of the organizers. 

The concert will be organized by Morwenna & Walid Assaf as coordinators. We will be responsible for finding the theater location, hiring the teachers, providing sound, an emcee and also providing a theme of the show. Each facility will be responsible for its own choreography, costuming, staging and story line etc. The only requirement is that works be culturally based. Fusion is fine as long as it relates to the dance form and keeps the essence of Oriental dance and /or folklore. American Tribal of any kind is not appropriate. Each group will get 20-30 minutes to present their material. This depends on the amount of groups involved. A video of the show will be made available to the public and to the performers.

The price to the general public shall be reasonable. The tickets shall be shared equally between all participants. This venue will also help to keep the dance form culturally correct yet up to date. People tend to forget that this dance form is the accepted dance movement style for over one third (1/3) of the world. Help us raise the level of the dance and expose audiences starting in the southwest corner of the USA. Any amount that you give is warmly appreciated and will have a great impact on the future of this beautiful dance form. Thank you for your time and we look forward to meeting you in the future.

story:
My name is Taryn Jansen and I will be graduating from Cornish College of the Arts with a BFA in Dance in May 2013.  As my chapter of college closes I have been offered an opportunity to transition and expand my skills and knowledge of dance. I have received an invitation to attend the Hubbard Street Dance Chicago summer intensive, which is a four-week program in Chicago. While I am there I will learn company repertoire, meet new people, network and have the opportunity to work with company members. In addition to this professional experience I will have the chance to gain connections with working professionals from around the world.  This all will help me start my own professional career. 

 

I would greatly appreciate any aid you can offer. It will make a great difference in my dreams to attend this amazing summer intensive.

 

My goal is to raise $4,000 for my housing, food expenses and my plane ticket.

$2,500: Housing + 1 meal a day

$1,000: Roundtrip plane ticket

$500: Food expensives (what is not covered in housing)

 

This intensive will give me the foundation to start my professional career right! It would mean so much to me to go to this intensive in a city that I've never been before. Hubbard Street Dance Chicago is an internationally recognized company and it is an honor to have been accepted into this program. Helping me fund this campaign will allow one college graduate the chance of employment with Hubbard Street Dance Chicago or other professionals in the area. With so many others in my generation out of work, I want to improve my chances of a job after graduation. If you can not contribute, please speard my word for me!

story:
Summary

After much success, Gimme One Riddim is currently producing its third remount in less than one year! From its world premiere at the Winchester Street Theatre, to an encore performance at Factory Theatre, the group is excited to bring this production back to the stage - accompanied by a live band! This year, Gimme One Riddim will be presented at the Enwave Theatre as part of Harbourfront Centre’s most popular dance series, NextSteps, but we need your help to share this special show with more audiences!

About the Production:

Photo Credit: Omer Yukseker

Created by choreographers Jasmyn Fyffe and Natasha Powell, Gimme One Riddim is a powerful tribute to the musical voice of Jamaica’s freedom - ska. Bringing Caribbean, contemporary and street dance influences to the stage, this captivating dance-theatre production honours the likes of Prince Buster, Millie Small, The Skatalites and The Wailers - celebrating freedom, hope, and unity. This show is family friendly, educational and highly entertaining, - a definite must see!

Bigger show, bigger venue, and much more.

Producing a show of this nature is a great undertaking. One we love where we have accomplished, but a larger show in a bigger venue requires more resources - we need your support. For our third theatre appearance, a five-piece band is accompanying us! Cast and crew are all coming back together for several weeks of rehearsals to incorporate our awesome musicians, enhance the ideas of the show, revamp the technical components, and costuming before we hit the stage at the Enwave Theatre. We have four performances from March 27 - 29 at 8pm. Friday March 28th includes a matinee performance at 1:30pm.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking contributions to go towards producing our upcoming performances at the Harbourfront. All proceeds go towards paying cast and crew salaries, venue costs, set design, advertising, and publicity expenses. Your contributions help us bring this show to those that love some good ol’ arts and entertainment, while contributing to Toronto’s cultural vibrancy! Contributions big and small are all greatly appreciated. For your generosity we have some fun and rewarding perks. The contribution levels and matching rewards are listed on the right side of this page.

The Impact

Photo Credit: Omer Yukseker. Cast: (From left) Irvin Washington, Liana Lewis, Esie Mensah, Roney Lewis, Jasmyn Fyffe, Hollywood Jade, Brandon Owusu, Shavar Blackwood, Trudy Lee Gayle, and Sharlan Cuffy. 

Gimme One Riddim is a production unlike any other in Toronto. Our audiences continue to be elated, having come across a show that accurately captures the time period of Jamaica's independence and the power that ska music had on a nation. For our youth, many have been introduced to a piece of history while also connecting to the entertainment value. Featuring five versatile male dancers has raised the bar of presenting positive role models. Purchase your tickets to see the show by click here.

For schools and community groups looking for an eventful experience at the theatre for their youth, group bookings to our matinee performance on Friday March 28 can be made by contacting Harbourfront’s box office at (416) 973-4000, press 1, or contact tickets@harbourfrontcentre.com.

Other Ways You Can Help

We always need help in spreading the word. LIKE our Facebook page (www.facebook.com/GimmeOneRiddim), follow us on Twitter (@GimmeOneRiddim), and share this Indiegogo campaign with your family and friends using the built-in share tools.

THANK YOU!!!

...

About the Creators

                                              L to R: Choreographers Natasha Powell and Jasmyn Fyffe

Honoring their Caribbean roots, Jasmyn Fyffe and Natasha Powell are the two powerhouse choreographers behind Gimme One Riddim. With over 20 years of experience as dancers, choreographers, and producers, with work that has taken them across Canada, these talented dance artists bring their extensive experience to this unique and entertaining production. 

Coined as “Alvin Ailey meets street dancer”, Fyffe’s work is created with a movement style that is an eclectic blend of her versatile training background while maintaining a strong contemporary foundation. Performing all over the world, this phenomenal mover has been seen in the hit-touring musical UMOJA, and alongside Grammy awarding-winning recording artist, Nelly Furtado. In 2012 she was nominated for the first ever Young Centre Dance Awards. She has been commissioned by Dance Ontario, Ballet Jorgen solo and duet program, and presented “Pulse”, one of the top shows in the 2013 Montreal Fringe Festival, for which she received Best Choreography Award. 

Recognized for her soulful yet hybrid movement style, Powell is one dynamic and creative individual. As a dancer she has appeared on the hit HBO television series The L Word, Nickelodeon’s original movie Spectacular!, and the dance film Center Stage 2. She too has been commissioned as a choreographer by Dance Ontario as part of their Commissions & Creative Partnerships Program, and was also co-choreographer of The 5th Fringe Festival. With sold-out shows, this production received Critic’s Pick from NOW Magazine as one of the top shows of the Festival, which led to it’s nomination as Best Dance Production in the Broadway World Toronto Awards.

story:
Bringing Dance to the River

Riverbank Dance Collective (RDC) is a dance organization that aims to strengthen the community at large by making the performing arts immediately accessible to all. Through a residency at Riverbank State Park in Harlem, RDC offers free and affordable performances to NYC school groups, senior citizens, and the general public.

RDC believes that dance, and all performing arts have the power to educate, inspire and empower people of all ages, and overall strengthen the community.

RDC is a new and budding arts organization in its first season of operation. For our opening season, RDC will present three performances that will bring dance to approximately 1,000 school-age children and senior citizens, as well as many more from the general public.

In order to make each performance this season a spectacular success, RDC needs your help! Your support will help launch RDC as an enduring presence in our immediate Harlem community, New York City, and beyond.


Launching Riverbank Dance Collective

Your support will enable RDC to accomplish the following:

  • Support our Dancers: We have 11 talented and hardworking artists in our company. The majority of our funding will  reimburse each dancer for travel and help defray the cost of living in NYC.
  • Create new Costumes: New work calls for new costumes! Help us outfit our creations!
  • Spread the word about RDC: A portion of our proceeds will go to marketing expenses such as flyers for our shows and free class series. We also hope to raise funds to purchase our domain name and launch an official RDC webpage.
  • Make magic behind the scenes: No great performance ever happened without behind the scenes support. This campaign will allow us to hire a videographer, purchase props, and pay for other technical support expenses for our productions.
  • Grow our Future: Riverbank Dance Collective is applying for non-profit status. A portion of this campaign will be applied to filing fees and other expenses associated with this process.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come support our shows! All of RDC's performances are affordable and open to the public. Performances will be held at Riverbank State Park's Cultural Complex II (145th Street and the River)

  • May 9th, 2013 10:30AM - Dances for Our Mothers: A Mother's Day Celebration. ($2 suggested donation)
  • May 18th, 2013 2PM- RDC performs as part of Riverbank State Park's 20th Anniversary celebration (FREE! Outdoors!)
  • June 5th, 2013 10:30AM- City Dance ($2 suggested donation)

Take Class with us! RDC currently teaches a FREE weekly contemporary dance class for teens and adults. This class is open to the public. Thursdays, 7:30pm-9:00pm through June 6th.

Help spread the word about Riverbank Dance Collective! Tell your friends, your family, or anyone who would like to see our shows, take our class, or learn what we are about.

Want to stay in the loop about RDC? Find us on Facebook and follow our page.

story:
Dear Community,

From 2005-2010 Movement for the Urban Village presented six consecutive seasons of original dance around New York City. Then I decided to take some time off to refocus and to develop Calling Names. I am so very excited to announce that on Saturday and Sunday, February 23 and 24, 2013 Calling Names will premier as part of SANKOFA, a program of new and classic work, Saturday and Sunday, February 23 and 24th, 2013 at Brooklyn’s brand new BAM Fisher, Fishman Space! It is an enormous honor to be able to be among the very first independently produced artists to show work at this brand new, beautiful, state of the art venue, it is also a very, very expensive.   We are this close to success and we need your help to make it to the finish line.

We need to raise $10,000 to cover final production and design costs in a union house as well as to be able to more fully compensate the performers for the time and commitment they have invested in the creation and development of this work. They have worked hard and long to bring my vision to the stage and their labors deserve to be compensated. If we don’t meet our goal we might lose this opportunity. We truly have a critical need for your support today.

Please help us save our SANKOFA season. The season is named SANKOFA to celebrate the Akan principle which invites us to move forward in full awareness and embrace of what has come before-- to look both ways. In addition to featuring Calling Names’ debut, we will also present a fully remounted production of Bearers, a classic MUV work. This opportunity to present work in one of the most esteemed houses for contemporary performance helps us to move both the work and our profile to a higher level with important funders, new audiences and the media.

All gifts are appreciated. Every contribution gets us closer to our goal. Even if you cannot give cash today, please help spread the word by sharing this link and telling at least 10 friends about MUV and SANKOFA. Finally, please come out and see the show, tickets will be on sale soon!

story:
The Story:

At the height of the Japanese occupation of Korea 13-year-old Heewon is sold into sexual slavery.  Five years and two occupiers later she escapes her brutal existence by marrying an American officer who whisks her away to a small, Midwestern suburb.  Desperate to create a new life and, more importantly, protect her daughter from her shameful past, she turns her back on the girl she once was.  But that girl will not be silenced, transforming instead into Ghost Girl who relentlessly terrorizes Heewon and, in turn, her daughter, Moran, driving them both to commit increasingly unreasonable, desperate acts. Will mother and daughter be able to exorcise the Ghost Girl from their lives or will she destroy them both?

 

The Genesis:

In April of 2000 a bright, funny, accomplished, overachieving MIT student took her own life by setting herself on fire.  What could possess anyone, let alone someone so seemingly happy and successful, to take their own life in such a brutal and horrific way?  It was this question that set playwright Sue Pak on the psychological, historical, and ultimately personal, journey that culminated in the writing of this powerful, provocative and magical new play: Ghost Girl. 

 

What we need and what you get:

We are fundraising primarily to help us fully realize our production design concept.  Ghost Girl spans twenty years and two continents and the visual elements are crucial to the storytelling.  We want our designers to have every resource at their disposal to take their incredible ideas to fruition.  Take a look at some of our design sketches to see what you will be funding.  No amount is too small to help! 

 

Vital Statistics:

Ghost Girl will be performed August 18-21 at the Workshop Theater.  Thurs-Sat at 8pm, Sat & Sun at 2pm

 

Tickets are FREE!  Reservations are STRONGLY recommended as we're selling out fast.  Please reserve tickets by contacting: GhostGirlPlay@gmail.com

 

Other ways you can help

Contribute! www.indiegogo.com/Ghost-Girl-Play

View other videos from our artists on our channel! www.youtube.com/GhostGirlPlay

Visit and like our page! www.facebook.com/GhostGirlPlay

Tweet and Follow Us! http://twitter.com/#!/GhostGirlPlay

 

More About Our Team:

Playwright Sue Pak and Director Cat Miller met while graduate students at Northwestern University.  They have been developing Ghost Girl for over a year and a half, beginning with a reading at Northwestern University and extending to long dramaturgical meetings over skype while Sue was in Qatar teaching screenwriting this past year.    They now bring it to the stage in NY with the help of producer Erin Gilmore, Set Designer Robert Shoquist, Costume Designer Miodrag Guberinic, Lighting Designer Emily McGillicuddy, Sound Designer Emma Wilk, Fight Choreographer Sean Chin, Stage Manager Matt Hundley

and our illustrious cast: Scarlett Bermingham, William Franke*, Jefferson Grubbs, Lisa Helmi Johansson, Whitney Kam Lee*, Katharine Lerner, Caitlin Mehner, Bonna Tek, and Nicholas Westemeyer.

 

*these actors are appearing courtesy of Actor's Equity Association

story:
Check out The Citizen Comic
Check out The Cowgirl Myth

From the Blog

Hi Everyone,
 
Our American Myth is coming! And as we hurtle towards our opening night, and the end of our IndieGoGo campaign, we have a ton of exciting news to kick off our opening week:
 

Our American Myth Livestreams Opening Night to the World:

Thanks to Arena Stage's New Play Institute, we will be able to stream our opening night shenanigans to all of you outside the Bay on#NewPlay TV. And you can talk to us and about the show on the twitter hashtag #OAM. Can't wait to see you there on Thursday at 8:00pm!
 

Meet Our Heroes (and get your own piece of Our American Myth!)

We've spoken of our the tale of a brave and conflicted politician, and the patriotic and idealistic young man who is ultimately driven to shoot her. And now you can meet our heroes. We present to you, The CITIZEN and The Cowgirl Myth, a comic and story-book story created just for our show. Check them out, and for the next three days while our IndieGoGo campaign is active, you can
 

DONATE AND GET YOUR COPY BEFORE WEDNESDAY:

The Show
What would you kill for?  At what point does violence become the best option?  Why do we have such a strong heritage of political violence in America?

Part drama, part debate, part poetry and entirely entertaining, Bindlepunks’ newest production examines these questions and more.

Join us as we weave a new American myth: the tale of a brave and conflicted politician and the patriotic and idealistic young man who is ultimately driven to shoot her.  Throughout this story of ambition and betrayal, the actors step out of the action to explore how our American culture, ideals, and politics create a breeding ground for acts of violence.

Power.  Violence.  Politics.  Free speech.  Guns.  Share your insights with us, as we share ours with you.

The Impact

Someone got shot, and we wanted to understand why. When Representative Gabrielle Giffords took a bullet to the head, we had some questions, like,“WHY?!” Through discussion we realized, “Hey, this thing is a little complicated”. So we started asking our friends, families, strangers at bars, and ‘The Interwebs’. They told us things, and we put those things into a play...

That was hard. And then we realized it’s even more complicated than we first thought. So we gave up. We did. We can’t answer it on our own. We can’t create the play without your perspective. We need to open up a dialogue with everyone we can get our hands on. With you. Because we realize... the conversation is the answer. Or at least the possibility for one. We want to talk about something that many of us are too afraid to even think about—the potential in a human being to commit a heinous act of violence.

We did our homework. We did a TON of homework. And the one thing we learned is that we don’t know enough. We can only speak for--How many of us are there? Seven?--seven people living in America. If we don’t talk about it beyond the tragic, bite-sized headlines, we believe we’ll just be setting ourselves up for another tragic shock a few years down the line.

So come to the show and talk with us.


What We Need

We need:
$1000 to pay all of the wonderful artists involved in the production
$1000 for props, costumes, and sound/lighting equipment
$1500 to pay for the rehearsal space
$500 for printing postcards, fliers and programs

Our artists, on average, are putting in about 100 hours to this project. We’ve promised them a minimum stipend of $100, but we would like to pay them an amount closer to what their time is actually worth. Any extra funds received will go towards paying the artists a respectable sum, and the further development of this project.


Other Ways You Can Help

Talk to us!
We’d love to hear your thoughts on the subjects of power, violence, political violence, free speech, and what America means to you. Send your thoughts to bindlepunks@gmail.com, facebook us, or post a comment on the Bindlepunks blog. Your words might end up in the show!

Talk about us!
If you can’t donate, you can help by sharing this page and the project with everyone you know.

If you’re in San Jose, visit the Works/San Jose and Satori Tea Company and let them know how much you love their support of the project.

Keep checking this page and our blog for updates on the project: writing, rehearsals, and performances.

Performances:
Thu, Oct 27th at 8pm @ Works/San Jose (LIVESTREAM)
Fri, Oct 28th at 8pm @ Works/San Jose
Sat, Oct 29th at 8pm @ Works/San Jose
Sun, Oct 30th at 4pm @ Works/San Jose
Thu, Nov 3rd at 8pm @ Satori Tea Company
Sat, Nov 5th at 8pm @ Works/San Jose
Sun, Nov 6th at 4pm @ Works/San Jose

Tickets:
$10-20 sliding scale at the door.
To reserve a spot, email bindlepunks@gmail.com or call (650) 458-PUNK

What Are Bindlepunks, Anyway?

Bindle punks:(noun) 1. Hobos or derelicts hired to do rough or unpleasant work. 2. Chronic wanderers; itinerant misfits, criminals, and lumber jacks.
Bindlepunks: (noun) 1. A company of chronic wanderers and itinerant misfits dedicated to the rough work of revitalizing the public attitude towards theatre.

Bindlepunks is dedicated to new and contemporary works and experimental theatre focused on social issues, and revitalizing both the public attitude towards theatre and the theatrical community’s attitude towards the public. We reject the concept of theatre as a ‘high art’, embracing irreverence and refusing to take anything seriously other than the quality of our work.
