story:
Help Story Theater Company’s Teen Actors Present “David and Lisa”

Story Theater Company is a not-for-profit children’s theater company that has been providing theatrical education and performance opportunities for the children and youth of central Iowa since 2006.  We are raising funds to stage the full-length play “David and Lisa”, which will represent a first for Story Theater Company:  a play designed, produced, and performed by our teens.  The inspiration to stage this play came from the youth themselves as a natural extension of Story Theater Company’s Teen Theater Club.  The club met with immediate success after its formation in 2012, and Story Theater Company recognized the demand for even more teen theater programming. 

The show selected is “David and Lisa”, James Reach’s powerful drama about two troubled teens who meet up and make a connection at a school for delinquent adolescents.  The script has a large ensemble of fascinating and compelling characters and provides the teens with the chance to tackle some challenging subject matter.  Auditions will be held in mid-December, and three performances of “David and Lisa” will be staged February 28-March 2.  

What We Need

Our goal is to raise $1400 to complete the funding for this teen theater production.  “David and Lisa” has the full support of Story Theater Company.  The teens will have access to Story Theater Company’s scene shop, costumes, and supplies.  Story Theater Company has also hired two excellent instructors/directors for the show and is providing much of the funding.  But theater is expensive, and a programming expansion of this magnitude just isn’t in Story Theater Company’s annual budget.  So we need your help.

Here’s where the money will go:


We are producing this show on a shoestring budget: less than 50% of one of our mainstage shows.  So we will be making sure that every dollar counts.

Four Reasons to Donate

  • By donating to our campaign you are not simply paying for costumes or renting a rehearsal room- you are supporting a team of dedicated youth who are ready to move their theatrical education to the next level.
  • Your support will provide the teens with the experience to work as an ensemble to create the entire production from the ground up.  The youth will be led through a company/ensemble approach to not only the acting of the piece but also the creation of every aspect of the production.
  • You will help create a performance experience specifically suited to a teen audience.  The subject matter, performance style, and story of “David and Lisa” are geared specifically to reach that seriously underserved demographic.  We hope to not only get more teens excited about the creative possibilities of live performance, but also touch their hearts and minds with stories and subject matter to which they can uniquely relate.
  • Story Theater Company is a not-for-profit 501(c)3 organization, so your donation is tax-deductible (Consult your tax advisor).  Plus, you’ll get some fun perks. (check them out!)

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everybody can donate money but that doesn’t mean you can’t help! We would absolutely love if you could get the word out there! Share our link and talk up our production on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, at work, at school or anywhere else you can!  And come to the show!

Thank you for checking us out.  We hope to see you at the show!

story:
Thief, a new piece of theatre exploring the transience of beauty, will premiere at the Brighton Fringe in May, before transferring to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

Thief is written and directed by Liam Rudden, whose previous Fringe successes include the sell out Silence In Court (Edinburgh Fringe 20011 & 2013), the award winning Cock And Bull Story (Edinburgh Fringe 2011) and Killers (5 stars Brighton Argus) at last year's Brighton Fringe.

The aim is to produce a piece of immersive theatre which allows the audience a more personal experience, without a fourth wall breaking the barrier between them and performer .

Because of the intimate nature of Thief, playing to audiences of between 30 and 60 a night, additional funding to pay actor and technician is invaluable - we are not publicly funded. 

The funding we require would go to pay an actor for three weeks rehearsal and one performance week at Equity rates, a technician for two weeks, as well as travel and accommodation for the duration of the Brighton Fringe run.

All funds will go to ensure that this production is one of the most exciting new pieces of theatre of 2014.


"Sailor is a man struggling to maintain his last ounce of humanity and self-respect, while doing what it takes to survive the brutal underworld of civilised society. His ethos of subverting accepted moral  behaviour and self-expression is drawn loosely from the works and life of Jean Genet." - Liam Rudden


Other ways to Spread the word LIKE www Facebook.com/ThiefThePlay 

VISIT www.playthief.com and 

FOLLOW @playthief on Twitter

story:
Get your tickets here:
http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/twibtix/x/3204443


What do you call emerging young artists? Broke.

Yup, that's who we are! 
We are filled with great enthusiasm and a wild treasure chest of creativity but with no $£¥€¢฿ to let our ideas come to life.

We are greatly passionate about this project because we will be pushing the boundaries of a theatrical horror experience by transforming an entire building into the world of the play. The Woman In Black will tickle, scare, blind and move you (in every sense of the word), but we need help bringing this to you.

By funding our indiegogo campaign, you will be playing a part in developing a new relationship between the theatre and its audience, and creating a piece of theatre that is rarely experienced around the world, let alone in Singapore.

What We Need

This indiegogo campaign is specifically set up so that we can afford the licenses required to stage the performance.
Every dollar from this campaign will go to paying the publishers of the play and any miscellaneous taxes, conversions and bank transaction fees.

What You Gain

We are inexpressibly grateful to your contribution of any amount.
Apart from staging the best production we are capable of, this is what you will get in return for your faith and support in our project!

(refer to the right)

$1- Listed Contributor
$5- Thank You Video
$10- Free Ticket!
$25- Creative Consultant
$50- 3 Free Tickets!
$100- 3 Limited Season Passes!
$200- Exclusive Scrapbook

7, 8 & 9 February
Sculpture Square Chapel Gallery

Please help make this production a success by spreading the word!
You can do it by:

  • Following our blog twib2014.tumblr.com
  • Telling everyone you know about this production!
  • Adding #twibsg2014 to your posts (if we see it, we will respond!)
  • Follow our Instagram @twibsg2014
  • Join our public event on Facebook!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Email v.ictoria.c@hotmail.com if you would like to make a donation in-kind, or for more information!

Stay tuned to this page for more details too!

With lots of love,
The Woman In Black team
story_txt:
Get your tickets here:http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/twibtix/x/3204443
What do you call emerging young artists? Broke.Yup, that's who we are! We are filled with great enthusiasm and a wild treasure chest of creativity but with no $£¥€¢฿ to let our ideas come to life.We are greatly passionate about this project because we will be pushing the boundaries of a theatrical horror experience by transforming an entire building into the world of the play. The Woman In Black will tickle, scare, blind and move you (in every sense of the word), but we need help bringing this to you.By funding our indiegogo campaign, you will be playing a part in developing a new relationship between the theatre and its audience, and creating a piece of theatre that is rarely experienced around the world, let alone in Singapore.What We NeedThis indiegogo campaign is specifically set up so that we can afford the licenses required to stage the performance.Every dollar from this campaign will go to paying the publishers of the play and any miscellaneous taxes, conversions and bank transaction fees.What You GainWe are inexpressibly grateful to your contribution of any amount.Apart from staging the best production we are capable of, this is what you will get in return for your faith and support in our project!(refer to the right)$1- Listed Contributor$5- Thank You Video$10- Free Ticket!$25- Creative Consultant$50- 3 Free Tickets!$100- 3 Limited Season Passes!$200- Exclusive Scrapbook7, 8 & 9 FebruarySculpture Square Chapel Gallery
Please help make this production a success by spreading the word!You can do it by:
Following our blog twib2014.tumblr.com

Telling everyone you know about this production!
Adding #twibsg2014 to your posts (if we see it, we will respond!)
Follow our Instagram @twibsg2014

Join our public event on Facebook!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Email v.ictoria.c@hotmail.com if you would like to make a donation in-kind, or for more information!
Stay tuned to this page for more details too!With lots of love,The Woman In Black team

story:
Vicious Circles, winner of the MainLine Theatre Next Stage award for “Best Local English Production” at the 2012 Montreal Fringe festival, and remounted to rave reviews as a MainLine Theatre co-production in 2013, is now embarking on its VICIOUSTRALIA tour of West Australia in 2014!!!

Originally produced by Montreal theatre company Stadium Tour, the VICIOUSTRALIA tour will be co-produced with Australian production company Weeping Spoon Productions, run by Shane Adamczak.

The tour will begin in Perth, at Blue Room Theatre's PICA Performance Space, as part of the Fringe World festival, on February 10th to 15th 2014.This will be followed by a run of several weeks in February-March 2014 at Tuxedo Cat as part of the Adelaide Fringe.  

With bookings completed and lodging arrangements already taken care of, we now need to raise money to send the the cast and crew to Oz! Plane tickets range from $2000 to $2500 each, which will cost a total of between $8000 and $10000 - and that's not counting the cost of FEEDING them once they get there, and the various props and settings that we need to purchase for the show...

Being an underfunded, non-profit organization, and with no thanks to the Harper government's elimination of nearly every available grant for the arts, Stadium Tour simply cannot afford the cost of these plane tickets.

That's where you come in, dear patrons of the arts. The actors and director are trying to save up as much as they can to help pay their way - but with fairly low wages and non-salaried work, it is not enough.

The money raised on Indiegogo will go to reduce the cost of each ticket - if we make our minimum, it will cut the costs roughly in half, and if we can double our minimum then we can send everyone there, and any extra above that will go towards food for the actors and materials for the show.

Check out our awesome perks and give what you can! Donators can choose from a wide array of packages, some of which include souvenir posters, soundtracks, t-shirts, and even reproductions of the Johnny, Sid, and Nancy sock puppets that are used in the show!!         

 

Vicious Circles - a Weeping Spoon/Stadium Tour co-production

sex. drugs. punk. rock. music.
tuinal. heroin. alcohol. vitriol.
hatred. disgust. self-loathing.
anger. violence. murder.
sid. nancy. johnny. malcolm.
vicious. circles. 

Winner of the 2012 Montreal Fringe Festival’s Next Stage Award for "Best Local English Production".
Nominated for the 2012 Chapters Award for "Best English Text".
Nominated for the 2012 Théâtre Denise-Pelletier's Fred Barry Award for "Best Production Design".

Vicious Circles is a meta-euphoric and surrealist-psychedelic tale about Sex Pistols bassist and punk rock icon, Sid Vicious, and the tug of war for his life between his bandmate and close friend, Johnny Rotten; his manager, Malcolm McLaren; and his girlfriend, 'Nauseating' Nancy Spungen, at New York's Chelsea Hotel. 

“The fix you need” – Cult MTL

“The cast is incredible” – Bloody Underrated

“Sheer genius” – Montreal Gazette

Written by Ben Kalman
Directed by Stéfan Cédilot 

Starring: Patrick Rogers as Sid Vicious, Kathleen Aubert as Nancy Spungen, Shane Adamczak as Johnny Rotten, and Charles Mayer as Malcolm McLaren 

Weeping Spoon Productions is an international multi-award winning independent theatre company based in Perth, Western Australia. Co-founded by a group of professionally trained actors, Weeping Spoon Productions has become one of the most prolific theatre companies in Perth. They have produced several award-winning touring productions including GREED, Love Songs For Future Girl, A Complete History Of Zack Adams, Pollyanna and The Adventures Of Alvin Sputnik.

“Weeping Spoon is an innovative young company that constantly challenges theatrical styles” -Post Newspapers

“Weeping Spoon Productions put on a fantastic show…it is not only intriguing, captivating and exciting but funny and thought-provoking... simply spectacular.” - Xpress Magazine

Montreal’s Stadium Tour produces theatrical performances inspired by rock music. Their first such production, Zeppelin Was a Cover Band!, was originally produced in French in November 2006 at MainLine Theatre, and remounted for the 2007 Montreal Fringe Festival. The English version became one of the hit shows of the Montreal Fringe in 2008, and was also performed at Centaur Theatre’s Wildside Festival in 2009. The company’s bilingual show Autobiomusicograph(y)ie was nominated for the Cirque du Soleil Award for “Best Original Production” at the Montreal Fringe in 2010. Their next production, All I Want is U2, was first co-produced by MainLine Theatre in 2011 before becoming a surprise hit at Zoofest in 2013. Their latest production, Vicious Circles, was nominated for three awards at the 2012 Montreal Fringe, winning the MainLine Theatre Next Stage Award, and was remounted to rave reviews as a MainLine Theatre co-production in May 2013.

Like STADIUM TOUR on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Theatre-Sans-Fond-Stadium-Tour/7635849073

story:
Who I Am… 

Hi! My name is Adam and I am an Artist. 

I grew up in many cities in the southwest, but spent most of my time here, in the Valley of the Sun, otherwise known as, Phoenix, Arizona. I was always a quiet, kept-to-myself kind of kid. While everyone else enjoyed recesses, I dreaded it. I would do anything to stay in the classroom during such activities. I would aid the teacher with cleaning and handouts, I would color and draw, anything to stay inside where there was the protection of an adult. It wasn't until I moved to Phoenix that I realized that I could reinvent myself, even at a young age. 

By this time I was 10 and decided that I was going to join band. From band I found choir and for many years I did both until I was a freshman in high school. I followed choir all four year and added one more art form my senior year of high school - dance. I joined dance because I was so very into musical theater and I was simply, a bad dancer and needed help.


Since then I have been training in Dance and on halfway done earning a Bachelor’s of Arts in Dance Education at Grand Canyon University. Dance has been an escape, a tool, an experience of humanity, liberating, powerful, and joyous. I don’t know what I would be like without all of these experiences.


Our program is small, but we are growing in numbers and talent every semester!

This campaign is to help me pay my way to Brooklyn, New York. After auditioning in the fall of 2013, I and six others were chosen to learn, collaborate, & perform with Leanne Schmidt & Company (a New York based modern dance company) for an entire week in March of 2014! And as we all know, New York’s cost of living is pretty much, twice as much as Arizona’s. As a student and student-worker making $8 per hour and less than 15 hours a week, there is no way I would be able to afford to go on this once-in-a-lifetime journey completely on my own. I might never be able to get back to New York’s Dance Scenes and this is an opportunity I do not want to let go because of money. I cannot do this on my own, which is why I am reaching out.

The magnitude of what you will be doing for me is more than you will ever truly understand. You are giving me an opportunity to see what people only see in the movies and on the bright, sliver screens of the theaters. You are giving me a chance to experience, learn, and appreciate what many won’t. You will be giving a boy, who never thought could dance or have a chance in New York, hope.


What We Need & What You Get

So here are the logistics. To get to New York I am trying to raise $2000. This will cover all my expenses including: 3 meals a day, transportation for a week, room & board, dance classes, shows, fees for using PayPal & Indiegogo, and anything extra would be used as an ‘in-case of an emergency’ type deal.

What is really cool about Indiegogo (the website I am powering my campaign) is that I can offer perks! Different perks based on levels! Check them out on the side if it’s something that interests you!

You might be wondering “what happens if he doesn’t make his goal?” Well, regardless of how much I actually raise everything is a considerable help and gets me closer to getting to New York. Even if you can only donate $1 of your hard-earned money, that in itself is help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. If you can’t donate, don’t worry about it! But please, if you can, try one of these:

  • Make some noise about my campaign; post it to your social media! Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google+, ANYTHING and EVERYTHING
  • Remember, you can use the Indiegogo share tools too!

If you’ve read this far, thank you. I truly appreciate your time and help. Thank You. :]


Darryl Webb/GCU

story:
This is Amber's world, and we are all just living in it!

Now Amber would like to get to Newburgh, to perform at the Railroad Playhouse, but she needs your help!!!!  Please donate to the cause, and help Amber be in the spotlight as she always knew she should be.

Can a reality show save a dying town? 

In AMERICA’S BRIGHTEST STAR, the small town of South Farmingham is turned upside down when Sherry, a middle-aged, introverted librarian, uploads a video of herself singing onto the website of the hit TV reality show “America’s Brightest Star.”  Her video unexpectedly receives millions of views, which prompts an invitation to perform on the show.  Awkwardly shy, she resists, but is prodded along by her celebrity-craving assistant Amber, the ambitious mayor Dolores Danton, and Cecil Ravinsdale, the cock-sure host of “America's Brightest Star.” 

Addressing issues of humanity's differing relationships with fame, fortune and social media, this dark comedy tackles fleeting fame, dying towns, and raw talent. 

THE RAILROAD PLAYHOUSE (RRP) is presenting the world premiere production of RRP Playwright-in-Residence , Alex Goldberg’s AMERICA’S BRIGHTEST STAR, directed by RRP Artistic Director, Seth Soloway. AMERICA’S BRIGHTEST STAR will play a limited engagement at the Railroad Playhouse (27 South Water Street, Newburgh, NY). Performances begin Friday, October 19 and continue through Saturday, November 3.

The production stars Megan Tusing (Wolves [Firework/59E59]; TV: “Law and Order”) as Amber, Charleigh E. Parker* (Cinderella [Asian Tour]; TV: “Boardwalk Empire”) as Sherry, Jeffrey C. Wolf* (Regional: Cabaret [Kevin Kline nomination-Ernst, Stages St. Louis]; TV/Film: “Boardwalk Empire”) as Cecil Ravinsdale, Catia Ojeda* (101 Dalmatians [Nat’l Tour]; TV: “30 Rock”) as Mayor Danton, Kevin Loreque* (CATS [Nat’l Tour]; Film: “The Birdcage”) as Dale, Kathryn Kates* (The Bakery Lady in “Seinfeld”) as Merla, and Edward Crawford (RRP: Lying Naked; PBS: “Promised Land”) as Gary/Dave/Network Executive. *Member of Actors' Equity Association, the Union of Professional Actors and Stage Managers in the United States.

The production features scenic design by Bill Bywater (20 years with Just Off Broadway, Inc), costume design by Bobby Pearce (Taboo, nominated for both the Tony Award and the Outer Critics Circle Award for Best Costume Design), lighting design by Emily Bean (RRP Inaugural One Act Play Festival), projection design by Grant McDonald (Sleep No More), and the production stage manager is Heather Arnson*.

AMERICA’S BRIGHTEST STAR is Thursdays at 7:30pm, Friday at 7:30pm and Saturday at 2pm and 8pm through Saturday November 3.

Tickets are $25 general admission, $20 Students/Seniors; and are now available online at www.rrplayhouse.org or by calling 845-565-3791.

Running Time: 95 minutes plus intermission

Website: rrplayhouse.org

THE RAILROAD PLAYHOUSE is dedicated to the revitalization of Newburgh and the preservation of Newburgh’s historic West Shore Railroad Station by providing a space for high-quality, artistically creative performing arts experiences.

The Railroad Playhouse provides a home for playwrights to workshop and showcase new plays; presents local, national, and international artists of all genres; creates partnerships with local businesses and organizations to continue revitalizing the area; has implemented after school programming and a summer arts camp for local children; and created teaching-artists residences in local schools.

Website: http://www.rrplayhouse.org

story:
Performance Network Theatre (a.k.a. 'The Network') has been in existence for almost 30 years.  From its beginnings as a free community theatre, the Network has faced a number of challenges.  We've been forced to relocate a number of times. We have undergone several identity changes.  We've even had a load-bearing pole placed inconveniently in the center of the performance space for many years.  For the most part, we've been poor, and very recently we've been forced to shut down temporarily due to financial mismanagement.

What stands out is the legacy of survival that has kept the Network alive, and has brought us to this point: How do we keep the Network going for the next 30 years?

The ‘New’ Network took over operations on June 18th, 2014 and re-opened the doors on August 4th. Currently we survive on 25% of normal revenue, as explained in our appeal video. Thanks to generous donations by supporters and a refined business plan that has enabled fewer staff to run the theatre, we're making it. But only just.

We've already produced three shows to critical acclaim, and we have a vision to turn the theatre into the hub of a movement to protect all art in Ann Arbor. Art has kept the Network alive, and so the Network will do all it can to keep art alive. With that mantra in mind a relaunch of the Network is envisaged for Spring 2015 when the new theatre space, which is currently being redesigned to reflect the "space of possibilities" mission, will be unveiled.

We 're asking for $30,000 because that's our non-production "nut". That's what it costs so we can do what we do every month. With $30,000 in the bank, our nut is covered and we can get on with producing drama that will not only ensure Ann Arbor's only professional producing theatre stays open for another 30 years, but will empower us to write the next chapter in the Network's story - a space of possibilities for art to flourish. Most importantly, of course, we have cool perks, like this Most Loyal Order of Nut Coverers' (MLONC) T-shirt:

There a bunch of cool perks for investing in our cause, whichever you choose, please accept our thanks in advance for joining us in the fight to keep art alive in Ann Arbor.


THE TEAM AT THE NETWORK

story:
We have hit our goal!!!

Amazing.  With time to spare.  We are so grateful to everyone who has donated.  Since there is still time left remaining on the campaign, we'd like to ask for your help one more time, to help us exceed this goal.  Everything above and beyond the money raised to date will go towards either a remount post-Fringe, or changing the medium of the show, perhaps to a short film.  Thank you so very, very much, and see you at the Fringe!

 

*****OUR SHOW HAS BEEN RE-NAMED THROUGH DEVELOPMENT. NEW POSTER TO COME!!*****

 

Our Play

Bitch. A catartic purge, based on a true story.

As two best friends clean up the mess of the night before, they recover from their alcoholic and romantic hangovers. A drunken glimpse into the journeys of friendships and loves, and the hilarious bumps along the way.

Director: Ted Hallett
Cast: Erin Thompson, Tracey Beltrano
Running Time: 45min.
Genres: Play, Comedy
Warnings: Sexual Content, Mature Language

 

Who We Are

We met at Second City while taking classes. Through a series of improv exercises and drunken nights, we realized we shared a past history worth writing about.

 

Bios

TRACEY BELTRANO

Tracey is a graduate of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts in NYC and has honed her comedic craft at The Second City Toronto where she met and befriended her writing partner, Erin Thompson. Her resume is an eclectic mix from the bizarre to the dramatic. Favorite past credits include: Grusha in "The Caucasian Chalk Circle" (AADA Company, NYC), Susan in "Say No More" (Inspirato Festival), Dot Matrix in "The Office Spaceballs" (Queen's Players Toronto) and Step Mother in the national tour of "Cinderella" (Touring Players of Canada). Tracey idolizes strong, female comedic performers such as Andrea Martin, Gilda Radner, Carol Burnett and Lucille Ball.  Catch Tracey, as a series regular, in the new television series "SomeTV!" to begin airing in the fall.  "Bitch. A cathartic purge based on a true story." marks Tracey's first writing endeavour.

ERIN THOMPSON

Erin is a graduate of the Randolph Academy for Performing Arts in Toronto and has recently returned to performing after living it up in the world of corporate marketing. While studying improv at Second City in Toronto, she connected with Tracey, her now friend and collaborator.  Favorite past credits include: Lady Macbeth in "Macbeth" (Shakespeare in the Square, Brampton), Shelby Stevens  in "Steel Pier" (RAPA), Naomi in "Naomi In The Living Room" (RAPA) and Dawn Schweitzer in "Mean Girls" (Paramount Pictures). Erin is inspired by quirky, multifaceted female performers such as Toni Collette, Catherine O’Hara, Megan Mullally, and Tina Fey.  "Bitch. A cathartic purge based on a true story." marks Erin's first writing endeavour.

TED HALLETT (Director)

Ted’s favorite credits include: The Breakout Kings (A&E); Train 48 (Can West Global);The Buddy Holly Story (Sudbury Theatre Center); The Playground (Chicago,Il); The Love Guru (Paramount Pictures); The Red Queen Effect (Seventh Stage Productions *Dora nominated* not me...the show) and The Second City National Tour Co, Toronto. Ted is one of the resident acting instructors at the Impatients Theatre Company and can be seen performing improvised theatre every week. This man does not wear a shirt at the dinner table, bakes his own bread and ate a whole roast beef one time. He enjoys thinking about stuff, showing his paintings in coffee houses and sitting outside.

MARY CLAIRE (MC) THOMPSON (Dramaturge)

MC has been active in the TO theatre scene for about two decades. She has performed with Alumnae Theatre, Cabbagetown Theatre, Amicus, Toronto Fringe, InspiraTO Festival and others. MC has also written and directed a number of short plays and co-hosts "Stage Left", a web radio show on Radio Regent. MC is currently involved as dramaturge on "Perfect Timing" and "Tug of War", and as director on "Fetish" - all three short plays are a part of the 2013 InspiraTO Festival (May 31-June 8, 2013 at Alumnae Theatre). See you in the Fringe Beer Tent!

 

St.Vlad's Theatre
620 Spadina Ave (just south of Harbord St.)

Thursday, July 4, 2013 10:00pm  
Sunday, July 7, 2013 11:00pm
Monday, July 8, 2013  4:45pm
Wednesday, July 10, 2013 11:15pm  
Thursday, July 11, 2013 12:00pm
Friday, July 12, 2013 8:00pm
Sunday, July 14, 2013 2:45pm

 

What We Need & What You Get

As you can imagine, producing a show in Toronto can be quite costly. Any funds raised here will be going to the following:

rehearsal spaces, props, costumes, set pieces, rental trucks, initiation fees, printing costs, posters, postcards, ads, etc.

The Impact

With your help, you will be making it possible for us to produce our very first play. You will help it get seen and be properly mounted. You will have afforded us the ability to develop our play with a dramaturge and work with the best team of creative minds there are. For this, we are truly grateful. Your support is so greatly appreciated. 

Other Ways You Can Help

COME SEE THE SHOW!!!

SHARE THE CAMPAIGN!!!! 

SUPPORT THE FRINGE FESTIVAL - IT'S A GREAT PLATFORM FOR NEW AND ESTABLISHED ARTISTS TO SHOWCASE THEIR NEW AND/OR DEVELOPING WORK.
story_txt:
We have hit our goal!!!
Amazing.  With time to spare.  We are so grateful to everyone who has donated.  Since there is still time left remaining on the campaign, we'd like to ask for your help one more time, to help us exceed this goal.  Everything above and beyond the money raised to date will go towards either a remount post-Fringe, or changing the medium of the show, perhaps to a short film.  Thank you so very, very much, and see you at the Fringe!
 
*****OUR SHOW HAS BEEN RE-NAMED THROUGH DEVELOPMENT. NEW POSTER TO COME!!*****
 
Our Play
Bitch. A catartic purge, based on a true story.

As two best friends clean up the mess of the night before, they recover from their alcoholic and romantic hangovers. A drunken glimpse into the journeys of friendships and loves, and the hilarious bumps along the way.


Director: Ted Hallett

Cast: Erin Thompson, Tracey Beltrano

Running Time: 45min.

Genres: Play, Comedy

Warnings: Sexual Content, Mature Language

story:
Who We Are

We are a group of eight Bboys (breakdancers) who first started dancing in Gaza in 2003 as our own form of resistance against the occupation that tries to suffocate our lives. In 2009, Israel destroyed the rec center where we practiced as part of “Operation Cast Lead.” But we didn’t let that stop us. We turned to our supporters through a crowd funding site like this one, and in what seemed like a miracle, we raised the $10,000 needed to rebuild and even expand. Today, we have taught more than 100 youth to exercise and find relief from the trauma that is their lives through self-expression, and have performed in more than 70 shows across the Strip. In January, we even held the first-ever breakdance competition in Gaza


What We Need

You’ll notice from watching the video of our competition that we can’t produce good sound – yet the music is at the heart of our dancing! You can help us become the professionals we dream of being. With your contribution, we can purchase a “DJ command center” that allows us to create and mix all sorts of different sounds and effects. Check it out here: http://www.zzounds.com/item--ODYFZGS12CDJW. With any leftover funds, we’ll purchase additional accessories like headphones.

Such equipment is not available in Gaza, of course, due to the blockade. But “Funk,” the founder of the crew (who now lives in the United States), has identified an international aid worker who regularly travels through the Erez crossing into Gaza, and has agreed to carry it in. 


What You Get

We can’t afford to offer a gift in return for your contribution, but we promise to send pictures and a video of our first performance with the new music to everyone who gives. We’d love to chat by Skype, or to get to know you through any other means. Contact Funk at funkcbcrew@gmail.com.

Thank you for your support and love!

story:
THANK YOU TO EVERYONE WHO DONATED TO OUR CAMPAIGN. IT MEANS THE WORLD TO US! 

The Low Down

Shapeshift is a multidisciplinary installation utilizing film projection, found object assembly, large apparatus construction and elaborate costumery, activated by acrobatic, pole and aerial dance performance, that will take place in March 2015 at Betti Ono Gallery. The work centers around three unique, but interrelated physical articulations of the imagined or unseen worlds (ie. the spirit world, the other plane) that fuel our existence. The word Shapeshift centralizes the many ways in which the act of shapeshifting (one’s body and one’s surroundings) is a powerful tool for resilience and agency for the artists as queer, Black women. Viewers will explore the mystical environments during a two week period, while characters created and performed by the artists tell their stories of powerful transformation at three live shows.

Help us bring Shapeshift to the Bay Area audiences with your donation.

Photo: King Texas


Who We Are: BODY WAVES

Body Waves is an Oakland-based queer, Black, multidisciplinary dance collective founded in early 2013. Ana María Agüero Jahannes, India Davis and Antoinette Chen See are the founders, choreographers and dancers in the collective. Body Waves has been recognized internationally for stunning acrobatics, hand-balancing, invented apparatuses and choreography rooted in Black movement and aesthetics. Body Waves performs an imaginative repertory for local audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area and throughout the U.S. and Canada in night clubs, museums, galleries and outdoor performance venues. We have sold out the Brava Theater, performed and produced shows at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts, Betti Ono Gallery, The New Parish, The Lab and within the many hotbeds of Bay Area queer nightlife. 

We see ourselves not only as choreographers and creators of visual and performance art, but also as curators of spaces for community evolution and sustainment. As queer Black artists, we recognize and affirm that community is necessary for our individual survival and the full realization of our endeavors.


Photo: Gein Wong

The Impact

In the Bay Area’s queer communities of color, there is a dire need for programming that reminds us of our resilience. We often come together in the trance of night clubs or at a vigil for the death of a community member. Shapeshift is designed to engage queer communities of color to experience a mystical, yet accessible alternative reality, to consider the ways we already metamorphose to support our individual and collective well being, and to conceptualize new ways of being alive.

How does Body Waves give to our community? We perform and inspire, teach community classes, and strengthen the network of artists in the Bay Area. Our work is a gift to ourselves and our community. We are queer, Black artists dedicated to creating work and experiences that are healing, most beautiful to us and that expand the public imagination of what's possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you make a financial contribution, you can help:

  • Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr.
  • Email your networks.
  • Use the tools to share!

That's all folks, donate now!

story:
What is the ART/the V.?

This July, the iDiOM Theater in downtown Bellingham, WA is producing the world premiere of two new one-act plays written by young artists from the collegiate community. The Awful Real Thing (The ART) written by Brian Toews and The Velociraptor; A New Work by Rene Vohze written by R. Kent Taylor & Levi Friedman, will premiere back to back with intermission for six evenings July 17, 18, 19 & 24, 25, 26 for $8 @ 8pm. Tickets are available through Brown Paper Tickets:

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/752764

idiomtheater.com, and at the door.

The ART/The V. is an exciting experimental theatre outing unlike anything you've ever seen. Inspired by the Dadaist art movement, Tim & Eric, South Park,  Andy Kaufman, Odd Future and avant-garde theatre, these one-act plays are new, relevant works that will challenge and entertain audiences, making them burst out laughing and looking away in horror at the same time. As artists we want to bring a breath of fresh air to the theatre scene in Bellingham by sharing with you a satirical fringe spectacle quite unique to the Pacific Northwest, Bellingham and the theatre world. A synopsis of the show is down below.

The Awful Real Thing (The ART): In a remote cabin in the Pacific Northwest, failed writer, Matt Tellerman celebrates his birthday alone, cutting himself off from all outside communication but when best friend, Archie, arrives bearing "a present", all hell breaks loose. The ART exposes the dark impulses of human nature by tempting a lonely writer to indulge his savage wants and commit something truly awful in order prove his self worth. With guns, knives and typewriters at the ready, you alone are held accountable for your own survival. A vulgar and violent farce about friendship and art.


The Velociraptor (The V.) is the newest work from award winning playwright, René Vohzé. Critics are raving, “if you thought life had meaning, you need to see this play, because it doesn’t!” Pierre St. Ives, former dance instructor at Julliard, says, “an incendiary commentary on corporate voyeurism…a critical critique on critics.” Glenn Hergenhahn, Artistic Director of the iDiOM Theater, declares the piece, “Minimalist trash…I’m not sure what I was thinking…God, help me.” Prepare to be delighted, disgusted and utterly transformed as a human being!

Comprised of many local players, these works offer a wild and wondrous night of NEW and BOLD theatre. A world premiere like none other, The Awful Real Thing and The Velociraptor are sure to entertain. The show contains nudity, violence and adult language. For mature audiences only.

the awful real thing
written & directed by Brian Toews
CAST
Jake Foerg
Liam Reed
Trey McGee
Mario Orallo-Molinaro
Jake Bettermann

The Velociraptor; A New Work by Rene Vohze
written by R. Kent Taylor & Levi Friedman
directed by Brian Toews & Grayson Miller
CAST
Emily Lester, Mario Orallo-Molinaro, Anna Wulfekuhle, Trey McGee, Jake Foerg, Michael Brannan, Jessica Andrews, Fatima Wardak, Maedeline Easton, Lorraine Wilde, Elai Shine, Jake Bettermann, Olivia Thielemann, Jessica Young, Jon Ramsey and Abraham Friedman

CREATIVE TEAM

Directors: Brian Toews & Grayson Miller

Stage Manager: Angelica Metcalfe

Assistant Stage Manager: Amelia Whitacre

Lighting Designer: Emily Schmit

Costume Designer: Mason Fraker

Props Designer: Savannah LeCornu

Sound Designer: Elai Shine

Hair/Make Up: Brianne Haggerty

Dramaturg: Kevin Jones

Special FX: Gavin Annette

Videographer: Jake Bettermann

Poster Design/Artwork/Publicity: Shawn Baker, Grayson Miller, Levi Friedman, Samantha O'Brochta


What We Need & What You Get----->>>>

As a creative team we are aware that putting on a show of this magnitude is ambitious as well as costly. We care a lot about our product and want our audiences to see the best show that they can possibly see. We want theatre to be an experience again with artistic agency instead of something antiquated out-dated and irrelevant! With your support, you will help us on our artistic journey to bring passion, quality and relevance to the magic of theatrical storytelling and your experience as a paying audience. Here's what your donations will help us fund:

  • Rental fees (a select few of us have already put a down payment on the iDiOM theatre space however there are still additional rental costs needed to utilize the space. The ART/The V. will pay for the space with revenue generated with ticket sales and your donations).
  • Props (we will be pulling from our own resources as a team but there are certain props and pieces that are necessary to tell the story. Examples include used ties and magnifying glasses.)
  • Costumes (we will be pulling from our own wardrobes and from local thrift stores however there are certain costume pieces including a spandex suit that will require craft supplies and fabric. Your donation will help fund the wardrobe needed to tell our story genuinely and of higher quality)
  • Set Pieces (The ART/The V. will be staged very minimally but there may be certain directions the show could turn that may require set construction and pain supplies. Your donation would help fund paint, lumber, brushes and

The Impact

Most of us involved in this project are college students who are very serious about getting their art out there and their foot in the artistic community. We feel as a collective that we can make this project worth your time if you give us the chance to share our unique and artistic perspective with you. We promise you won't be disappointed; all your contribution would do is help us tell our story and make our dreams come true...that's a cliche but we say it with the utmost sincerity.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    LIKE the page on Facebook and share with friends:

    https://www.facebook.com/renevohze4lyfe?ref=br_tf 

    Purchase tickets here:

    http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/752764

story:
Kunstler is a two-character play about the radical attorney famous for defending the Chicago 7 and his involvement at Attica and Wounded Knee.  He had an outsized personality and a tremendous appetite for life.  The play concerns a seminar he is scheduled to give at a law school and his unanticipated encounter with a young black woman who has reasons to be angry with him.  The play premiered in Westchester at Hudson Stage in 2013.  The New York Times praised it as "wise and revealing" and "skillful," and the local paper, the Journal News, called it "glavanizing," "riveting," and "stirring."  (The photo above is from the Westchester production.)

The original plan was to remount that production in the New York Fringe, but our star and our director got offers elsewhere they could not turn down, so we're putting together a new production.  Our new star is Broadway veteran Nick Wyman, and he will be supported by Gillian Glasco, who made a vivid impression in my play Court-Martial at Fort Devens for which she shared an Audelco Award.  The director is Meagen Fay, an alum of the legendary Second City  of Chicago and a performer on and off Broadway and in countless TV shows.  As it happens, Meagen's uncle was an associate of Kunstler on the Chicago 7 trial and she grew up referring to him as Uncle Bill.  (She also attended some of the trial.)  I could hardly ask for anyone with better preparation to take this on.  

We're doing it in the New York Fringe, where I had such good luck performing a solo called You Only Shoot the Ones You Love in 2011.  (That show, produced by Artistic New Directions -- the producer of Kunstler-- got strong reviews, moved to an extended run and has played engagements around the country.)

The budget is based on the experience of doing You Only Shoot.  There were application fees for the Fringe, we'll have to rent a few weeks of rehearsal space, we need to observe Equity rules regarding financial compensation to the actors and stage manager, and we anticipate some costuming expenses.  All told, though, it's a pretty low budget for a full production of a full-length play.  (Since the play takes place in a lecture hall, elaborate scenery is not necessary.)

The original production was warmly received by a number of people who knew Kunstler.  Two of his daughters, his law partner, people he defended and a reporter with whom he had an ongoing relationship all came to see the show and were enthusiastic.  And those were only the people we could lure to Westchester.  We expect to engage much of New York's legal community.  Our hope is that a good response will result some kind of ongoing life for the project.

story:
DINOSLAM

Party World Rasslin' is a seasonal party and bizarre wrestling spectacle. At our last event, your support helped us defeat the mechanical legions of SLAMNET in an unforgettable Party War. After some hard matches, and hard partying, over 1500 people cried with one voice in exultation. Our champion victoriously held aloft a hatching snake egg - the symbol of humanity's rebirth!

PWR now prepares for our 12th Party! Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—PWR has  become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In 3 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring with clip-on work lamps to attendance of a thousand+ and a full spectrum of professional audio, video and lighting. And we've built almost all of it ourselves, thanks to you! We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs. Here's what we want to do for our next show.


Wrestling Finds a Way

Cybernetic apocalypse, haunted pirate ship, underground ice caves...these are some of the settings PWR has created and waged battle within. So what's next? What lost worlds have we yet to explore? We'll tell you - DINOSAURS!! PWR's next show will take place in lush prehistoric climes littered with ancient creatures! Dinosaurs will battle dinosaurs, humans will battle dinosaurs, humans will battle humans! Expect untamed saveragery and antedilluvian might! How is this possible?

As many of you know, our immortal snake patron, Mother Worm, was killed and reborn at our last show. Now, the infant form of this omnipotent creature is using her fledgling powers to populate 4th Tap Brewiing co-op with all kinds of creatures. DINOSAURS have returned to inherit the earth!

 But some would seek to exploit and destroy this beautiful new world. People like CHAD BLITZ, a former celebrity surfer corrupted and twisted by a poisonous energy drink called HELLSPORT. He'll do whatever he can to brew more HELLSPORT - and craft the world in its foul image! But our Partyweight Champion, THEODOSIA, the unfrozen colonial woman, will surely challenge Chad's foul intent! Chad has brainwashed and gained guardianship Theodosia's only friend, the 13-year-old Kippy. Can Theo free Kippy once and for all and defeat Chad, or will his cult-leader prowess pull everyone into a new and Dinosaur-free age? Wooooooah no!

The saga continues...along with New chapters in the chronicles of Pink Eye and the Dumpster Babes, Dan "the Man" Ziglar, Chubby Uncle Juan and Puggin'Head, Bull DeCroix and the NARRC, the Intergalactic Express, Luigi Primo, Dadbod, Skip Rathbone, Big Daddy Bolero, Charlie Frown and more!!! HAIL BABY WORM!

This is our fourth Summer Show since 2014! With a theme as exciting as this one, we want to make it totally bananas visually. Our art team is diligently turning 4th Tap Brewing Co-Op into a powerful gradient of prehistoric biomes. Magnificently vibrant fronds, a full-sized and articulated dinosaur head, TONS of skeletons, black-light iridescent algae and bones - it's going to rule!

What is this money used for?

$5100 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on a show for 1500 people. One and a half thundo! Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spent north of $9000, each, to produce our last 2 shows.

Through diligent saving and prudent investment, we've managed to cap our fundraising goal at ~$5000, depending on the season. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; your support and our careful budgeting have allowed us to do this without ballooning our costs! And it's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than two years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations have let us do include:

  • Cooling. We don't want the heat of summer to discourage people from engaging in Party Violence. We're renting a couple of portable AC units to help everyone stay cool n' comfortable! These suckers draw a lot of power, as well, so we're going to get a generator to make sure our electrical system is protected.

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a GLOWING, NEON CYBERSCAPE by their selfless, capable hands. The DINOTOPIA they are creating is going to be an immense and lush party zone you won't want to leave! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Safe space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem, no questions asked. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

  • Projection and lighting. Huge audiences compel us to try to use every part of our venue—so that all audience members can find a comfortable view of the show. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We still have improvements to make; you'll notice and love our latest generation of lights!

  • Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.

Show Expenses: $2450

Props: $300
Art: $450
Contruction Projects: $75
Cooling: $550
Staff Food: $80
Promo materials: $100
Security: $160
Insurance: $385
Printing: $150
Training: $200

Operational Expenses: $725

Discretionary Show Expenses: $325
New Projects Capital: $400

Other Expenses: $4406

Artist and staff pay: $2350
Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $1653
Indiegogo and credit card fees: $403.86

Extremely Hype Swag

 
Whoa!!! If you donate, you'll get some great perks! Including an exclusive T-shirt that you can only get from this indiegogo campaign!

Here's the EXCLUSIVE new T-shirt by Nat Bradford! Get it in a black or green, tee or tank!
 




Colors may vary slightly.

Also, a new COMMEMORATIVE POSTER from Zeke Gaudiana! What! Check out this great dinosaur friends:



And how about a PLUSHY BABY MOTHER WORM? Take home PWR's favorite Snake Deity, by C James Donovan!



Trading cards are headed your way, too! 7 new cards + 17 favorites relevant to the show - get a pack of 5 double-sided cards!

 



Laser cut pins by Nat Bradford!

Some other great rewards include VIP Balcony passes, pins, and more! Keep an eye on this space for more pictures!

Risks & Challenges

 

Challenges:

PWR has become robust and its universe swole with powerful party drama. As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter.

 

Risks:

The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and DARKWAR!


Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/405244896500242/

HMW

story:
The Quickie of It.

I'm a writer, singer and spoken word artist with a new rock/punk musical called wRETCH, which has just been accepted into the prestigious Fresh Fruit Festival (LGBTQ Arts Fest).  In my 25 years as a writer, I've written many songs, but never a full musical and I am SO excited for this new foray into musical theatre.  This project involves all the things I love: theatre, a strong message, risk-taking, music and women!

This project is so important to me because it is a platform to speak out (sing out!) against the sexism that is rampant in our society.  But not in an angry, ranty kind of way.  In a fun, tongue-in-cheek, sardonic, humorous, intelligent kind of way.  For many of the songs, I adopted the Riot Grrrl style of In Your Face lyrics and performance that I love so much.  I'm no wall flower and wRETCH is a celebration of women who stand UP and stand OUT.  It is absolutely vital to get the show's message out there: Even though we have so little control in society, we must not take it out on our bodies.  We have to support ourselves and support each other as we thrive!

I've been working on this show for almost a year and getting to the production/performance stage is actually a dream come true.  Not only do I get to realize a show that I believe in with all my heart, but I get to be the lead vocal in a friggin' rock band!  How amazing is that!

Contributions will help us fund this dream project.  When you contribute $1 or $27 or even $567 or more, you are helping to bring together a team of women who are rocking sexism back on its ass.  All the artists involved with the project are receiving honorariums.  The venue and some of the tech is all paid for by Festival (thank you FFF!).  But we need sets, lights, sound gear, costumes, props, marketing and, most importantly, I need a sub sandwich that I eat in the 2nd act!

wRETCH will be presented as part of the Fresh Fruit Festival on July 12, 14 , 15 2017 @ 9pm at The Wild Project. 195 E. 3rd Street, NYC.  Tickets are available at www.freshfruitfestival.com.

How wRETCH was born.

Last year my 16 year old daughter was hospitalized for twelve weeks for an eating disorder.  I learned how desperately she struggled with having a positive body image.   All the images of successful, happy, sexy, strong women that she saw were of slender women.  Even the women who were considered “big and beautiful” weren’t all that big.  Even though I had told her since she was little to “love herself for who she is, however she is,” the media monster had gotten to her. 

I got angry.

According to the National Eating Disorders Association: "In the United States, 20 million women and 10 million men suffer from a clinically significant eating disorder at some time in their life...”  That means that nearly 1 out of every 10 women/teens/girls and 1 out of every 20 men/teens/boys suffer with an eating disorder at some point in their life.  I ask WHY?

I realized that no matter how many times I told my daughter that she was beautiful, smart and wonderful, I couldn’t compete with the unrealistic, unattainable, unbelievably narrow concepts of beauty, attractiveness, and sexiness in our culture, all of which are perpetuated by the images in movies, tv, videos, on-line, commercials, ads, and music.

So I decided to do something about it by writing wRETCH.

I’ve heard from my therapist that sublimation is the most productive use of any negative emotion:  turn it into art.  So, I created wRETCH.  It’s a response to the current version of the war on women and femininity which manifests in women, trans women and gay men as eating disorders, body hate, mental health issues, low self esteem and depression.  

wRETCH is an intense, hard-hitting, fierce, at times funny as hell, response to sexism and anti-feminism.  The story follows the story of a band called wRETCH while they put on their final show.  Throughout the fast-paced 80 minutes, the band sings songs about eating disorders, yes, but also about body image, woman power, sexual autonomy, mental illness and woman/feminine culture (including drag/gay male culture).

Now, 15 months after my daughter was discharged from the hospital, she is maintaining a handle on her eating disorder, with the support of a therapist, a nutritionist, her friends, and me.  

I wrote this show for her and fierce feminine women and men everywhere.  Woman Power!

The Nuts-n-Bolts

We need $7,000 to put on this show.  Really, we need $14K, but I'm using $7,000 of my own savings because I believe in this show so much.  I know they say artists shouldn't fund their own work, but I really believe in this show and I don't want to ask you to foot the entire bill.

Where the $14K will go.

$7,000 (approx) will go to pay the Actor/Musicians, Director, Stage Manager, Lighting, Set, Props, Costume, Sound and Make Up Designers.  

$4,000 (approx) will go to production - sets, costumes, props, sound gear rental ($1500 in and of itself), rehearsal rental

$2000 (approx) will go to marketing materials - postcards, flyers, Facebook, ads

$1000 (approx) will go to storage of all the set pieces and musical instruments for the two weeks leading up to the show and during the show, travel expenses and possibly tshirts, if we can get them made.

If we don't make our goal, then funds will be lessened accordingly from the following areas in order: costumes, rehearsal studio rental, sets, make up, marketing, storage, travel expenses, artists' fees.

#TeamwRETCH

Alex, Rachel, T, Steph, Deb, Danica, Eli, Emily, Vickie and, Dan are making up this great team who all come from amazing diverse backgrounds.  Deb, Steph and T all come from punk, rock-n-roll backgrounds, Rachel's got opera in her blood, I'm a bluesy, spoken word kinda dyke.  Alex is a physical devised theatre artist, The team's designers are from theatre, music concerts, dance and film.  And Dan is just...well...amazing - as stage manager and all around go-to guy.

Making us look great on social media and communications is Megan Picurro.  Also vital to the team is Victoria Weinberg (line producer) who is passionately dedicated to women in the arts.  Cedric Hill (producer) is the CEO of To & From Productions and  my long time artistic/business partner.

 (Check out the Team section for more info on these amazing people.)

Perked Up

Each of the perk levels are named for strong, courageous, inspiring women and feminine men who pave the way for women like me to do what I do.

Hillary Clinton perk ($1) - Public Thank you on Facebook and Twitter

Ani DiFranco perk ($11) - All previous perks plus a "We Rock Sexism on its Ass" sticker

Laverne Cox perk ($27) - All previous perks plus a copy of the official show flyer signed by all the cast members.

Margaret Cho perk ($53) - All previous perks plus an inside look at rehearsals (5 min video shared with you)

Lily Tomlin perk ($77) - All previous perks plus one track from the upcoming cast recording.

Laurie Anderson perk ($101) - A personalized poem for you or a loved one written by Pandora Scooter. Great for anniversaries, birthday, special occasions or just because.

Suzan Lori Parks perk ($157) - Personal thank you letter from Pandora (plus all perks at the $77 dollar level and below)

Tina Turner perk ($253) - 10 minute Facetime chat with some of the team of wRETCH including actors, designers, director, stage manager, writer and more! (plus all perks from the $77 level and below)

Meshell N'Degeocello perk ($567) - DVD of the show for your viewing pleasure! (plus all perks from the $77 level and below)

Elizabeth Warren perk ($755) - Cast recording of the album wRETCH (plus all perks from the $77 level and below)

RuPaul perk ($1001) - House Concert with wRETCH the band anywhere in the tri-state area (NYC/NJ/CT)

Kathleen Hanna perk ($2503) - House Concert with wRETCH the band anywhere between Boston through CT into NJ/Eastern PA and down to DC.

Want a perk that you don't see here?  Let me know!  pandora@pandorascooter.com. I love haggling!

Trust.

I've been writing and performing my own original shows for 16 years.  As a DIY performance artist, I revel in the producing, the coordinating, the negotiating, and the collaborating.  I am an out of the box performer.  I like to write my own stories and experiences and play them out on stage in front of a live audience.  I make my own material and produce it myself (with loads of help from people like you and from Festivals like Fresh Fruit).  Beyond a shadow of a doubt, I am dedicated to this project.  I will see it through to the very end (and past that, probably).  I have never given up on a project.  And, according to my long-term team mates (directors and producers), I usually put on a great show.  

Please trust that your financial support will be very much appreciated, prudently spent and will help to create a theatrical experience that will thrill our audiences.  

Some Risky Business

There are some risks in putting on a show in Manhattan in July.  The first one is that the audience may not show up.  In order to handle this, I've recruited a large team of people (including three producers) who are going to focus on getting the butts in the seats.  I also have a kick-ass marketing director on board who is creating all our logos, flyers and branding.  (She happens to be a total Riot Grrrl fan, too!)  Another risk at this DIY level is that cast members may get better paying gigs and feel they have to drop out.  I'm confident that even if this happens, we'll be able to catch up with a new cast member and deliver a fantastic show.  A third risk is that the show just won't go "over."  To mitigate this risk, we're going to be doing teasers and previews of the show to test it out before showtime at the Fresh Fruit Festival.

You Love This But...

If you can't contribute, but you love this project, you can still help out in a number of ways:

  1. Post this campaign on Facebook with your personal endorsement and why your friends should consider giving.
  2. If you're in the NYC area, come see the show! And bring friends! Check us out on Facebook.
  3. Reach out to two or three friends who might be able to contribute and personally ask them to look at this campaign page.
  4. Get in touch with me at pandora@pandorascooter.com to ask what else you can do!  We always need volunteers!

Thank you for all your support and interest!
story_txt:
The Quickie of It.
I'm a writer, singer and spoken word artist with a new rock/punk musical called wRETCH, which has just been accepted into the prestigious Fresh Fruit Festival (LGBTQ Arts Fest).  In my 25 years as a writer, I've written many songs, but never a full musical and I am SO excited for this new foray into musical theatre.  This project involves all the things I love: theatre, a strong message, risk-taking, music and women!
This project is so important to me because it is a platform to speak out (sing out!) against the sexism that is rampant in our society.  But not in an angry, ranty kind of way.  In a fun, tongue-in-cheek, sardonic, humorous, intelligent kind of way.  For many of the songs, I adopted the Riot Grrrl style of In Your Face lyrics and performance that I love so much.  I'm no wall flower and wRETCH is a celebration of women who stand UP and stand OUT.  It is absolutely vital to get the show's message out there: Even though we have so little control in society, we must not take it out on our bodies.  We have to support ourselves and support each other as we thrive!
I've been working on this show for almost a year and getting to the production/performance stage is actually a dream come true.  Not only do I get to realize a show that I believe in with all my heart, but I get to be the lead vocal in a friggin' rock band!  How amazing is that!
Contributions will help us fund this dream project.  When you contribute $1 or $27 or even $567 or more, you are helping to bring together a team of women who are rocking sexism back on its ass.  All the artists involved with the project are receiving honorariums.  The venue and some of the tech is all paid for by Festival (thank you FFF!).  But we need sets, lights, sound gear, costumes, props, marketing and, most importantly, I need a sub sandwich that I eat in the 2nd act!
wRETCH will be presented as part of the Fresh Fruit Festival on July 12, 14 , 15 2017 @ 9pm at The Wild Project. 195 E. 3rd Street, NYC.  Tickets are available at www.freshfruitfestival.com.

How wRETCH was born.
Last year my 16 year old daughter was hospitalized for twelve weeks for an eating disorder.  I learned how desperately she struggled with having a positive body image.   All the images of successful, happy, sexy, strong women that she saw were of slender women.  Even the women who were considered “big and beautiful” weren’t all that big.  Even though I had told her since she was little to “love herself for who she is, however she is,” the media monster had gotten to her. 
I got angry.
According to the National Eating Disorders Association: "In the United States, 20 million women and 10 million men suffer from a clinically significant eating disorder at some time in their life...”  That means that nearly 1 out of every 10 women/teens/girls and 1 out of every 20 men/teens/boys suffer with an eating disorder at some point in their life.  I ask WHY?
I realized that no matter how many times I told my daughter that she was beautiful, smart and wonderful, I couldn’t compete with the unrealistic, unattainable, unbelievably narrow concepts of beauty, attractiveness, and sexiness in our culture, all of which are perpetuated by the images in movies, tv, videos, on-line, commercials, ads, and music.
So I decided to do something about it by writing wRETCH.
I’ve heard from my therapist that sublimation is the most productive use of any negative emotion:  turn it into art.  So, I created wRETCH.  It’s a response to the current version of the war on women and femininity which manifests in women, trans women and gay men as eating disorders, body hate, mental health issues, low self esteem and depression.  
wRETCH is an intense, hard-hitting, fierce, at times funny as hell, response to sexism and anti-feminism.  The story follows the story of a band called wRETCH while they put on their final show.  Throughout the fast-paced 80 minutes, the band sings songs about eating disorders, yes, but also about body image, woman power, sexual autonomy, mental illness and woman/feminine culture (including drag/gay male culture).
Now, 15 months after my daughter was discharged from the hospital, she is maintaining a handle on her eating disorder, with the support of a therapist, a nutritionist, her friends, and me.  
I wrote this show for her and fierce feminine women and men everywhere.  Woman Power!
The Nuts-n-Bolts
We need $7,000 to put on this show.  Really, we need $14K, but I'm using $7,000 of my own savings because I believe in this show so much.  I know they say artists shouldn't fund their own work, but I really believe in this show and I don't want to ask you to foot the entire bill.
Where the $14K will go.
$7,000 (approx) will go to pay the Actor/Musicians, Director, Stage Manager, Lighting, Set, Props, Costume, Sound and Make Up Designers.  
$4,000 (approx) will go to production - sets, costumes, props, sound gear rental ($1500 in and of itself), rehearsal rental
$2000 (approx) will go to marketing materials - postcards, flyers, Facebook, ads
$1000 (approx) will go to storage of all the set pieces and musical instruments for the two weeks leading up to the show and during the show, travel expenses and possibly tshirts, if we can get them made.
If we don't make our goal, then funds will be lessened accordingly from the following areas in order: costumes, rehearsal studio rental, sets, make up, marketing, storage, travel expenses, artists' fees.
#TeamwRETCH
Alex, Rachel, T, Steph, Deb, Danica, Eli, Emily, Vickie and, Dan are making up this great team who all come from amazing diverse backgrounds.  Deb, Steph and T all come from punk, rock-n-roll backgrounds, Rachel's got opera in her blood, I'm a bluesy, spoken word kinda dyke.  Alex is a physical devised theatre artist, The team's designers are from theatre, music concerts, dance and film.  And Dan is just...well...amazing - as stage manager and all around go-to guy.
Making us look great on social media and communications is Megan Picurro.  Also vital to the team is Victoria Weinberg (line producer) who is passionately dedicated to women in the arts.  Cedric Hill (producer) is the CEO of To & From Productions and  my long time artistic/business partner.
 (Check out the Team section for more info on these amazing people.)
Perked Up
Each of the perk levels are named for strong, courageous, inspiring women and feminine men who pave the way for women like me to do what I do.
Hillary Clinton perk ($1) - Public Thank you on Facebook and Twitter
Ani DiFranco perk ($11) - All previous perks plus a "We Rock Sexism on its Ass" sticker
Laverne Cox perk ($27) - All previous perks plus a copy of the official show flyer signed by all the cast members.
Margaret Cho perk ($53) - All previous perks plus an inside look at rehearsals (5 min video shared with you)
Lily Tomlin perk ($77) - All previous perks plus one track from the upcoming cast recording.
Laurie Anderson perk ($101) - A personalized poem for you or a loved one written by Pandora Scooter. Great for anniversaries, birthday, special occasions or just because.
Suzan Lori Parks perk ($157) - Personal thank you letter from Pandora (plus all perks at the $77 dollar level and below)
Tina Turner perk ($253) - 10 minute Facetime chat with some of the team of wRETCH including actors, designers, director, stage manager, writer and more! (plus all perks from the $77 level and below)
Meshell N'Degeocello perk ($567) - DVD of the show for your viewing pleasure! (plus all perks from the $77 level and below)
Elizabeth Warren perk ($755) - Cast recording of the album wRETCH (plus all perks from the $77 level and below)
RuPaul perk ($1001) - House Concert with wRETCH the band anywhere in the tri-state area (NYC/NJ/CT)
Kathleen Hanna perk ($2503) - House Concert with wRETCH the band anywhere between Boston through CT into NJ/Eastern PA and down to DC.
Want a perk that you don't see here?  Let me know!  pandora@pandorascooter.com. I love haggling!

Trust.
I've been writing and performing my own original shows for 16 years.  As a DIY performance artist, I revel in the producing, the coordinating, the negotiating, and the collaborating.  I am an out of the box performer.  I like to write my own stories and experiences and play them out on stage in front of a live audience.  I make my own material and produce it myself (with loads of help from people like you and from Festivals like Fresh Fruit).  Beyond a shadow of a doubt, I am dedicated to this project.  I will see it through to the very end (and past that, probably).  I have never given up on a project.  And, according to my long-term team mates (directors and producers), I usually put on a great show.  
Please trust that your financial support will be very much appreciated, prudently spent and will help to create a theatrical experience that will thrill our audiences.  

Some Risky Business
There are some risks in putting on a show in Manhattan in July.  The first one is that the audience may not show up.  In order to handle this, I've recruited a large team of people (including three producers) who are going to focus on getting the butts in the seats.  I also have a kick-ass marketing director on board who is creating all our logos, flyers and branding.  (She happens to be a total Riot Grrrl fan, too!)  Another risk at this DIY level is that cast members may get better paying gigs and feel they have to drop out.  I'm confident that even if this happens, we'll be able to catch up with a new cast member and deliver a fantastic show.  A third risk is that the show just won't go "over."  To mitigate this risk, we're going to be doing teasers and previews of the show to test it out before showtime at the Fresh Fruit Festival.

You Love This But...
If you can't contribute, but you love this project, you can still help out in a number of ways:

Post this campaign on Facebook with your personal endorsement and why your friends should consider giving.
If you're in the NYC area, come see the show! And bring friends! Check us out on Facebook.
Reach out to two or three friends who might be able to contribute and personally ask them to look at this campaign page.
Get in touch with me at pandora@pandorascooter.com to ask what else you can do!  We always need volunteers!

Thank you for all your support and interest!

story:
First let us introduce ourselves with the RARE Theatre Productions Mission Statement...

Theatre should be a conversation amongst souls: a relationship that is able to take a shortcut past the filters, prejudices, and other shallow inhibitors that keep people from making connections.  It should recharge the humanity that gets drained little by little through day to day life. Everyone has a story to tell.  We at RARE Theatre believe that everyone also has a story to hear. We have a desire to work in theatre because we love telling stories and know the benefits of hearing the right story at the right time. In every production we put forth, we will seek those identifiable moments of humanity and ways to bridge the gap between performer and audience.  We will push to create the best theatre in both acting and production. We believe in collaboration and know that our hard work can make up for small (and sometimes nonexistent) budgets...

Now for our inaugural production as a group of storytelling professionals (and the reason we need your help!)... Rare Theatre Productions presents...

“Crooked,” a play by Catherine Trieschmann:

Fourteen year old Laney arrives in Oxford, Mississippi with a twisted back, a mother in crisis and a burning desire to be writer. When she befriends Maribel Purdy, a fervent believer in the power of Jesus Christ to save her from the humiliations of High School, Laney embarks on a hilarious spiritual and coming-of-age journey that challenges her mother's secular worldview and threatens to tear their fragile relationship apart.
"The work of a big accomplished writer's voice...a gem of a discovery." -The New York Times.
"This is a wonderfully neat play, at once simple and complex, grappling with big issues - matters of faith, fantasy and the flesh - while keeping its sneakers firmly planted on the suburban topsoil of adolescent angst and domestic frictions." - The Daily Telegraph.

_____________________________________________________________________________

We are incredibly passionate about theatre, and especially this piece! We want to give you, our audience, the best possible experience!

That's where you come in.  Shows (especially shows that are this awesome) cost money to produce. We are theatre artists, so we are accustomed to working on tight budgets. Therefore, we're grateful for any amount you give us, and will use it in an economical, productive way. We aren't aiming for extravagance, we just want to give the piece justice.

what we need and what you get.

Here's what your contributions will be going towards:

- Licensing Rights for the show

-Production Materials (Lighting gels, props, paint, lumber, costumes- etc)

-Marketing (posters, programs, flyers, ads in local publications)

-Rented pieces/materials

-We also would love to give financial support to our production team. They are all very talented professionals that are giving of their time and creativity. We want to ensure that they are taken care of and aren't losing money while they are taking care of us.

Read all about the perks------------------->

other ways you can help.

If you can't contribute financially, don't feel bad! We still care about you! You can help us out TREMENDOUSLY by spreading the word. It's been proven that the best form of advertising is word of mouth. Seriously. Google it.

And stay tuned for announcements about our mid-January opening!

Our sincerest “thank yous!” from 

The RARE Theatre Productions Team: 

Artistic directors Bekah Reimer (also director of “Crooked") and Adam Ellis.

And the CAST of “Crooked”:

Laney: Kallen Prosterman

Maribel: Amanda Cutrona

Elise: Jill Braddock-Watson

story:
LISPA has offered Mo'min Swaitat, a Palestinian acting teacher, actor and director, a place on the Advanced Devising Practice program in 2015. The class will meet in Berlin from January to March, and then in London until July. This is an incredible opportunity for an aspiring Palestinian actor, artist and theater school instructor to hone his craft and continue his artistic training. Mo’min will not be able to accept this offer without your support!

The good news That LISPA offered me a Half-Tuition Scholarship


Mo'min's Story

Mo’min Swaitat grew up in Jenin and is a passionate and active participant of the global theater community. Mo’min graduated from The Freedom Theatre in 2011. He completed the Initiation Course In Devising Theatre in 2013 -2014 before returning to work at The Freedom Theatre. Mo'min created Askadinya, a groundbreaking play on gender-based violence, written based on women’s stories gathered during The Freedom Theatre’s interactive theater workshops with women in marginalized communities across the West Bank. Today, he has the chance to return to LISPA and continue his education On The Advanced Devising Practice course 2015, At London International School of Performing Arts (LISPA).


The Freedom Theatre

The Freedom Theatre is a community-based theatre and cultural center in the Jenin Refugee Camp, occupied Palestine. The Freedom Theatre is developing a vibrant and creative artistic community. While emphasizing professionalism and innovation, the aim of the theatre is also to empower youth and women in the community and to explore the potential of arts as an important catalyst for social change.


What We Need: $12000

  • Tuition: $5000
  • Travel expenses: $1,500
  • Room rental for 7 months: $5,500
Our goal is based on tuition, travel expenses, and room rental. Anything we make over our goal will go toward Mo'min's local transportation and living expenses, including food.


What you get 

By funding this campaign, you get:
  • $50 - Freedom Theatre T-shirt
  • $100- Arna's Children DVD
  • $500 - Video clip Askadinya
  • $1,000 - digital photo of Mo'min in show at LISPA   

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot support us financially, you can help us with the campaign by sharing this link on Twitter, Facebook, or via e-mail and spreading the word!
