story:
Wait.. what's happening?!

The Red Lips Woman Production of Sex, Cynicism and Other Small Miracles has been chosen out of thousands of applicants to attend the renowned New York International Fringe Festival, for its 20th year anniversary. This is HUGE! 


Sex, Cynicism and Other Small Miracles! 

The production is the brainchild of Lachlan the Bray and Garrett Riley and has been twelve months in the making. It first premiered in June 2015 at the Exit Theater in San Francisco, directed by Mia Romero, before crossing the ocean to Kempsey, Australia. Early 2016 found the production touring regionally throughout the Bay Area, everywhere from Truckee to Bolinas. Now it has been accepted into one of the best known theatrical festivals in the world that is attended by over 75, 000 people annually.  The opportunity for exposure is of huge magnitude -- and we humbly ask your help to get it there!


What's it about?

Rent is costing you a kidney.  Love is fleeting.  Our dependence on pharmaceuticals is slowly killing us. An Australian country boy and an urban vagrant coax spoken-word, rock-n-roll and theatre into a raucous threesome exploring why each and every one of these things are beautiful.

  

Why should this happen?

Because this is a story about our generation's daily struggles, which we face both as artists and individuals.  The show uses satire, music and of course, spoken word to tell the stories of two polarizing poets navigating an urban landscape by balancing love lives and career moves.  Lachlan the Bray emigrated from Australia in an attempt to ‘make it big!’ and now battles with the choice of commercial success or artistic freedom.  Garrett Riley, a lonesome vagrant rock star on the up, copes with heartbreak that could very well lead to his demise.  The show features a three-piece band that underpins the stories and songs of these two artists, swinging loosely through jazz, blues and rock music.
The style of the production holds the future of collaborative performance arts. Red Lips Woman productions are dedicated to producing empathetic, engaging theatre that will inspire people to change their lives and in turn, the world. RLW was created to serve this purpose, while simultaneously providing strong roles for women (which exists through Mia Romero, our Director and Producer).

The Nitty Gritty 

Until now we have self-funded all of our previous incarnations of this show but unfortunately, the budget required to take a show cross-country is beyond our capabilities.  We also are operating in the tightest time crunch so far, with only two months until the Festival begins. We need your help!
The logistics of taking a show out of town (let alone across the country) are no small undertaking. (Don't worry, we are up for the challenge!) Airfares and accommodation are providing the largest financial hurdle as we must transport and house the crew in NYC for the duration of the two-week long festival.  Once we arrive, our expenses are focused primarily on the show: technical support (board operator, lighting design, stage manager), musical equipment rental and amps, secure transportation to and from the venue with all our gear, and liability insurance for our cast and crew.  We also need to pay our artists!They are providing their exceptional talents and time to be a part of this project and must be duly compensated.  A percent of our budget is going towards publicity as well, so we can get bums on seats once we are up and running.  Here is a short breakdown of where it all goes:

Publicity:
  • Program and flyer printing ($300)
  • Advertisement in TimeOut New York Program ($175)
  • Facebook listing ($100)
  • Feature in Fringe Propaganda (200)
  • SpinCycle mailing lists ($500)
Airfares:
  • $1800-$2100 for 5  people

Accommodation:

  • $1750-$2000, 5 people for 2 weeks

Production costs:

  • Artist/musician stipends ($1500)
  • Stage manager/board op ($500)
  • Equipment rental ($1500)
  • Set design/materials ($800)
  • Rehearsal space ($500)
  • Insurance ($125)

    Your Direct Impact! 

    Helping the show get to the Fringe is not just a huge opportunity for us as performers, it is recognition for the genre itself. The opportunity to bring poetry to a theater stage is super exciting! These art forms go hand in hand and productions melding the two are shockingly rare. With our show, we can educate a modern theatre audience on the plight of non-traditional art forms.

    Even if you may not be able to contribute financially, your energy in helping spread the word is essential! Help us connect with people who live in NYC and can attend, mention it to a friend, share the events and our videos. Tweet us! It is going to be an exhilarating ride, and we can't wait to share it with you!

    Speaking of which -- there are some pretty great incentives... you know, in case ensuring the future of spoken word and theater wasn't enough. :) Go check them out!

Helping the show get to the Fringe is not just a huge opportunity for us as performers, it is recognition for the genre itself. The opportunity to bring poetry to a theater stage is super exciting! These art forms go hand in hand and productions melding the two are shockingly rare. With our show, we can educate a modern theatre audience on the plight of non-traditional art forms.
Even if you may not be able to contribute financially, your energy in helping spread the word is essential! Help us connect with people who live in NYC and can attend, mention it to a friend, share the events and our videos. Tweet us! It is going to be an exhilarating ride, and we can't wait to share it with you! 
Speaking of which -- there are some pretty great incentives... you know, in case ensuring the future of spoken word and theater wasn't enough. :) Go check them out!

story:
Hello! We are LKT Productions - an emerging theatre company from across the UK who are ambitious, feisty and two-thirds Northern! (Toby lets us down....). We have been mentored by award-winning Hope Theatre and artistic director Matthew Parker.

We are raising funds to create a vivid, re-imagining of Oscar Wilde’s Th’ Importance of Being Earnest! It’s incredibly important to us that we build up funding and support to: 

  • Pay our actors and creatives 
  • Stay out of debt (hopefully)
  • Get regional (particularly Northern) accents onto the London fringe theatre scene 
  • Change the tradition of classics and the notion of upper class being interpreted as characters having an RP accent. 
  • Equality, diversity and making amazing theatre. 

It will be incredible for us to achieve these goals and we’re trying as hard as can to gain additional funding and sponsorship but market is saturated and extra money is scarce. We are relying on family, friends and complete theatre-loving strangers to help us! 

What We Need & What You Get: 

We need £5000 or as much as we are able to raise in 60 days! Every single penny counts and if that is all you can it will be received just as gratefully! 

We are offering a plethora of rewards for those who support us such as: 

  • signed programmes 
  • signed posters 
  • Thanks on our website 
  • Free tickets 
  • Free programmes
  • Free drinks on night of performance 
  • Invitation to Press Night/Gala Performance 
  • Mentions in our programme and on our social media 
  • Invitations to Producer’s run 
  • Invitation to Dress Rehearsal 

If we don’t reach out £5000 goal then we’ll be scrabbling around to pick up the rest of the bill ourselves as we will not let our actors and creatives go without!

LKT Productions is made up of ambitious, dedicated professionals who strive to do their best for every project they undertake. We will make this project a success but need your help to do that! 

Other Ways You Can Help! 

Please share this page on social media and follow us on our Facebook: @LKTProd 

Or twitter: @LktProductions! Every share gets us closer to our goal!

story:
Hello! How have you been? 

We are Jakarta Performing Arts Community, a non-profit musical theatre community based in Jakarta. Consisting solely of volunteers, our community has been a platform to learn more about musical theatre and its craft. It has grown into a platform to explore the inner workings of a theater production --where we get to learn more about the performance and production aspects. It has also become a platform to explore and reflect on current social issues through our performance.

In 2017, we examine the rampant prejudice plaguing Indonesia through the star-crossed love story of WEST SIDE STORY. Last year, we brought DREAMGIRLS, a tale of female empowerment and solidarity, to life.

This year, we are proud to announce our upcoming production, COMPANY: A Musical Comedy, and explore the meaning of marriage and companionship in an urban society.

 

"Why are you not married yet?"

"Why did you marry so young?"

Sounds familiar? 
Everyday, we are faced with such personal questions from our peers. In our rapidly developing world, perhaps those fleeting moments of intimacy  are our way to grasp for a human connection.

COMPANY embodies our most intimate and universal theme yet: human relationships. It tells the story of Bobby, a young single man living in New York. Surrounded by married friends and exciting flings, Bobby contemplates what company truly means in a lonely life in the city that never sleeps.

We believe that COMPANY is as timely as ever. The musical is set in New York City and explores modern issues in a modern setting, from the values of marriage to defining sexuality to encountering gender inequality to the ups and downs of modern friendships. All familiar topics for city dwellers.

With all the bad reputations surrounding Jakarta at the moment, we feel that it is important to change the narrative and shed some light on a different side of Jakarta. It is one of the fastest-growing metropolitan areas in Asia, in which modern performances are popular among the globalized, urban population. English is more widely learned and spoken among our audience, and they are very keen to be exposed to more English-speaking entertainments.

On top of that, this will be our first production to incorporate live orchestra as our accompaniment. It will be our biggest challenge yet, but with your help, we can prepare our talented and hard-working volunteer cast and crew for the next step of our community’s growth.

 

Putting together a stage production is never an easy task. There is a multitude of creative, technical, and managerial aspects involved.

Our community supported by donors, fundraising efforts, and unrelenting support from our audience. However, the resources to stage a production in Jakarta are limited and expensive --from rehearsal space, set buildings, sound equipment, to venue hire.

Although we are a non-profit theatre community and not a professional theatre company, we believe that it is important to acquire the license to this musical as the proper practice in staging other people's works. We feel that we need to set a good example for other budding theatre communities in Jakarta.

Our community also consists entirely of volunteers who contribute their time and energy to a project close to their hearts. Therefore, we would like to ensure that our team is well taken care of and has a great time learning and growing with us.

 

The money pledged to our Indiegogo campaign will go toward purchasing a license from Music Theatre International.

The license will provide us with the right to perform COMPANY, as well as essential performance materials including the script and the score for our director and actors. 

Any additional money will go into our production budget, further divided into rehearsal venue, performance venue, set, lighting, costume, make up, and other needs. 

 

COMPANY is a profoundly entertaining and thought-provoking piece and we hope to do it justice. Our artistic vision requires a thorough attention to each production element. 

By donating, you are not only helping shape COMPANY into the best version we can. You are also pushing our team of volunteers to greater heights by enabling us to improve our craft for future productions. With our volunteers dedicated unrelenting energy and countless hours into our community, we strive to provide more extensive trainings --not only on performing, but stage management, set design, costumes & makeup, and firsthand learning experience in how to operate sound and lighting within what a professional theater production is like. Our community may not be able to give financial compensation for their hard work, but we can provide a proper learning opportunity about musical theater that we hope will be useful for our members beyond this community. Above all else, we want every single person in our community to grow with us.

We also would like to extend our contribution to the society beyond our productions. The proceeds of this production will be donated to Sahabat Anak, a non-profit organization that provide education for marginalized children. Additionally, we are planning to hold workshops and training sessions where we can share the joy of self-expression and the beauty in creativity with our underprivileged friends.

We believe that art should be accessible to all, and that every single cent counts in providing that opportunity for those who need it.

 

As a token of our gratitude, we are humbled to give perks to our donors who believe in our dream. Check out the perks page for more information!

 

If you would like to donate items such as food, drink, or suitable costumes, please reach out via email for a further discussion.

If you're interested in volunteering, please follow our social media @jakartapac for volunteer calls. 

And finally, spreading the word of our campaign is always appreciated. Share this campaign and tell your friends!

 

We cannot thank you enough for supporting our cause. 

There's a song in COMPANY called Side by Side. It goes: "What would we do without you? How would we ever get through?" That's precisely how we feel about you!

Join us on this exciting journey, and keep us COMPANY by supporting this production!

story:
RENO's Theatrical Dance Company

Founded in 2018 by Artistic Director, Keely Cobb, Around the Stage is a Reno based theatre and dance company comprised of multi-talented performers and theater technicians. Around the Stage has collaboratively created three evening length works in Reno, NV and been guests artists at Reno Little Theater, GhostLight TV and Encompass Academy. 

This year, we were so excited to have our Artistic Director, Keely Cobb, selected as one of Artown's commissioned artists. This was a huge honor and allowed the company to plan for a live dance show featuring live music at the Reno City Plaza. Unfortunately, due to COVID-19, we had to cancel every live event we had planned for 2020. This included all of our fundraisers, two months of rehearsals, our guest artist performances, professional development weekends and our Artown show.  Instead of dreading on what could have been, we decided to look to the future and start planning a big season for next year! 

"Take My Hand" A Music Video Premiere

When our live shows were canceled, we quickly turned to a virtual alternative

Coming July 18th

Our First EVER Music Video Premiere 

In collaboration with Adriana and the Wildflowers 

Get a taste of what Around the Stage is capable of and what we can bring to 2021!

Check out Adriana and the Wildflowers new single here: 

https://open.spotify.com/album/6zQMbIJkzKZ5z7leOMuMBk

 

Where Your $$$ Goes 

Producing shows is a highly expensive activity and while we have SO MANY ideas for next year, what we do is all based on the amount of funds we have to spend. Here's a list of a few of the many items that need to be purchased in order to get a show on its feet: 

  • Performance Space $$$$
  • Rehearsal Space $$ 
  • Costumes $$
  • Props $ 
  • Tech Equipment (Lighting and Sound Rentals) $$$$
  • Dancer Pay $$$
  • Technician Pay $$$
  • Photographers $$
  • Videographers $$$
  • Insurance $$
  • Permits $ 
  • Travel Expenses (Plane Tickets, Lodging, Gas) $$$

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are crazy right now! We completely understand. If you can't donate you can still help us out greatly by sharing this campaign and talking about it with your family, friends and co-workers!

story:
I would absolutely love to raise £1000 in order to go away and work on a few projects -

If you're able to contribute to my writing retreat, I will -

1)  Send you a copy of my first play Diary of a Hounslow Girl and my Second play POT

2) Have a a cup of coffee or tea (Whatever you fancy) with any emerging writers or actors who would like any advice on the industry or writing itself.

If I don't reach my entire goal I will use your incredibly generous donations to purchase smaller working spaces within London and towards writing time for myself.

Your contribution would give me the space I need to write some magic!

How can you help?

If you cant contribute then don't worry! Please make some noise about it on social media and share the Indiegogo Link with anyone and everyone!

story:
Stripped Down Dance Salon

Hi, I'm Gretchen Garnett.  Last year I relocated to Amsterdam from San Francisco, where I was running my dance company, Gretchen Garnett & Dancers.  When I arrived, I noticed a lack of venues and performances where young and emerging choregraphers could perform, show work and interact with audiences.  The Stripped Down Dance Salon was created to fill this need and to bring more dance into the Amsterdam community. It is an opportunity for some of Amsterdam's most exciting choreographers, dance makers and performers to connect with audiences and show their work in an informal, low-tech salon setting.  Four local groups, Gretchen Garnett & Dancers, Silvia Bennett/Gabor Csongradi/Emese Csornai, Jagoda Bobrowska and Svetlin Velchev, will show work in this new event at the end of May.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This is where you come in!  Of course, creating this type of event takes funds and those are tight everywhere!  The money we are raising with this campaign is simply to pay the artists for their work.  These are professional choreographers and performers bringing their passion and talent to the community and they deserve to be compensated.  Our $2,000 goal will just barely cover small stipends, but the more you can give, ther more will go directly to these hard-working dancers and choreographers.  Even if we don't reach our entire goal, you can know that these artists are getting paid with whatever you are able to raise.  To sweeten the deal a bit, I've added some perks, like special insights on the choreographic process, free tickets to performances, dances choreographed and performed just for you and private yoga lessons!  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that a monetary contribution is not possible for everyone.  But if you still want to help you can share this with everyone you know.  You can use the buttons on this page to share with your social networks.  You can tell people about it by email.  And most importantly, you can come to the show!  We do this to connect with you and seeing you at a performance is the best way to make that happen.  Details are below.

 

Thank you so much!

Gretchen Garnett

 

stripped down dance salon

new dance works by Gretchen Garnett & Dancers, Silvia Bennett/Gabor Csongradi/Emese Csornai, Jagoda Bobrowska and Svetlin Velchev

Sat. 25-Sun. 26 May 2013

20.30

Theater Perdu - Kloveniersburgwal 86, Amsterdam

Tickets: €10

for reservations email gretchengarnettanddancers@gmail.com

 

watch, socialize, drink, explore

story:
My Story

Summer ballet intensives are a critical part of my training as a serious ballet student. They allow me to have access to top teachers and facilities that my local studio cannot provide. They also allow me to focus completely on ballet training without interference from homework and school activities, which creates the ideal environment for me to greatly improve my dancing while I am there. Summer intensives are also expensive. I would love to go back to Miami City Ballet where I improved so much last summer but my family and I need some help to make it happen this year.

I have been saving every penny from cat sitting, Christmas money and the money my straight-A report cards bring in. With that money, the tuition cost is covered but my family and I are trying to raise the money for five weeks of housing and the round trip airfare. My overall goal is to raise 100 donations of 25 dollars. If you are able to help us out, a contribution of any amount will be greatly appreciated.

story:
Our Story

In October of 2009 Christopher Skinner was mysteriously and brutally murdered in downtown Toronto. This horrific event brought homophobic violence into the headlines and out of the shadows galvanizing the Toronto queer community. Everyday queer students continue to contemplate their lives because they are faced with gay bashing at school. However, some people, queers themselves, believe our marginalized community has grown up and we are no longer living in terror.

While our community has definitely evolved, lemonTree creations believes our fight is far from over.


Set out to explore being queer in contemporary Toronto, lemonTree creations assembled a group of dynamic performers to work together to share their stories of being gay in the city. After nearly two years of development and a workshop presentation at the 519 in July 2010, STILL LIFE is having its premiere at one of Canada's most exciting theatre festivals, SUMMERWORKS. 


Through the lens of a gay bashing, STILL LIFE explores how friends and strangers are connected by a night shared at a hospital. Time is fluid in the play with the past existing alongside the present. As Matt and Steven struggle to keep their relationship afloat, Andrew offers Steven an escape from the norm while Sarah, the only witness to the incident, puts the puzzle pieces together. A night out turns into a confrontation with the truth and thus, the four characters reveal the joys and struggles of being queer in a Toronto, today.




The Impact

Due to the nature of the project the artists involved were required to be in rehearsal for 6 hours, 6 days a week for almost 6 months (spread throughout two years). The art came from their experiences being queer in the city and their full presence was required. However, we are a small and very young non-profit company and our financial resources are limited. As such, most of our money goes into covering rehearsal space and other small production costs. Our artists have yet to be compensated properly for their time, commitment and most importantly for their artistic contribution to this very personal story.


As we move into our presentation at SummerWorks, our team is working hard to offset the production and marketing costs. This way, the revenue generated from the box office can allow us to properly pay our artists. This is where you come in. Your very generous contribution will go directly into covering our production costs. Once this is provided, and if we do surpass our $2000 goal, the funds will amount in generous and well deserved compensation for our artists. As a young company we rely on donations and box office revenue to make art. In other words, your contribution makes up 50% of our revenue sources and, as such, we consider you crucial to our play creation. No amount is too small. Please donate!


Other Ways You Can Help

Feel free to let people know about our little campaign. We need your help to spread the word and gather as much support as possible.

CHECK OUT OUR SITE www.lemontreecreations.ca FOR MORE INFORMATION

in a Toronto, today.

Due to the nature of the project the artists involved were required to be in rehearsal for 6 hours, 6 days a week for almost 6 months (spread throughout two years). The art came from their experiences being queer in the city and their full presence was required. However, we are a small and very young non-profit company and our financial resources are limited. As such, most of our money goes into covering rehearsal space and other small production costs. Our artists have yet to be compensated properly for their time, commitment and most importantly for their artistic contribution to this very personal story.

As we move into our presentation at SummerWorks, our team is working hard to offset the production and marketing costs. This way, the revenue generated from the box office can allow us to properly pay our artists. This is where you come in. Your very generous contribution will go directly into covering our production costs. Once this is provided, and if we do surpass our $2000 goal, the funds will amount in generous and well deserved compensation for our artists. As a young company we rely on donations and box office revenue to make art. In other words, your contribution makes up 50% of our revenue sources and, as such, we consider you crucial to our play creation. No amount is too small. Please donate! 


Other Ways You Can HelpFeel free to let people know about our little campaign. We need your help to spread the word and gather as much support as possible. CHECK OUT OUR SITE www.lemontreecreations.ca FOR MORE INFORMATION

story:
About Aleksander and his trip to Australia

Aleksander is a dancer and an aspiring choreographer from Poland. This spring, he has been invited by Erica Sobol and collidEdance Company to visit Australia from mid-April to June, to take part in the "collidEdance Intensive: Australia", 6-weeks training dance program, as well as to perform in collidEdance shows in both Melbourne and Sydney. As CollidEdance's artists and Erica Sobol herself always have been the biggest Alek's inspiration, and their work is something he always looks up to, attending the Australian Intensive program would be a huge challenge, growth opportunity and a dream coming true for him.
 


CollidEdance Intensive: Australia

It is a 6-week long dance training program with Erica Sobol and collidEdance company member Morgan Burke. We intend to spend 3 weeks in Melbourne and 3 weeks in Sydney. Program involves training in conditioning and body awareness, stretching/strengthening, jazz and contemporary technique, partnering, and improvisation. Combination classes will emphasize athleticism, musicality, and style. The intensive will include collidEdance repertory rehearsals as well as new work creation and will conclude with performances in both Melbourne and Sydney. The show, an evening of Erica's finest choreography, will be a celebration of the intensive's creative process, of the dancers' improvement in body and soul, and of the Australia art community. We will invite local musicians, photographers, fashionistas, creators-of-all-sorts to join us. It's goal is to offer the dancers a once-in-lifetime opportunity for challenge, triumph, growth, and learning in an intimate and supportive environmen.


Meet Aleksander

Aleksander has got his very first opportunity of dance training at the age of 17 in Poland, where he is originally from. Ever since, he couldn't think of doing anything else. Dancing, choreographing and teaching shortly took over his entire life. For Alek, dance is all about story telling. His biggest inspiration comes from watching people, their stories, emotions, the way they approach and face life. Expressing feelings through movement and sharing it with other dancers in the studio is truly, his biggest passion. His movement is contemporary based, but he is constantly growing, taking from as many choreographers as possible, with a goal of becoming a versitale and a whole dancer, choreographer, artist, and human.

 

The Reason

In Poland, where Aleksander is from, the lack of a proffessional dance industry makes it nearly impossible to find sponsors willing to support a dancers' growth. Not being associated with any group or a dance company makes it even harder to get your training sponsored. Despite that, Aleksander is taking all the effort needed to gather enough funds and make it to Australia on time. Among other actions, he is currently putting together a fundraiser show in Poland. That's also why this campaign was created. Nevertheless, for now, Aleksander is not able to pay for both his travel and a 6-weeks living in Australia costs.

 

The Goal

The $1700 amount will completely cover the plane fare from Poland to Australia. Achieving the campaign goal will make it possible for Aleksander to be a part of the "collidEdance Intensive: Australia" training program which will be a once-in-a-lifetime event and experience.

We have some amazing incentives and rewards to thank you for your aid in the trip, ranging from signed postcards from Australia, to passes for upcoming dance workshop classes Aleksander will teach in June and July in Los Angeles, CA.

 

The Impact

Alongside being a dancer and a choreographer, Aleksander is a dance teacher. Being part of this experience will give him an amazing opportunity for growth and developement, not only as a dancer, but also as a teacher, an artist and a human being. Using this experience, he hopes to inspire his audience and dance students in both Europe and America more. He aims to spread both the dance art and the life knowledge earned during those 6 weeks in Australia. Among those, this event will help him develop his artistry and dance skills even more, give him another tool to express himself through the art of movement, which has been his biggest dream ever. Most importantly - after attending this program he will become a better qualified instructor and choreographer, which will result in giving his students a bigger challenge and pushing them to grow even more.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

So many of you have already donated your time, emotional support, talent for the polish fundraiser show, and more. If you are unable to assist us with a contribution here you can still help us by spreading the word. Feel free to share links to this page on your personal Facebook and Twitter accounts. Subscribe to Aleksander's youtube channel at the link below to see his choreography and dance work of the past few years - be sure to send the link to your friends! The more we can raise, the better chance we have to meet our goal.

Thank you so much for your time. You and your help are truly appreciated. Hopefully Aleksander will be able to share his trip experience with you soon!

If you want to ask any questions, feel free to contact Aleksander directly at aleksander.palinski@gmail.com

 

youtube: http://youtube.com/aleksanderpalinski

story:
Short Summary

I, Pegah Tabassinejad, am a freelance director and choreographer. I completed a BA in Stage Directing at Tehran’s Art University. I also studied Contemporary Dance and Choreography in Paris at the Conservatoire de la Danse. I am currently researching about the ‘presence’ in theater with focusing on Gilles Deleuze and Gilbert Simondon as I complete my MFA in Interdisciplinary Art at Simon Fraser University. My main areas of interest are experimental theater and contemporary dance. I have directed several pieces, among them ‘Yerma,’ ‘A Doll’s Room,’ and ‘Fake Memories.’ I also created, directed and choreographed ‘Charisma,’ which has been performed in Tehran’s ‘Molavi Hall,’ ‘Dancing on the Edge Festival’ in Holland (a five city tour), and at ‘Push Off 2012’ in Vancouver.

How did the idea for this show come to me? It was a strange feeling, like a sudden storm coming on, a flood of disparate ideas and images, some of which were fairly transparent to me and some of which were rather opaque and mysterious and needed further teasing out. They were like charged particles that started hovering all around me and then colliding against one another with strange violence, and I knew that I needed to somehow rein it all in, to bring it all together into a kind of turbulent chorus--I knew that I could find some kind of deeper meaning there.  

Being from Iran, one of those ideas, perhaps inevitably, had to do with interiors--that is, with those places where we can isolate ourselves from the outside world and feel safe. What was interesting to me, however, was the idea that a person’s identity can still be shaped within her private realm by certain external forces, by (let us call them) windows through which she observes the world and through which she is also being observed (e.g., internet [skype, various social networks, shopping sites, etc.] and television).  What do we make then of a person’s identity? Is anyone unique? Or are we all just cogs in some great machine, carefully observed and controlled from a distance, merely a small part in a homogeneous mass? Or is there a way out?  

To explore some of these questions I decided to adapt Ibsen’s ‘A Doll’s House.’ The piece is not just a conventional staging of the play, but is a combination of theatre, performance art, and visual art. The show lasts fifty hours, with three set theatrical performances taking place between 8PM and 10PM on Oct. 19-21.

What We Need & What You Get

I have been working with a team of fifteen talented collaborators over the course of the past three months to bring this show to life. The show is conceptually complex and will require the use of various technological aids (surveillance cameras, projectors, laptops, and tv monitors). We are also building a mobile glass wall, which will not only serve as a set during the theatrical performance hours, but will be the central feature of an ongoing fifty-hour live installation (a combination of performance art, virtual performance, and visual installation) that will frame the scheduled performances. The cost of setting up such a show is high and since the project thus far has been self-funded we find ourselves in a difficult situation and in need of further funds. We need another $5,000 to properly support the team, secure the technical aids that will be necessary for the show, and complete the building of the set.

The Impact

We believe that this project will be a unique and thought-provoking inquiry into the nature of various forms of surveillance and its effects on our lives. It deals with the shifting nature of public and private life and questions our ideas about the relationships we form through Internet protocol services such as Skype. I explored this idea in a durational piece last April. I brought together actors from all corners of the world via Skype. They performed from their houses and communicated with their partners virtually in the performance space. The performance (which, in a way, was a small-scale test for the current show) was very well received by the public. According to a written survey we conducted with audience members as they left the performance space, they found the piece stimulating and provoking. Our goal with the new piece is to more fully explore these complex issues and create a challenging work. Your contribution would be greatly appreciated! 

Other Ways You Can Help

And even if you are unable to help financially, please help us spread the word about our campaign by sharing it on your facebook, twitter page, etc and/or email it to people who might be interested in helping us. 

 

More Information on the Performance

 

Monitoring [A Doll's House]

Based on Henrik Ibsen’s A Doll’s House


Concept and Direction: Pegah Tabassinejad
Project Counselor: Bojan Bodružić
Stage Manager: Cherry Song
Technical Director: Jonathan Kim
Performers: Angela Ferreira, Aryo Khakpour, Victoria Lyons, Daniel O’Shea, Gina Readman, Natalie Schneck, Benjamin Stone

Dramaturgue: Steve Neufeld
Assistant Director: Nazli Akhtari

Set: Emily Neufeld
Sound: Nancy Tam
Multi-Media: Sammy Chien
Video: Nima Soofi, Bahar Nourizadeh and Bojan Bodružić
Lighting: Jonathan Kim
Costume: Pardis Tabassinejad
October 19-20-21, 2012

Performances @ 8pm @ SFU Woodwards- Second Floor- Studio T
Accompanying a 50 hour live installation between the first and last performance.

story:
Short Summary

Hello,


I am Cuauhtemoc Peranda, MFA, and a choreographer and dancer based in the Bay Area. I am putting on a dance concert at La Peña on Nov. 4th, with some other amazing dance artists, and we need funds to help make this production a reality.

 

The Boy Who Fell From The Sky
 ….a gift from above, a sentiment for creation….
 The Boy Who Fell From The Sky is a collection of small dances set in a large performance event, Mitote. Each dance follows the themes of “struggle, rebirth, and creation,” setting a certain tone of “hope and possibility” for the night of dancing. The inspiration for this concert comes from the Iroquois creation myth of how the earth came into being: “A sky woman falls down, into a world made of water and sky, and upon a turtle’s back she rubs earth and clay, and there the land, the earth was made”. Yet, in the fashion of Mitote, Cuauhtemoc Peranda decided to change the story and make the one who falls from the sky not a woman, not a man, but a boy—full of innocence, magic, and wonder. In following his Aztec name, Cuauhtemoc, meaning “Descending Eagle & The Messenger of The Gods to The People”, he is creating a world of imagination and necessary messages of self-creation and community renewal. And, with works from guest artists Jochelle Pereña, Kristin Torok, and Elizabeth Morales, this performance event, Mitote, creates a mythic space for inspiring creation in all those who are present. A dynamic night of contemporary dance, The Boy Who Fell From The Sky is not a performance to be missed!

 


This is an important campaign because without funds, dances like this cannot happen.  Dances cannot become possible. This Dance Company and concert is about healing, and creativity. We practice in the Native American, Modern, and LGBT dance forms, often unseen, and rarely seen together. 

 

This dance concert will reach a great many populations: The General Dance Community, Berkeley, Oakland, San Francisco Art Lovers, The LGBTQ peoples, Native Peoples, LA RAZA, and the future of dance and arts. Moreover, as concerts are made by Cuauhtemoc Peranda Mitote, the company is empowered to teach more about Mitote, and eventually tour the world--sharing our art with those who need it, and making our communities known and realized as actual people. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Funds will go to: ARTIST FEES, RENTAL OF VENUE, COSTUMES, TRANSPORATION, MARKETING, MUSICAL SCORES, AND LIGHTING OF THE DANCES. Dancers should be paid for their work, and a stipend can only be given if there are funds. Of course there are regular fees for a dance, and most money/ticket sales go to the House/venue-- so in order for an artist to actually be paid for their work, we need your donations. 

As a perk, you can come to our open rehearsals, and at the event come backstage and share a special moment with the artists. Come and meet us after our work, and get to know our process and why we make dance!!

 

The Impact

Funds are needed to realize the actualization of this event, or it cannot happen.  We do not end with the artists performing, but Mitote is spread to the spectator, all their individual worlds, and into the worlds and communities we all inhabit.  Any contribution helps to fuel the power of Cuauhtemoc Peranda Mitote and achieve the goal of this performance. Already, previous works by choreographer Cuauhtemoc Peranda have been recognized, and awarded, as culturally recognizant, respective, and explorative of multiple communities and their identities.  This event is the latest in the strong headway Cuauhtemoc Peranda and these artists are making.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

All performance takes time and energy!  If you or someone you know can contribute costuming materials or construction skills, marketing or print design and supplies, or any other possibly helpful contributions of time, materials, special skills, etc., please let Cuauhtemoc know! And of course, please tell your friends, family, and all your circles of the event, share it on Facebook or whatever social network you're a part of, and absolutely, COME SEE THE ARTISTS!!!

story:
What’s this play about?

Briar Rose & the Thirteenth Fairy tells the classic tale of Sleeping Beauty through the eyes of both the hero and the villain.  Weaving together the narratives of storytelling greats Perrault, Basile, Walt Disney, and The Brothers Grimm, playwright Caroline Angell has re-imagined a very old story for an audience of all ages.  

What happens when you wake up one morning and 100 years has passed you by?  How do you protect the innocence of your children in a world where evil is ever-present?  And what's the best way to keep your Horse's snotty attitude in check?  The universal questions posed by this timeless fairy tale are addressed in a charming, hilarious, and occasionally terrifying manner in this new production, presented by Everyday Inferno.


So, is this a children's show?

Didn't we just say it's for "all ages"? Our play is based on several versions of the Sleeping Beauty fairy tale and explores mature themes that will appeal to an adult audience. It's also very funny and contains puppets, fairies, and a talking fish. Your clever and discerning children will be delighted by it as well.


Who is Everyday Inferno?   

We are a newly-formed New York City theatre company built around a core of collaborating theater artists. Briar Rose & the Thirteenth Fairy will be the company’s first fully staged production and will combine the talents of all four of the company’s current collaborators: Caroline Angell (Playwright), Gina Femia (Creative Consultant), Anais Koivisto (Director), and Katherine Sommer (Producer).   


Do you have a mission statement or something like that so I know what you believe in?   

Well, since you ask… Everyday Inferno is devoted to creating adventurous theatrical productions of both new and classic texts. We seek to exceed the conventional limitations of low-budget theatre by exploring nontraditional spaces, stagecraft, and storytelling. We are committed to developing a diverse audience by producing work that is large in scope while keeping our production costs (and ticket prices) at a minimum.


Seems like you spent a lot of time writing that…

Yes. Yes we did.


What will I actually be paying for?

Producing theatre in New York is an expensive proposition, even for a small fringe company like us. Your donation (whether it’s $1 or $1,000) will go directly toward getting our show up on the stage, with the largest amount going to space rental and to paying the actors and designers involved.   

Your money could pay for:
$10 pays for materials for one shadow puppet  
$20 pays for one hour in a rehearsal studio
$50 pays for three hours of audition space  
$100 pays for materials for two costumes
$500 goes to scenic designer’s fees  
$1000 pays for half of our theater rental   


Should I be excited about this?   

Yes! Absolutely! We think we’re very exciting!   

We are a company firmly committed to high-quality, low cost theatre. We want to provide a lot of bang for your buck. This production will be full of music, magic, comedy, and maybe even some expert juggling (pending casting!). It will definitely be a lot of fun.


I’m not sure I’m convinced. What else can you say to convince me to give you money?

All donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law. Give yourself a break come tax day!


What if I want to give you a different amount of money? Or want to give you money without getting a perk in exchange?

You can give us any amount of money you wish. And you can opt out of the associated perk (although you're still likely to get a "thank you" from us!) by selecting "contribute now" instead of clicking on one of the offered perks. Did you really think we were going to turn down your money?!


I don’t have money to spare, is there another way I can help?   

Money is fantastic but nothing beats word of mouth. Not everyone who is interested in our project has money to contribute – we completely understand that. Want to help in some other way? Get the word out!

Share the link to this page on Facebook or Twitter (check out the helpful "share" buttons at the top of this page- right under the video)! Talk us up to your friends at parties or send an email about us to your rich eccentric great-grand-aunt. However you choose to do it, we deeply appreciate it.
story_txt: What’s this play about?Briar Rose & the Thirteenth Fairy tells the classic tale of Sleeping Beauty through the eyes of both the hero and the villain.  Weaving together the narratives of storytelling greats Perrault, Basile, Walt Disney, and The Brothers Grimm, playwright Caroline Angell has re-imagined a very old story for an audience of all ages.  What happens when you wake up one morning and 100 years has passed you by?  How do you protect the innocence of your children in a world where evil is ever-present?  And what's the best way to keep your Horse's snotty attitude in check?  The universal questions posed by this timeless fairy tale are addressed in a charming, hilarious, and occasionally terrifying manner in this new production, presented by Everyday Inferno.So, is this a children's show?Didn't we just say it's for "all ages"? Our play is based on several versions of the Sleeping Beauty fairy tale and explores mature themes that will appeal to an adult audience. It's also very funny and contains puppets, fairies, and a talking fish. Your clever and discerning children will be delighted by it as well.Who is Everyday Inferno?   We are a newly-formed New York City theatre company built around a core of collaborating theater artists. Briar Rose & the Thirteenth Fairy will be the company’s first fully staged production and will combine the talents of all four of the company’s current collaborators: Caroline Angell (Playwright), Gina Femia (Creative Consultant), Anais Koivisto (Director), and Katherine Sommer (Producer).   Do you have a mission statement or something like that so I know what you believe in?   Well, since you ask… Everyday Inferno is devoted to creating adventurous theatrical productions of both new and classic texts. We seek to exceed the conventional limitations of low-budget theatre by exploring nontraditional spaces, stagecraft, and storytelling. We are committed to developing a diverse audience by producing work that is large in scope while keeping our production costs (and ticket prices) at a minimum.Seems like you spent a lot of time writing that…Yes. Yes we did.What will I actually be paying for?Producing theatre in New York is an expensive proposition, even for a small fringe company like us. Your donation (whether it’s $1 or $1,000) will go directly toward getting our show up on the stage, with the largest amount going to space rental and to paying the actors and designers involved.   Your money could pay for:$10 pays for materials for one shadow puppet  $20 pays for one hour in a rehearsal studio $50 pays for three hours of audition space  $100 pays for materials for two costumes$500 goes to scenic designer’s fees  $1000 pays for half of our theater rental   Should I be excited about this?   Yes! Absolutely! We think we’re very exciting!   We are a company firmly committed to high-quality, low cost theatre. We want to provide a lot of bang for your buck. This production will be full of music, magic, comedy, and maybe even some expert juggling (pending casting!). It will definitely be a lot of fun.I’m not sure I’m convinced. What else can you say to convince me to give you money?All donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law. Give yourself a break come tax day!What if I want to give you a different amount of money? Or want to give you money without getting a perk in exchange?You can give us any amount of money you wish. And you can opt out of the associated perk (although you're still likely to get a "thank you" from us!) by selecting "contribute now" instead of clicking on one of the offered perks. Did you really think we were going to turn down your money?!I don’t have money to spare, is there another way I can help?   Money is fantastic but nothing beats word of mouth. Not everyone who is interested in our project has money to contribute – we completely understand that. Want to help in some other way? Get the word out!Share the link to this page on Facebook or Twitter (check out the helpful "share" buttons at the top of this page- right under the video)! Talk us up to your friends at parties or send an email about us to your rich eccentric great-grand-aunt. However you choose to do it, we deeply appreciate it.

story:
Watch the video for scenes of Sitka and a partial read through of the melodrama.

mel·o·dra·ma  

/ˈmeləˌdrämə/

Noun

1. A sensational dramatic piece with exaggerated characters and exciting events intended to appeal to the emotions.
 

his·to·ry  of  a·las·ka  

/ˈhist(ə)rē/ of /əˈlaskə/

Noun

1.  A sensational dramatic story with exaggerated characters and exciting events that will appeal to the emotions.

Help Sitka, Alaska revitalize Community Theater through a historical, campy melodrama, Paris of the Pacific. 

This request is from the Greater Sitka Arts Council that originated in 1973 and was known for its excellent Community Theater. However over time it waned and then was dormant until 2008. Now Sitka is revitalizing the Community Theater and hopes to stage an audience participation melodrama.

 Sitka, population less than 9,000, is a small island community in Southeast Alaska. Now known as the most historic city in Alaska, Sitka served as the Russian capital of Alaska.  In fact the sale of Alaska from Russia to the United States took place in Sitka in 1867.  At that time, Sitka was known as the Paris of the Pacific due to its rich culture and arts.

Three main threads weave together Sitka’s culture, the Tlingit Native Alaskans who have inhabited the area for over 10,000 years, the Russians who landed in 1799 seeking sea otters for trade, and Americans from the United States following the purchase of Alaska from Russia in 1867.  All three groups are ready to share the stage in Paris of the Pacific.

Why a melodrama? Alaskan, especiallySoutheast Alaskan, history is full of colorful and quirky characters.  What better way to share our rich history than with community melodramas, something Southeast Alaska is known for.  Ketchikan has been offering the same locally written melodrama, Fish Pirates Daughter, for almost thirty years. Its popularity has become almost cult like with impromptu audience participation. It’s still fun for the local audience and for the tourist audience as well.  Juneau had the  Hoochinoo and Hotcakes melodrama also locally written, Skagway offers the Soapy Smith Revue, Haines had Lust for Dust also locally written, and just across the border in Whitehorse, British Columbia has the Gaslight Follies, and Dawson has Diamond Tooth Gertie’s that offers a melodrama.  All these melodramas are based on a smidgen of historical truth with lots of fun stirred in.

Our melodrama, aptly titled, Paris of the Pacific, is also locally written and is about the exchange when the US bought the Alaska territory from Russia in 1867. The Greater Sitka Arts Council has been working for the past several years getting the play written and fine-tuned.  Now, 146 years after The Transfer, we are ready to start production for a 2013 season having our first opening during the Alaska Day Festival that Sitka celebrates every year in October.  Alaska Day is an official state holiday held on October 18 each year. It commemorates the formal transfer of Alaska from Russia to the United States. It might be official statewide but Sitka is the only town that closes the schools and banks and has a parade in the rain. We hold an Alaska Day Ball with period costumes and the Army Big Band comes down for the party from Fairbanks. It is a weeklong event full of fun, music, art, and soon, with your help, a melodrama.

 

Budget items                                                                                 Cost  

Flame retardant muslin for five scene changes                                $1,500

Lumber for constructing mobile support rolled up scenes                    $700

Lumber for construction of mock fishing boat and bar scene               $600

Props  for living room, bar scene,                                                     $600

Lighting Stage Lighting System, Musicanfriend.com                        $1,000

Costumes                                                                                      $600

Total                                                                                          $5,000

story:
Pamela Lourant Flamenco!

 

             HELLO!! Thank you for coming to our Spain fundraising page!!

  I am Pamela Lourant and I have been a flamenco teacher in Santa Barbara, Ca since 2001. I teach group classes, private lesson and choreography. I also have performed on California's biggest and best stages. Currently I am working with LA Opera's production of "CARMEN" with Placido Domingo!!

  My past credits include:

FOX's "ALIAS", "BENISE: NIGHTS OF FIRE!" PBS Special, PLACIDO DOMINGO's "LUISA FERNANDA" and "CARMEN", "PUSS IN BOOTS" Dreamworks, "PASION" Timo Nunez, "ESPANA CLASSICA" Roberto Armaral, "FOREVER FLAMENCO" Deborah Lawler 

 

Sangre Nueva Dance Company

  I created Sangre Nueva Dance Company for the up and coming young flamenco dancers of Santa Barbara that want the opportunity to grow and become professional flamenco artists! These dancers have been taking classes and performing every year since they were as little as THREE YEARS OLD!!

                                     They live for flamenco. It's in their soul!  

  I’ve enjoyed watching them grow from tiny little baby flamencos into up and coming flamenco artists. Through their dedication, abundant energy and discipline they have exceeded all expectations!! Yet.... They want more. They want Spain.

 

 With your contribution, you can give these up and coming young artists an opportunity of a lifetime!!

 

What We Need &

How You Can Help

 

  We are working hard and doing our best to save as much money as possible for this trip. But financial help is needed with expenses.

Here are the details:

1. Roundtrip Flights  (LAX – Madrid) - $992/per person

$992 x 5 people = $4,960

2. RNFE (high speed train roundtrip to Granada) - 120 EUR per person

120 Eruo x 5 people = 600 EUR

3. Accommodations (2 weeks) - 100 EUR per night 

100 Euro x 14 = 1,400 EUR

*** This would be an apartment which allows us to cook at home and will cut down on dining out costs!

4. Class Fees (Carmen de las Cuevas) - 300 EUR per person/per week

300 EUR x 5 x 2 weeks = 3,000 EUR

 

TOTAL: $4,960 + $6,754 (5,000 EUR) = $11,714.00

 Please keep in mind Indiegogo charges a 9.0% fee on the funds we raise. If we reach our goal, we get 5.0% back, for an overall fee of 4.0%

which leaves us with $12,090.

 

 

What You Get!

  For your generous contributions, besides our DEEPEST GRATITUDE, you will receive some of the following perks!!

  Post mailed signed thank you card, signed flyers, brand new 2014 "Noche de Flamenco" signed posters, and a DVD from a future "Noche de Flamenco" concert!!

  Also available are TWO - SIX comp tickets to a future "Noche de Flamenco" show of your choosing, private lessons with Pamela Lourant and private flamenco performances for you and your guests with the entire flamenco company!!

The Impact!

Out of the thousands of flamenco dancers that have taken classes for years in Santa Barbara, sadly very few have traveled to Spain. The dedicated dancers that have are now professionals working all over California, the United States and the world.

**There has never been an organized trip like this before with up and coming artists in all of Santa Barbara! This would be a first! And from this, hopefully more dancers will see that it is possible to travel to Spain and continue their flamenco education.

 

Our Plans After We Return

Children's Creative Project of Santa Barbara

 Recently the company was selected to become part of the Children’s Creative Project of Santa Barbara! Since 1974 the CCP, a non-profit education program provides quality arts experiences for elementary and secondary school students in Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo County! During school assemblies we will give Flamenco “demonstrations” which means explaining the history of flamenco and Spainish culture accompanied with dance segments. They'll get a history lesson and an exciting show all at the same time!

  This provides an opportunity for Sangre Nueva and I to give back to the community and inspire the next generation of young dancers! WE ARE THRILLED!!

 In 2014 "Noche de Flamenco" will begin its second season of authentic flamenco productions all over California! We are driven and filled with excitement to bring a  revamped concert series to audiences!!

 

If We Don’t Reach Our Goal…

Depending on the amount we raise, we will try our best to combine all fundraising efforts from Indiegogo, private shows, teaching classes and personal savings in order to get to Spain!  If we still do not have enough for all 5 people, I will take as many people as I can in order to learn choreographies and come back and teach them to th rest of the company. It is a trip of a lifetime and an experience we won’t forget! Spain is our goal. I want the best for my company and for the ‘Noche de Flamenco’ concert series for the 2014 season! We strive for the best, and the best of the is in Spain!

For more information on Pamela Lourant, Sangre Nueva dancers, video from past performances and photos, please visit:

                            www.PamelaLourantFlamenco.com

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can’t contribute, THAT'S OK but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our Spain campaign!!
  • And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools

 

On behalf of 'Sangre Nueva' and myself, THANK YOU SO MUCH for your time and have an amazing day!!

  This provides an opportunity for Sangre Nueva and I to give back to the community and inspire the next generation of young dancers! WE ARE THRILLED!!

                            www.PamelaLourantFlamenco.com 
 
Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Who We Are

PASADENA DANCE THEATRE  (Non-profit) is composed of elite, classically trained dancers with diverse experiences, backgrounds, and special talents that contribute to the unique tapestry that makes up "The Company".  We are members of our community ranging in age from dynamic, energetic young dancers to seasoned dancers who are respected for their experience and regarded as important members of the company.  Cynthia Young (Ballet West) is Artistic Director and Laurence Blake (The Joffrey Ballet) serves as Associate Artistic Director. 

On October 11, 2014, PASADENA DANCE THEATRE will present an evening of dance entitled "PASSIONmoves".  This live performance will feature a collection of five exciting, new contemporary works created by some of PDT's own talented company members.  "PASSIONmoves", is part of a fundraising effort to support our mission to continue presenting high quality professional performances, bring audiences fresh and innovative choreography, and serve our community through top-notch dance education and outreach programs.

(L-R: Deanna Reeves, Alissa Halpin, Jose Luis Trujillo, Bethana Rosenthal, Evan Rosenblatt, and Ashleigh Doede)

                                                                                           (Photo by Donna Lam)

Your contribution will help us:

  • Support our Conservatory by funding scholarship programs for underprivileged, talented dancers.
  • Reinstate and continue our community outreach program, Dance Mosaic.
  • Assist in the cost of production.

Our Goal

$15,000.00 will help us cover the following:

  • $5,000.00 will go towards scholarships for students in our Conservatory who need financial assistance to cover tuition. 
  • $5,000.00 will help employ PDT company members and bring dance education into the classroom.   
  • $5,000.00 will cover production cost, including and not limited to: artist's fees, rehearsal space, lighting, costumes, sets, advertising/promotion, and other related expenses.

                                                                                  (Photo by Jose Luis Trujillo)

Direct Impact

Our goal of $15,000 will not only support our newest production, "PASSIONmoves" but contribute to our Conservatory of Performing Arts, the official school of Pasadena Dance Theatre. 

Our Conservatory plays a key role in the development of future artists with our Professional Training Program and offers students of all ages, artistic enrichment and opportunities for personal growth and expression.

It will fund outreach programs like Dance Mosaic, a program that offers students the opportunity to learn about dance in a hands-on environment, as well as our Nutcracker outreach, which has brought cultural and educational experiences to more than 6,000 Southern California children. 

With your help we hope to continue and expand this endeavor.


Every Dollar Count$!

DONATE TODAY!  Give now and help us make a difference in our community and for those who are most in need of the arts, our children.  Please help support this special production and endeavor to unite our community through dance, and become part of our PDT family.
We are very excited about our upcoming production and future endeavors and look forward to sharing our artistry with you.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    SPREAD THE WORD!    #passionmoves 

    • Help us make some noise!  Share our campaign with your family and friends.
    • Share it on Facebook, Twitter, Youtube, email, and word of mouth.
    • Attend our performance on October 11, 2014 at 7:30PM at our Studio Theater at 1985 E. Locust Street, Pasadena, CA 91107.  Call (626) 683-3459 for more information.
    • Come dance with us!   
    • Log on to PasadenaDance.org to learn more about us.
    Pasadena Dance Theatre is a non—profit 501(c)(3) educational corporation and is completely self-supporting, with expenses being met through ticket sales, fundraising efforts, grants, memberships, tuition, class fees and donations, in concert with the support of its volunteer organization, Assemblée. In addition, PDT also holds several annual membership drives.
    We welcome your help and support!

Help us make some noise!  Share our campaign with your family and friends.
Share it on Facebook, Twitter, Youtube, email, and word of mouth.
Attend our performance on October 11, 2014 at 7:30PM at our Studio Theater at 1985 E. Locust Street, Pasadena, CA 91107.  Call (626) 683-3459 for more information.
 Come dance with us!   
Log on to PasadenaDance.org to learn more about us. 

Pasadena Dance Theatre is a non—profit 501(c)(3) educational corporation and is completely self-supporting, with expenses being met through ticket sales, fundraising efforts, grants, memberships, tuition, class fees and donations, in concert with the support of its volunteer organization, Assemblée. In addition, PDT also holds several annual membership drives.

We welcome your help and support!

story:
Ottawa Dance Directive (ODD)

ODD has sparked a fresh start in Ottawa for contemporary minded dance artists. Currently in its fourth year of operations, ODD is gaining ground with four distinct streams of programming: 

  • Compagnie ODD (resident performance company); 
  • Series Dance 10 (professional presentation series); 
  • resource sharing and exchange; 
  • professional development and residency opportunities. 

Ottawa Dance Directive was created by four like–minded contemporary dance artists from the Ottawa/Gatineau region: Natasha Bakht, Yvonne Coutts, Sylvie Desrosiers, and Lana Morton. Each one of these women has proven her artistic merit as an independent dance artist through sustained years of activity, rigorous commitment to the form, and recognition for artistic excellence.

ODD’s programming nourishes the local community while intersecting with the provincial and national dance milieu. The vision reflects the founding members’ twenty-eight years of professional dance activity in Canada.


WHAT ODD DOES

ODD’s vision is to provide multi-dimensional tiers of programming that work together to build a platform for dance art practice, creation, professional development, resource sharing, and presentation.

Compagnie ODD

http://vimeo.com/44924641

Compagnie ODD was commissioned by the Canada Dance Festival in 2012 at the NAC Studio with works by Tedd Robinson and Yvonne Coutts (the most sold show in the 2012 CDF!).  The evening has been presented in Peterborough and Toronto and will be shown at the 2014 Dancing on the Edge Festival in Vancouver with new work by guest Noam Gagnon. 

Series Dance 10 / SD10

SD10 has presented a diverse group of national and international artists: Marc Boivin, Brian Webb, Kate Hilliard, Cathy Kyle Fenton, Ireni Stamou, Annie De Pauw/Échine DO, Heather MacDonald, Julie Anne Ryan (Deborah Hay), Marilou Lépine,Yvon Soglo AKA Crazy Smooth, Noam Gagnon, Meagan O'Shea (Stand Up Dance), Claudia Moore and Dan Wild (Tedd Robinson, James Kudelka), Collective (gulp) Dance Projects, Sonia St-Michel, Simon Renaud, Susie Burpee, Linnea Swan, Ame Henderson, Matja Ferlin (Croatia), Paul-André Fortier, Robyn Poitras, Heidi Strauss, Laura Taler, and Clement Layes (Berlin), and in May 2014 Caroline Barrière. 

Seasons 2014-15 and 2015-16 will feature Sarah Williams, Dorsale Danse, Laurence Lemieux, Natasha Bakht, Jennifer Dallas, Bienevue Bazie, Jeff Hall, Emmanuel Joethe, and Peggy Baker Dance Projects.

  

Residencies

There have been 35 weeks of residencies given to artists since August 2010. ODD has also given extended residencies to local companies, Bboyizm and Propeller Dance. Visiting artist residencies have included Helen Husak (Calgary), Lori Duncan, Rob Abubo (Toronto), Simon Renaud (Toronto), Shannon Cooney (Berlin) and in 2014, The Good Women Collective (Edmonton).

Services and Professional Development

ODD has managed its subsidized rentals to a capacity of 90% since 2010 with over 75 groups and artists gaining access.  

Lasting Impact

ODD has designed a hybrid structure to fulfill several needs within the community. It is a holistic view of development and resource exchange at moment when our economic situation is demanding cohesive action. It is responsive, inclusive, and proactive.  

ODD’s principle force is the steadfast belief that we can work together as a community while maintaining and respecting individual mandates. 


WHERE DO YOUR FUNDS GO?

OPERATIONS IS THE PROJECT is targeting all activities programmed by ODD.

Your support enables ODD to continue to provide employment and opportunity to a wide range of dance artists from Ottawa / Gatineau and beyond. 


SPECIFIC PROGRAMS

Your support will directly fund the May creation project for Compagnie ODD.  This includes fees for five dancers, guest emerging choreographer Andrew Turner, and guest composer David Drury. The performances will be in ODD is OFF, June 2014.

Your support will allow Compagnie ODD to complete its first presentation out of province at Dancing on The Edge in Vancouver in July 2014 with works by artistic director, Yvonne Coutts, and choreographers, Tedd Robinson and Noam Gagnon.

Your support will give ODD the ability to present its next SD10 event District O featuring Ottawa choreographer Caroline Barrière.

Your support will help fund the two key staff positions, the artistic director / general manager and associate director / production manager.

Your support will enable ODD to continue to provide access to the beautiful studios and ODD BOX venue at artist affordable rates.


PLEASE HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

There are many ways to help support Ottawa Dance Directive... 

  • spread the word about the "OPERATIONS IS THE PROJECT" campaign
  • attend a performance of Series Dance 10 in May 2014
  • attend a performance by Compagnie ODD in June 2014
  • become a Season sponsor
  • volunteer
  • dance!

www.odd-cdc.org

Pitch Video by Ben Walker

THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING ODD: OPERATIONS IS THE PROJECT!

story:
ABOUT THE LOST //

The Lost (or, How to: Just Be) is a coming-of-age dramedy about a bright Harlem teen named Bobby, who is thrust out of his comfort zone and forced to deal with new surroundings and new desires. The Lost incorporates elements of rap, spoken word and hip hop dance to tell Bobby’s story and create an honest, sincere portrayal of life as an urban youth today.

Our play focuses on inner-city teens and the all-too-real challenges they face daily, including social inequality, LGBTQ issues, and the foster care system, to name a few. Not only are we depicting a segment of the population that is underrepresented in theater, the team behind The Lost is reaching out to the very people who inspired the play: the youth. We're partnering with The CityKids Foundation, an organization that provides arts education to underserved kids, to expose their students to the world of professional theater and the powerful work that can come from it. In addition to our outreach with CityKids, a portion of the proceeds from ticket sales of The Lost will benefit GLAAD.

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES // 

Producing for theater is not cheap. Your generosity will help subsidize out-of-pocket expenses for:

  • Rehearsal studios, which can cost upward of $45/hour
  • Printing materials, including 180-page scripts for 15 company members, 1000+ promotional postcards, 100+ posters, etc.
  • Stipends for nine professional actors & one professional stage manager
  • Costumes & wardrobe for a cast of nine
  • ...and so much more

THE CAST //

THE CREATIVE TEAM //


THE VENUE //

Artistic Director Tom Noonan founded the Paradise Factory in 1983, as a center for theater and film development.  Tom received the Guggenheim Fellowship in Filmmaking in 1998, and wrote & directed the Sundance Grand Jury prize-winning “What Happened Was…” (1994).  His personal method of creating new works, which he developed over thirty years as an actor, utilizes the theater as an incubator for the cinematic form. 

The building at 64 East 4th Street was once “The Paradise Ice Cream Factory” – where the ice cream cone was invented, in the 1920s.  The building then became a hat factory during the industrial revolution, which then perished in a fire.  The condemned building was unoccupied thereafter, until Tom Noonan and Jack Kruger built a theater, rehearsal rooms, and breathed life back into the building.  Years later the City of New York and Borough President Scott Stringer would award a grant of five million dollars toward the total renovation of 64E4. 

HONORARY BOARD at the Paradise Factory includes Christopher Walken, Sean Penn, Susan Sarandon and Wallace Shawn.

THE FESTIVAL //

The Planet Connections Theatre Festivity is New York’s premiere eco-friendly and socially-conscious arts festival. Fostering a diverse cross-section of performances, the Festivity seeks to inspire artists and audiences, both creatively and fundamentally, in a festive atmosphere. At the heart of the Festivity are like-minded individuals  creating theatre, film, music and art, all while supporting organizations that give back to the community at large.

story:
Classics on the Rocks is a classical theatre company based in NYC. After a successful inaugural season in 2013 with two staged readings we're branching out to produce our first fully staged production - and we need your help!

To the right you'll see various perks for our benefactors - each level has been lovingly named after one the bards best boozy characters. Take a look... will you be The Porter, Trinculo & Stefano, Sir Toby Belch & Sir Andrew Aguecheek, Nick Bottom, or the most boozy of them all Sir John Falstaff?

New to Classics on the Rocks? Here's what we're all about....

What makes a whiskey good? It's a spirit that stands alone in its simplicity. An elixir carefully crafted to be sweet and smoky within the same sip. A drink that delights and is different for each taster. Something to be shared, savored, and served simply… on the rocks.

What makes a classic good? A story that withstands the tests of time - that stands alone in its universality. Engaging characters that you love and hate sometimes within the same breath. An experience that delights and is different for each audience member. Something to be shared, savored, and served simply…on the rocks.

At Classics on the Rocks we believe that classical theatre is special.  The words, the language, and characters have lasted centuries, and for a good reason. While you may not always be able to put your finger on what makes it a classic (like a fine dram of whiskey) you just know that on some level it resonates within you as though it was made just for you.

As storytellers, our goal is to share the story with you, and to do so as simply as possible. We focus on the words and characters eliminating fluff, filler, or exotic concepts. Through our live stage productions and class workshops we strive to explore the classics with you in a fun, engaging, and interactive way.  It’s classical theatre you can understand. It’s classics served simply…on the rocks.

Classics on the Rocks launched successfully in 2013 with a dream and mission – to share our love for classical theatre, romantic language, quirky ingénues, and crazy clowns with the masses. We found a receptive audience here in NYC in our inaugural year, in which we self-produced two staged readings in our signature no-frills fashion with great success. Having spent much time refining our company’s mission and goals we are now ready and excited to take the next step forward to producing a fully staged production of As You Like It in July 2014 - and we need your help!

Being an independent theatre company in New York, offers all sorts of challenges ranging from finding ways to stand out and attract an audience to finding a performance space that offers the proper atmosphere. And naturally, this all comes with a price - even the most modest of performance and rehearsal spaces cost upwards of $3,000. 

This is why we need your support. All donations will go directly towards our production of As You Like It - rehearsal and performance space, costumes, and prop pieces. Our goal is to see As You Like It in turn fund the next production and onwards - so you will be able to see your initial donation pay-it-forward with every future show. 

We have been accepted as a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts services organization that helps independent artists like our company cut through the red tape of non-profit paperwork and focus on creating. This partnership gives us the perfect foundation to stand upon and now it is time to get to work growing our community and gathering the support we need to move forward.

With your generous tax-deductible donation, together, we can share the intimacy of classical theatre, witness first hand the magic and power of face to face theatrical communication, and build a lasting community of actors, artists and lovers of theatre. (and have some fun sipping fine spirits and talking Shakespeare together too).

And when you support us today - you'll get some fun perks too...

Will you join us and our group of lovable fools, quirky ingenues, and crazy clowns? Take a look to the right and see which boozy character of the bards you are!


Thank you for being a part of our community!
