story:
TERRA FIRMA DANCE THEATRE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT!


Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT)  kindly invites your support and contributions  in reaching our objective of $5000, to assist us during our April 27th-May 3rd residency and performances at the prestigious Kaatsbaan International Dance Center, and beyond.....

Please take a moment to read on, and help us to meet (or exceed) our goal!

Your support is critical in fulfilling our mission objectives.....EVERY amount helps.

A Coveted Kaatsbaan Residency

During the week of April 27-May 3rd, the company has been invited to work, in residency and develop a new creation by Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway. The new work, entitled, "Mockingbird", features the high-octance physicality and ardent flair for which the company has become known. We are looking forward to the continued development of this important addition to our repertory as we assume our residency in late-April 2014.

In addition to this new and exciting work, TFDT will also showcase Loungway’s “Stagioni” (literal translation to “Seasons”), an original and evocative deconstruction, featuring Max Richter's recomposed version of Vivaldi’s masterpiece, “Four Seasons.”  Featuring 10 top-notch artists, Loungway creates an eclectic account of a new universe painted with texture and intricacy. "Stagioni", also features original costumes, created by TFDT dancer, Gabby Grywalski. 

Performances are open to the public and we sincerely hope you will join us.....

Kaatsbaan, an international center dedicated to preserving and developing professional dance, was founded by Gregory Cary, Kevin McKenzie, Bentley Roton and Martine Van Hamel.  They host a variety of programs to fulfill their mission and have developed a considerable reputation in presenting quality dance and dance-makers.  The Kaatsbaan Choreographic Residency, a hallmark of the program and host for companies such as The Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburgh, Limón Dance Company, and Doug Varone & Dancers, has awarded the 2014 residency to Terra Firma Dance Theater.  We are pleased to join the ranks of these innovators in the dance world and look forward to traveling to Tivoli, NY for an experience treasured by those before us. 

Your support will enable us to provide no-cost to low-cost tickets to underserved audiences to our upcoming performances; remunerate world-class dancers and choreographers that are featured in our season; deepen, broaden and diversify our community outreach efforts;programming and expand our arts-education programs.  Kindly consider supporting Terra Firma Dance Theatre, and know that your contribution assists in ensuring arts-accessibility and programming that is of the highest caliber.  All contributions are tax-deductible, and we extend the utmost gratitude.

Read on, to learn more about TFDT and some of the perks that you can receive, including private lesson in dance or Pilates, exclusive social gatherings, and recognition of your support of our organization.



WHY YOUR SUPPORT MATTERS

Thanks to your past valued support in 2013, we were able to create a solid foundation that will serve as a springboard as we continue to fulfill our mission objectives in providing affordable and accessible dance of high-artistic merit. 

To share a small sampling of what your past support has enabled:

-We successfully met our fund-raising goals; presenting a full-Spring season featuring the work of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway; former Cedar Lake dancer, Manuel Vignoulle; and recent Princess Grace-fellowship recipient Loni Landon

-Traveled to Poland, by invitation, to perform at Krakow Nights...an annual arts festival

-Shared the stage with stars of NYCB and ABT in relief efforts for the Philippines, coordinated by Ashley Bouder-NYCB principal

....and much much more

 In expanding the breadth of our activities during the 2014/15 season we are excited to announce we have been selected, out of a highly competitive field, to receive the 2014 Kaatsbaan UpStream Choreographic Residency Award.  The week-long residency provides us with the time and space to create a new work and will culminate in a showcase performance at the Kaatsbaan Studio Theater.  We invite your support as we undertake this rare and treasured opportunity to immerse ourselves fully in the creation of a new work, and utilize it as a catalyst to expand our ambitious programming and objectives for the following season.


TO LEARN MORE ABOUT TERRA FIRMA DANCE, please visit www.tfdance.org 



·      

About Terra Firma Dance Theater

 Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT), under the guidance of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway, serves as a cultural think-tank for the dance landscape of New York. We promote an environment that cultivates dialogue and the exchange of creative ideas as exemplified through our dance performance, educational outreach and experimental theater initiatives. Our primary focal points are underserved populations and non-traditional theatergoers in order to introduce them to the power of the arts as a life changing force. As a rapidly rising contemporary ballet company, the core of our work focuses on movement as the primary language of basic human interaction and communion.

In promoting a risk-free environment of diversity, TFDT emphasizes the value of dance as a medium to enrich, empower and engage all members of the community via its high-quality, accessible and affordable programming.

As vanguard caretakers of the art form of ballet, we actively seek to promote new audiences and heighten their awareness and willingness to move away from “traditional and typical dance models”. With a responsible eye to the future of ballet, we work to provide a progressive and contemporary experience, with the understanding that ballet will not look as it once has.

The interwoven philosophical, societal and political issues of the 18th and 19th centuries, that once informed and governed the creation and understanding of new dance work and art in general, no longer exist. It is with this notion in mind that we embark upon our mission to present a new and viable model that preserves ballet as a current and relevant art form, which carries the potential to provide a deep and long lasting impact upon its audience members

 

Terra Firma Dance Theater is comprised of 10 high caliber dancers: Izabela Szylinska (formerly of Polish National Ballet), Lester Badenoch (former dancer w/ Atlanta Ballet, American Repertory Ballet, North Carolina Dance Theatre), Tiffany Mangulabnan (current soloist, Ballet Next; former Principal- Philippine Ballet Theatre); Gabby Grywalski (Pittsburgh Ballet); Lukasz Zieba (freelance dancer, Poland, Ailey School professional-track aspirant); Jessica Miller (recent SUNY Purchase graduate), Max Capelli-King (Peridance Contemporary Dance Company, Limon Dance Company); and Courtney Liu (recent Duke graduate), Mara Driscoll (NYU-Gallatin graduate); Lily Balogh (current soloist, Ballet Next, formerly of NYCB)

The company has steadily increased in its capacity with the generous support of the Geraldine Dodge Foundation; New Jersey State Council for the Arts; Hyde and Watson....and supporters such as YOU!

 

About the Director

Stuart Loungway is the Founder/Artistic Director of Terra Firma Dance Theatre. His training began with Tania Lichine, Irina Jacobson, and John Clifford before receiving a full scholarship to the prestigious School of American Ballet. He began his professional career performing with the Houston Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, before joining San Francisco Ballet Company and continuing as a Principal Dancer with American Repertory Ballet. He has performed soloist and principal roles in work by David Bintley, James Kudelka, George Balanchine, William Forsythe, Mark Morris, and many others. Mr. Loungway maintains an active schedule as a master teacher, choreographer, performer, and served on the dance faculty at Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University. Selected as “Who’s Hot” by National Dance Critics Association Chair Karyn Collins, Mr. Loungway’s choreography, as expressed by Robert Johnson of Dance Europe, is “elegant and evocative” and “bodes well for the future of dance.” His work and company have been featured in the national dance publication Pointe Magazine.


His work has been featured at Ballet Builders/New Choreographers on Pointe. He is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company teacher for Ballet Hispanico.
story_txt:
TERRA FIRMA DANCE THEATRE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT!Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT)  kindly invites your support and contributions  in reaching our objective of $5000, to assist us during our April 27th-May 3rd residency and performances at the prestigious Kaatsbaan International Dance Center, and beyond.....Please take a moment to read on, and help us to meet (or exceed) our goal!
Your support is critical in fulfilling our mission objectives.....EVERY amount helps.A Coveted Kaatsbaan ResidencyDuring the week of April 27-May 3rd, the company has been invited to work, in residency and develop a new creation by Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway. The new work, entitled, "Mockingbird", features the high-octance physicality and ardent flair for which the company has become known. We are looking forward to the continued development of this important addition to our repertory as we assume our residency in late-April 2014.In addition to this new and exciting work, TFDT will also showcase Loungway’s “Stagioni” (literal translation to “Seasons”), an original and evocative deconstruction, featuring Max Richter's recomposed version of Vivaldi’s masterpiece, “Four Seasons.”  Featuring 10 top-notch artists, Loungway creates an eclectic account of a new universe painted with texture and intricacy. "Stagioni", also features original costumes, created by TFDT dancer, Gabby Grywalski. Performances are open to the public and we sincerely hope you will join us.....Kaatsbaan, an international center dedicated to preserving and developing professional dance, was founded by Gregory Cary, Kevin McKenzie, Bentley Roton and Martine Van Hamel.  They host a variety of programs to fulfill their mission and have developed a considerable reputation in presenting quality dance and dance-makers.  The Kaatsbaan Choreographic Residency, a hallmark of the program and host for companies such as The Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburgh, Limón Dance Company, and Doug Varone & Dancers, has awarded the 2014 residency to Terra Firma Dance Theater.  We are pleased to join the ranks of these innovators in the dance world and look forward to traveling to Tivoli, NY for an experience treasured by those before us. Your support will enable us to provide no-cost
to low-cost tickets to underserved audiences to our upcoming performances;
remunerate world-class dancers and choreographers that are featured in our
season; deepen, broaden and diversify our community outreach efforts;programming and expand
our arts-education programs.  Kindly consider supporting Terra Firma
Dance Theatre, and know that your contribution assists in ensuring
arts-accessibility and programming that is of the highest caliber.  All
contributions are tax-deductible, and we extend the utmost gratitude.
Read on, to learn more about TFDT and some of the perks that you
can receive, including private lesson in dance or Pilates, exclusive social
gatherings, and recognition of your support of our organization.
WHY YOUR SUPPORT MATTERSThanks to your past valued support in 2013, we were able to create a solid foundation that will serve as a springboard as we continue to fulfill our mission objectives in providing affordable and accessible dance of high-artistic merit. To share a small sampling of what your past support has enabled:-We successfully met our fund-raising goals; presenting a full-Spring season featuring the work of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway; former Cedar Lake dancer, Manuel Vignoulle; and recent Princess Grace-fellowship recipient Loni Landon-Traveled to Poland, by invitation, to perform at Krakow Nights...an annual arts festival-Shared the stage with stars of NYCB and ABT in relief efforts for the Philippines, coordinated by Ashley Bouder-NYCB principal....and much much more In expanding the breadth of our activities during the 2014/15 season we are excited to announce we have been selected, out of a highly competitive field, to receive the 2014 Kaatsbaan UpStream Choreographic Residency Award.  The week-long residency provides us with the time and space to create a new work and will culminate in a showcase performance at the Kaatsbaan Studio Theater.  We invite your support as we undertake this rare and treasured opportunity to immerse ourselves fully in the creation of a new work, and utilize it as a catalyst to expand our ambitious programming and objectives for the following season.TO LEARN MORE ABOUT TERRA FIRMA DANCE, please visit www.tfdance.org 
·      
About Terra Firma Dance Theater
 Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT), under the guidance of
Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway, serves as a cultural think-tank for the
dance landscape of New York. We promote an environment that cultivates dialogue
and the exchange of creative ideas as exemplified through our dance
performance, educational outreach and experimental theater initiatives. Our
primary focal points are underserved populations and non-traditional
theatergoers in order to introduce them to the power of the arts as a life
changing force. As a rapidly rising contemporary ballet company, the core of
our work focuses on movement as the primary language of basic human interaction
and communion.
In promoting a risk-free environment of diversity, TFDT emphasizes
the value of dance as a medium to enrich, empower and engage all members of the
community via its high-quality, accessible and affordable programming.
As vanguard caretakers of the art form of ballet, we actively
seek to promote new audiences and heighten their awareness and willingness to
move away from “traditional and typical dance models”. With a responsible eye
to the future of ballet, we work to provide a progressive and contemporary
experience, with the understanding that ballet will not look as it once has.
The interwoven philosophical, societal and political issues of
the 18th and 19th centuries, that once informed and governed the creation and
understanding of new dance work and art in general, no longer exist. It is with
this notion in mind that we embark upon our mission to present a new and viable
model that preserves ballet as a current and relevant art form, which carries
the potential to provide a deep and long lasting impact upon its audience
members
 
Terra Firma Dance Theater is comprised of 10 high caliber
dancers: Izabela Szylinska (formerly of Polish National Ballet), Lester
Badenoch (former dancer w/ Atlanta Ballet, American Repertory Ballet, North
Carolina Dance Theatre), Tiffany Mangulabnan (current soloist, Ballet Next;
former Principal- Philippine Ballet Theatre); Gabby Grywalski (Pittsburgh
Ballet); Lukasz Zieba (freelance dancer, Poland, Ailey School
professional-track aspirant); Jessica Miller (recent SUNY Purchase graduate), Max Capelli-King (Peridance
Contemporary Dance Company, Limon Dance Company); and Courtney Liu (recent Duke graduate), Mara Driscoll (NYU-Gallatin graduate); Lily Balogh (current soloist, Ballet Next, formerly of NYCB)The company has steadily increased in its capacity with the generous support of the Geraldine Dodge Foundation; New Jersey State Council for the Arts; Hyde and Watson....and supporters such as YOU!
 
About the DirectorStuart Loungway is the Founder/Artistic Director of Terra Firma Dance
Theatre. His training began with Tania Lichine, Irina Jacobson, and John
Clifford before receiving a full scholarship to the prestigious School of
American Ballet. He began his professional career performing with the Houston
Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, before joining San Francisco Ballet Company and
continuing as a Principal Dancer with American Repertory Ballet. He has
performed soloist and principal roles in work by David Bintley, James Kudelka,
George Balanchine, William Forsythe, Mark Morris, and many others. Mr. Loungway
maintains an active schedule as a master teacher, choreographer, performer, and
served on the dance faculty at Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers
University. Selected as “Who’s Hot” by National Dance Critics Association Chair
Karyn Collins, Mr. Loungway’s choreography, as expressed by Robert Johnson of
Dance Europe, is “elegant and evocative” and “bodes well for the future of
dance.” His work and company have been featured in the national dance
publication Pointe Magazine.

His work has been featured at Ballet Builders/New Choreographers on Pointe. He
is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the
New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for
the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He
has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales
University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY
PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as
a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching
ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and
company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the
faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous
advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company
teacher for Ballet Hispanico.

story:
Hello!

We’re Mika and Randi. We are puppeteers and drama teachers based in Victoria and Vancouver, BC, and we perform and teach fun, interactive puppetry for kids and adults. We have been accepted into the puppet theatre intensive at The Banff Centre in Alberta. This program will teach us the skills necessary to build our own puppets and create more inventive and exciting stories for you. But we need your help!

We need to raise $4,000 to cover the cost of tuition, accommodation, and travel or we won’t be able to attend this amazing puppetry intensive. We are turning to you to ask for contributions. In exchange, we’re offering personalized thank you songs sung by our puppet pals, felt hand puppets designed to look like you or your friends, or a place in a puppetry workshop held in Vancouver in February. Your contribution will help us attend an amazing program taught by some of our puppetry idols, and further, it will help us spread the fine art of puppetry and storytelling to young people and adults all over BC!

Check out the program here: http://www.banffcentre.ca/programs/program.aspx?id=1383&p=requirements

If you live outside of Canada and would like a Personalized Puppet perk, please add $5 CAN to your donation to cover the cost of shipping.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially? Here's how you can help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, by word of mouth, or carrier pigeon!

THANK YOU!

story:
LAB's A Chance to Dance

Los Angeles Ballet needs an iPad to help coordinate the expansion of their outreach program. We at Chaspen Foundation for the Arts (ChaspenArts.org) are committed to helping them get it! A mere $600 would cover a mid-range iPad. Should we fail to raise the whole amount, all proceeds raised would still go to LAB, as a grant earmarked toward the purchase of a tablet. All proceeds in excess of $600 will go toward a second grant, to help fund LAB's "A Chance to Dance" for the 2013-14 season.

What is "A Chance to Dance?"

One Sunday each month during every season, the dancers of Los Angeles Ballet offer monthly FREE ballet, jazz, hip-hop, alternative dance/fitness classes, and lectures/demonstrations for all ages. Healthy beverages and snacks are provided free of charge by local businesses. Daycare is also FREE, with art materials provided by Blick Art Room Aid, to enable parents who wish to take the classes. 

For over 8 years, LAB sought to establish "A Chance to Dance," finally proceeding with the program last year - UNFUNDED - to serve low-income children, families, seniors, and veterans. Founded and helmed by Los Angeles Ballet Principal Ballerina Allynne Noelle and supported whole-heartedly by the dancers of LAB, the community outreach initiative began last year at the Los Angeles Ballet Center in West LA, with nearly 200 people of all ages accessing the monthly free classes. This year, on a shoestring budget, LAB expanded the program into Hope Street Family Center in South-Central LA.

Classes at both locations encompass Creative Movement for Ages 3-6, Pilates Mat Class (all ages), Introduction to Ballet (all ages), Mommy & Me (infant-2), Adult Beginning Ballet, Adult Advanced Ballet, Kids/Teen Master Class (7-13), Horton Technique, Jazz, Hip-hop, Caribbean Dance, Yoga, Hula Hoop, and more. 

LAB dancers participating in the program have included Principal Dancers Allynne Noelle, Allyssa Bross, Christopher Revels; Soloists Chelsea Paige Johnston, Alex Castillo, Bianca Bulle, Julia Cinquemani; and most of LAB's Company Dancers, as well as LAB Physical Therapist Susanne Thom. 

In order to coordinate the expansion of classes with additional teachers and a vast influx of students in two locations, the program desperately needs an iPad for the Chance to Dance Associate Administrator. It would also be a great benefit for photos and archival video, which would help LAB to prepare grant proposals to fully fund the project.

Even if you can't contribute, please get the word out! Tell your friends! Share this message with your email list and on your Facebook page! Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Please see "A Chance to Dance" on Facebook for additional information.

story:
In order to see the entire campaign, be sure to scroll all the way down.

- Who We Are  

We are Hellzapoppin Circus Sideshow Revue, an authentic variety show with an edgy rock n roll twist. One night at the foot of our stage could change your life, tickle your deepest curiosities, and make you consider running away with us. This show will bring you an addicting elixir of vaudeville entertainment, death defying stunts, and bewilderment. But we are much more than a stop on the map. For each mile we travel, a heart is touched, a mind opened, and a memory made. We are a family that is thick as thieves, passionate about our work, and loyal to our trade. Hellzapoppin contains artists of all walks of life that jump on stage night after night using their bodies as props and will continue to put themselves through hell to entertain and challenge even the jaded  who think they've seen everything.  It's Hellzapoppin's job to prove them wrong and show them they've seen nothing yet!

-Why This Matters

Carrying on a valuable piece of Americana, the contents of our bus matter in so many ways. With every town we visit, we make sure to immerse ourselves in the local culture, learn about people as individuals and become the very fabric that connects us as human beings. So many amazing stories and experiences have been passed on through the plight of our fans by our very own lips. Hellzapoppin is a movement, a culture, a change, a brand of entertainment and community that is bringing back a forgotten and beautiful lost art. Hellzapoppin performers are the few that represent the many that have felt different, forgotten or misunderstood. We look to entertain, educate, and offer a platform for unheard voices.

-Why You Matter

We know that not everyone can quit their jobs, and walk away from their responsibilities to join this menagerie.  But what we do know, is that we can offer up the chance for you personally to be a part of this incredible creation.  We travel on a beaten down, dated, and heavily used former prison bus.  Not only does it get us from gig to gig, but it is our home.  It’s where we live, eat, work and sleep.  Without it, Hellzapoppin would be no more, and would take with it a very unique piece of history.  With your help, we will be able to make the necessary repairs to this bus.  This will keep us on the road, and our movement breathing.  You will become the beds that we rest our beaten bodies on, the engine that drives us, and the vessel that carries our art from place to place.  We believe in humanity, and community.  We believe in paying it forward, and being living proof that charity and a passion for the arts is necessary for existence.

-What We Need

Hellzapoppin is looking to raise $13,000.00. The proceeds will go to bus repairs. If we are to exceed our donations, we hope to purchase a new bus. Your contribution is TAX DEDUCTIBLE!

-How You Benefit

Aside from the great perks found on the right side of this page.  You'll be a recognized advocate for independent arts.  Your name will be listed as a supporter on www.hellzapoppin.com under the advocates page!

-What Happens If We Don't Meet Our Goal

In the event that Hellzapoppin does not reach the goal, we will use the funds for as many bus parts we can get. We'll push on and work as hard as we possibly can to keep going.

-Our Place In The World

Hellzapoppin was a dream that became a reality in a staggeringly short amount of time. The owner/creator, Bryce “the Govna” Graves saw his first freak show back in 2004. From that moment on, he would be destined for center stage. Like most people, he had/has responsibilities and a stable life. But for some, out of that stability, a stagnant boredom appears.  Each and every one of us has had this moment, this strike of emotion and inspiration, that has made us want to wipe the slate clean and begin anew. But for some, it seems impossible. There’s a belief that mediocrity is the only place that is safe from ridicule. For some, the risk is worth the ridicule. Hellzapoppin is a direct representation of doing what you love, and doing it the only way you know how. Without this outfit, so many lives would be impacted. We aren't just performers, we are a living breathing extension of sideshow and what we do. Not everyone can swallow swords, stick drills in their faces, or be a half-man… But everyone can be a fan, a believer, a supporter and a lover of the arts.

-Pay It Forward

 Kicking off the 2013 tour, out of nowhere our transmission blew. Our next paying gig was across the country and we were stranded in a dead zone. Without a penny to our names, and no way of continuing on, we thought the tour was done. But with donations from over one hundred fans, we were able to replace our blown transmission with a new transmission (with a two year warranty included). In doing so, we were not only able to get back on the road, but keep the 2013 tour going until the very bitter sweet end. With your donations, once again, Hellzapoppin will be brought back to life. If our goal is reached, our fans will be rewarded with our permanence in this world, and the continuation of this traditional art. 

-Other Ways You Can Help

We certainly understand not having the financial means to donate. HOWEVER, there are other ways to contribute!  Simply use the Indiegogo share tools, and share our campaign on all your social media outlets.  Word of mouth is just as valuable, so if you can share daily until the campaign is over!  Spread the good word and download our press releases, blurbs and posters from our website and hang them all around town, scream it out loud, tell your friends, tell your family, tell your co-workers and help  us get the word out there!  You can download promo materials here: http://www.hellzapoppin.com/join.html.

If you'd like to donate but can't at the moment and would like to receive reminder notifications, please email bryce(at)hellzapoppin(dot)com.

(here's a look inside the mystery prison bus)

For more information about Hellzapoppin Circus SideShow Revue check out www.hellzapoppin.com.

story:
About Bad Seed:
Bad Seed is a theatre company dedicated to a singular concept in the Atlanta artistic scene: To produce consistently thought-provoking and question-raising theatre.  

Our goal is to make audiences contemplate all aspects of life, from the blatantly political to the extremely personal.  If our audiences leave our shows discussing and questioning what they have seen, our mission will have been achieved.

Debut Productions:
Our debut productions will be Closer, by Patrick Marber and Sexual Perversity in Chicago by David Mamet.  Both of these plays delve into the interrelations of four emotionally damaged people. To make matters more interesting, the productions will be in repertory with the same four actors appearing in both plays. These challenging and intensely personal plays will debut February 20 on the intimate black box stage at the 14th Street Playhouse and run for three weeks only.

Our Roots: 
Bad Seed Theatre was founded by Rod Lindsey, an actor, director, and producer with over 20 years of theatrical experience. His passion for issues-based theatre derives from his time at Emory University where the theatre community was electric. This eventually led him to become one of the few men to produce and direct The Vagina Monologues multiple times. Finally, a desire to create theatre with a focus on relevant political, social, and cultural issues culminated in Bad Seed.  

With a promise to produce shows that ask questions and cause you to think, the artistic staff settled on Closer and Sexual Perversity in Chicago. These shows promise to be the perfect beginning for a theatre company that wants to inspire as well as entertain.  

How You Can Help:
Your contributions will be instrumental in making these shows the best they can be.  All donations will be used to pay for such things as space rental (both performance and rehearsal), advertising, technical support, personnel, props and costumes.  

The cost of producing quality theatre is great, but with your help we can make it happen. Even if you are unable to make a monetary contribution, you can still make a difference. If you think Bad Seed Theatre will be a valuable addition to the theatre community in Atlanta, PLEASE tell others about us. Word of mouth is the best advertising this campaign can have.
story_txt: About Bad Seed: Bad Seed is a theatre company dedicated to a singular concept in the Atlanta artistic scene: To produce consistently thought-provoking and question-raising theatre.  Our goal is to make audiences contemplate all aspects of life, from the blatantly political to the extremely personal.  If our audiences leave our shows discussing and questioning what they have seen, our mission will have been achieved.Debut Productions:Our debut productions will be Closer, by Patrick Marber and Sexual Perversity in Chicago by David Mamet.  Both of these plays delve into the interrelations of four emotionally damaged people. To make matters more interesting, the productions will be in repertory with the same four actors appearing in both plays. These challenging and intensely personal plays will debut February 20 on the intimate black box stage at the 14th Street Playhouse and run for three weeks only.Our Roots: Bad Seed Theatre was founded by Rod Lindsey, an actor, director, and producer with over 20 years of theatrical experience. His passion for issues-based theatre derives from his time at Emory University where the theatre community was electric. This eventually led him to become one of the few men to produce and direct The Vagina Monologues multiple times. Finally, a desire to create theatre with a focus on relevant political, social, and cultural issues culminated in Bad Seed.  With a promise to produce shows that ask questions and cause you to think, the artistic staff settled on Closer and Sexual Perversity in Chicago. These shows promise to be the perfect beginning for a theatre company that wants to inspire as well as entertain.  How You Can Help:Your contributions will be instrumental in making these shows the best they can be.  All donations will be used to pay for such things as space rental (both performance and rehearsal), advertising, technical support, personnel, props and costumes.  The cost of producing quality theatre is great, but with your help we can make it happen. Even if you are unable to make a monetary contribution, you can still make a difference. If you think Bad Seed Theatre will be a valuable addition to the theatre community in Atlanta, PLEASE tell others about us. Word of mouth is the best advertising this campaign can have.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Anita Riggio, Book Writer, Lyricist and Producer of BRINDLEBEAST, and building this musical has been my passion, my pleasure, and my work for six years. Since 2010, we have successfully raised $90,000 through Kickstarter and direct contributions. These funds have allowed my collaborator, composer Sila Shaman and me to come to this campaign with a completed script and score, a Broadway cast of actors who are as committed to this project as they are talented, and an award-winning director and choreographer who are keenly interested in bringing BRINDLEBEAST to life in an excting new theatre space--plus BRINDLEBEAST has just been honored with the 2013 Martha Hill Newell Playwright's Award. GREAT NEWS!! But before we get to a staged reading, before we get to a fully realized production, we need funds to meet specific goals--and THAT's where YOU come in.

The Current Need

Check out the side bar for the low down on what you'd get for your contribution. Meantime, here's what we need:

  • $5,000 to pay for the ASL translations of the script and songs
  • $6,500 to pay for travel and housing expenses 
  • $12,000 to pay ASL interpreters and coaches during a 60 hour workshop
  • $25,000 for development

Um...but that's a pile o' cash, isn't it?

Sure. $48,500 is a pile o' cash. But we're mounting one campaign that would carry us through the development process of the next year and a half--and to our world premiere. If we reach our goal, this campaign will fund three phases of development:

Phase #1 would be the ASL translations of the script and songs, ASL tutoring for our five hearing actors, and ASL interpreting for our two deaf actors. 

Phase #2 would be travel, housing, and development for a workshop or lab. 

Phase #3 would be development for a fully staged reading. 

Makes sense, doesn't it?

 

The Project

BRINDLEBEAST braids together three story strands: a love story between a hearing man and a Deaf woman; a story of confronting a personal beast; a chronicle of the creative process itself. 

The world of BRINDLEBEAST is inherently inclusive: it is multi-racial, Deaf and hearing, straight and gay. The quest of the protagonist in BRINDLEBEAST is everyone’s quest: to confront one’s inner beast in order to love and be loved.  

I hope audience members will recognize themselves and their own struggles in these characters, and that after seeing BRINDLEBEAST, will return to their lives a bit more tolerant, a bit more accepting, a bit more loving of themselves and others.

 

Other ways you can help

You can support BRINDLEBEAST even if you can't contribute. Here's how:

  • Help get the word out about BRINDLEBEAST by making some noise about this campaign at school, at the office, within your circle of family and friends.
  • "Like" the BRINDLEBEAST Facebook page at: https://www.facebook.com/Brindlebeastie and leave a post. We LOVE hearing from you!
  • Share this link on your own FB page and Twitter feeds, and let your friends know why you're excited to support BRINDLEBEAST. Invite your friends to "like" our FB page, too.
  • Visit the BRINDLEBEAST website at: http://www.brindlebeastmusical.com/Home.html Share it with your friends and family.
  • Use #Brindlebeast to give us a shout-out!
  • While you're on the site, read my blog on writing and producing BRINDLEBEAST and Sila's blog about composing the music. Check out the "Building Brindlebeast" page for photos of our journey.  http://www.brindlebeastmusical.com/Building_Brindlebeast/Building_Brindlebeast.html
  • Send us flowers and cookies! Kidding, but do leave a comment. It's encouraging to know you're out there--and that you care!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign!

 

A Final Word

Because the creative team is expanding, the venues, locations, and dates of readings and performances are undetermined as of this writing.

Perks are not transferrable. Airfare and hotel are not included in any perk.

We so appreciate your support and we will endeavor to direct your donation to the category of your choice, however, if that category is fulfilled, we reserve the right to divert funds to an unfulfilled category while delivering the perks as described.

Send us flowers and cookies! Kidding, but do leave a comment. It's encouraging to know you're out there--and that you care!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign!

 
A Final Word


Because the creative team is expanding, the venues, locations, and dates of readings and performances are undetermined as of this writing.
Perks are not transferrable. Airfare and hotel are not included in any perk.
We so appreciate your support and we will endeavor to direct your donation to the category of your choice, however, if that category is fulfilled, we reserve the right to divert funds to an unfulfilled category while delivering the perks as described.

story:
Our Story

BandBazi (Farsi: Trapeze) is an award winning, multi-cultural performing arts company founded in 2001 by actress and aerialist, Philippa Vafadari in Brighton, East Sussex. We are a multicultural and inclusive charity that uses circus and theatre skills to give a voice to marginalised groups through professional productions and education programmes. 

BandBazi aims to give a voice to disenfranchised groups and challenge stereotypes. To achieve this it uses circus and performance skills and dialogue to create new, original and accessible work. On first sight the plays seem comfortable but, as they progress they address issues around mental health, cultural identity, gender or social relationships. The company produces work on its own or in co-production with other theatre companies. The touring schedule is backed up by an educational outreach programme. The workshops are targeted at a cross-section of the community and provide the people taking part with a means of self-expression through creative writing, circus and physical skills and improvisation.  They form the backbone of the company’s desire to bring theatre to groups who might not otherwise realise the relevance it can have to their lives.


Mind Walking is a new aerial drama by acclaimed playwright Tanika Gupta, which explores what happens to a family when the mind of an old, Indian man starts to unravel. Bobbie has spent all his adult life in Britain, but in a care home he reverts back to his first language; a language that he spoke as a boy in Bombay in the 1940's. His family - loving wife, grown- up daughter and teenage grand-son are devastated. How will they manage to communicate with Bobbie? How do they understand Bobbie's life as he enters a world that they have no comprehension of? As secrets and hidden stories tumble out of Bobbie’s mouth, his family start to question the truth about their ancestry and shared history. Mind Walking is an emotional drama exploring notions of home, cultural identity and family bonds. 


We currently have a regional tour running in the Autumn throughout South East England and Scotland; however, we want to take the story further - to India! Our Aerial rigger Jonothan has been to assess the suitability of a few theatres in Mumbai, Chennai, Bangalore and Delhi for aerial circus and it looks very possible. Now all we need is the funds to tour around the country.


The Impact

BandBazi produces work on its own or in co-production with other theatre companies. The touring schedule is backed up by an educational outreach programme. The workshops are targeted at a cross-section of the community and provide the people taking part with a means of self-expression through creative writing, circus and physical skills and improvisation.  They form the backbone of the company’s desire to bring theatre to groups who might not otherwise realise the relevance it can have to their lives. We hope to take our work to India, to where the story of Bobbie started; raising awareness of Alzhiemers and growing old to broad range of people and increasing participation in the Arts.


What We Need & What You Get

We currently have funding for part of the project, but are looking for further funding to cover various costs including:


Creative professionals' fees and performer/production team wages

Costume/Props freight

Visas

Flights - both from the UK to India and internal

Accommodation

Publicity & Marketing 

Technical support

Aerial rigging equipment

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Tell all your friends about the great work we do, both as a professional theatre company and in our Youth Circus Theatre workshops. If you would like to learn more then have a look at our website or drop us a line on mail@bandbazi. Check out the Facebook page and 'like' us to receive regular updates from BandBazi HQ!

story:
Gay teen's murder inspires Vancouver playwright's MY FUNNY VALENTINE

"The [2008] murder of Lawrence King has become the most prominent gay-bias crime since the 1998 murder of Matthew Shepard" -Newsweek Magazine

A death goes far beyond its immediate surroundings. Inspired by the headlines, MY FUNNY VALENTINE enters the minds of seven people on the fringes of a horrendous murder that will forever affect them. 

"The play is certainly affecting...the timeliness makes [it] feel very present in the here and now". -PLANK magazine

As Vancouver, BC is currently ranked as the hate crime capital of Canada, there is no time like the present for Zee Zee Theatre to launch its third acclaimed season with award-winning playwright Dave Deveau's latest, MY FUNNY VALENTINE, a provocative, heart-wrenching, and challenging look at viewpoints of hate and otherness. 

MY FUNNY VALENTINE by Dave Deveau

Directed by Cameron Mackenzie

Featuring Dora-award winner Kyle Cameron

Stage Managed by Jillian Perry

Set & Costume Designed by Marina Szijarto

Lighting Designed by Jergus Oprsal

Sound Designed by Shawn Sorensen

Performances start April 14th 

at Performing Arts Lodge, 581 Cardero Street, Vancouver, BC

http://www.zeezeetheatre.ca

The Impact

Vancouver is currently ranked as the hate crime capital of Canada, which is horrifying, especially given our supposed liberal-mindedness on the West Coast. As a result, the timing for MY FUNNY VALENTINE couldn't be better - it is a means to start a conversation. The play examines hate within a community and its implications, something we need to shed light on right here at home.


Typically a theatrical run in Vancouver for small independent companies is 1-1.5 weeks. Zee Zee is launching this vital production with performances starting April 14, and we are hoping to continue the run through the month as there are so many people who need to see this production. This is where the real conversation happens. 

What We Need & What You Get

Despite having some government support (through the Canada Council for the Arts) and year-round fundraising efforts (including the dance party Queer Bash), the cost of producing professional theatre annually is exorbitant. We still require that final financial push to ensure that we can get the word out. 

These funds will pay for theatre rental as well as artist fees as we believe passionately that artists should be paid a professional living wage for their work and have worked by that mandate over the past three seasons. Our past productions have cost around $30K each, and we are in the final phases of that push to ensure that as many audience members as possible can take part in this conversation. 


Rehearsals are underway, and now we ask for you to join us in helping this tremendous journey come alive. Perks are listed on the side bar!


Other Ways You Can Help

You can also lend your support by telling your friends on Twitter and Facebook about this funding drive and the show itself: https://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=19215399...


And spread the word about ticket sales as well, an important part of our funding structure: http://www.ticketstonight.ca/ticketstonight/eve...

story:
The Project

Christopher Utley is an aspiring, Christian playwright in Los Angeles determined to turn the norms and conventions of the gospel stage play upside down.

 

With your help, Blessed Arts Theater is working hard to present Christopher’s debut stage play titled “in-a-me” in North Hollywood this August 2011.


Synopsis of “in-a-me” 

Terry King is on the verge of having his lifelong dream come true.  But in order to achieve it, he must first make war - both externally against haters, naysayers & an alcohol addiction, and internally against his own inner voices of fear and shame - voices that manifest themselves in the guise of a demonic spirit called THE FAT MAN. Through his struggle, Terry comes to learn that mankind's most vicious enemy is the one "in-a-me."


The Impact

At Blessed Arts our tagline says it all. Our mission is to “bring revival to the stage.” We want to tell contemporary, relevant and unashamedly Christian and engaging stories. Realizing that most seekers are hesitant to go to the church to hear a message, we want to take the message to the seeker. By presenting our work on ‘neutral ground,’ we hope we are casting the widest possible net to share the good news. It is our hope and prayer that you will partner with us as we humbly and faithfully do what he has called us to do.

 

What We Need & Our Appreciation

Through advanced ticket sales, we are hoping to raise $500 to fund a showcase and discussion of Christopher’s stage play “in-a-me” in North Hollywood. This will cover the bare minimum costs of renting the venue, renting rehearsal space and paying the actors and crew.

 

There are so many reasons you should help fund this project. The first is that if you know Christopher, you know that he is a man wholly sold out to giving God glory through his work. The second is that Christopher and his wife stand firm in the belief that Christian theater is not a hobby, but a calling on his life to use his gift and talent for writing to minister to God’s people. “in-a-me” is engaging, hard-hitting and ultimately cathartic. And finally, each donation level has unique perks that we gladly offer to show you our appreciation. Take a look at our perks section for more details.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In-kind donations are greatly appreciated! Can you provide a room or office once a week for rehearsals to curb rental costs? Provide pre-show dinner for the 10-person cast and crew? Host our post show cast party? Advertise in our theater program? Contact us at Blessed arts theater [at] gmail [dot] com for more ways you can get involved.

You can also lend your support by telling your friends on Twitter and Facebook about this funding drive. Just share our page.

story:
A Recipe for: Dinner and Sex Upstairs

Prepared by The Dotted Elk Theatre Company

Dinner and Sex Upstairs is a new play by award-winning playwright Gregory Paul Thomas, directed by Rebeka Avendano for the Dotted Elk Theatre Company. Taking place in The Bronx in the 1990s, the play focuses around domestic violence, broken homes and teen pregnancy and the cyclical patterns these issues can carve on generations of families. The play treads the line between realistically gritty and tragically funny, giving us a unique, simultaneous insight into a world that is too often seen through only one-side of the looking glass: either from the outside looking in or from the inside trying to get out.

Dinner and Sex Upstairs is a perfect fit for up-and-coming director Rebeka Avendano,  a 90's baby and a Bronx native herself. She will focus on a nature vs. nurture-based theme she calls "Inherited Destiny," which begs us to question: Are we who we are naturally or are we who our families and environment have made us to be?

A Little More about the Play

Dinner and Sex Upstairs was originally written in a span of 18 hours over three days for a college workshop where it was given two weeks to get on its feet for one performance. With a little more time and experience under their belts, Greg, Rebeka, and the rest of The Dotted Elk crew feel it's time to rework the play and bring it to an outside audience. With some rewrites in the books, some old faces returning and some new faces gracing our stage, this promises to be an off-off-Broadway show you won't want to miss this season.

Ingredients: $4,500

Every contribution brings us one step closer to our goal! As a contributor, we'll keep you updated regularly on our fundraising and production progress until we open. We'll even clue you in to exactly what part of the production process you helped make happen. How neat is that?

Here's where your contribution will go:

  • $2500- $3000: Performance Venue
  • $450: Rehearsal Space
  • $120- $150: Audition and Callback Space
  • $55: Casting Notices (Backstage and Playbill)
  • $200: Stage Manager
  • $200:PR
  • $375: Promo Stuff (videos, posters, postcards, programs, etc.)
  • $175: Set
  • $100: Lights
  • $100: Sound
  • $75: Costumes
Sprinkle in some Perks!

If you just can't wait to see Dinner and Sex Upstairs, you can purchase presale tickets right here through IndieGoGo. If you're one of the first, you'll get an early bird discount! This way we know you're coming, you know you've funded something tangible, and we get some of our production capital early.

And of course, there're more secret ingredients on top of tickets... Glance to your right if you're curious.

Other Ways You Can Help Us Get Cooking!

Everyone can contribute to our campaign! We appreciate all forms of help:

  • Share, like, and follow. You never know who else might want to help us buy ingredients. The more people we reach, the better chance we have at serving all of our courses.
  • Audition for our show! 
  • Apply to be our Stage Manager!
  • Help us distribute flyers.
  • Let us know if you have any other cool ideas!

All of the above are sweeter than cherry pie.

Serving Soon!

Dinner and Sex Upstairs will run for two weeks in April 2014 in Manhattan. In 2013, the company produced Last Man Out at Theater for the New City; it hopes to replicate that success in a smaller, more intimate venue with Dinner and Sex Upstairs. The Dotted Elk is currently reviewing New York City theatres to determine a space that will best fit our production's unique recipe.

Check us out:

http://www.thedottedelk.com/

https://www.facebook.com/TheDottedElkTheatreCompany

Thanks!

The Dotted Elk Theatre Company
story_txt:
A Recipe for: Dinner and Sex Upstairs
Prepared by The Dotted Elk Theatre Company
Dinner and Sex
Upstairs is a new play by award-winning playwright Gregory Paul
Thomas, directed by Rebeka Avendano for the Dotted Elk Theatre Company. Taking
place in The Bronx in the 1990s, the play focuses around domestic violence,
broken homes and teen pregnancy and the cyclical patterns these issues can carve
on generations of families. The play
treads the line between realistically gritty and tragically funny, giving us a
unique, simultaneous insight into a world that is too often seen through only
one-side of the looking glass: either from the outside looking in or from the
inside trying to get out.
Dinner and Sex Upstairs is a perfect fit for up-and-coming director Rebeka Avendano,  a 90's baby and a Bronx native herself. She will focus on a nature vs. nurture-based theme she calls "Inherited Destiny," which begs us to question: Are we who we are naturally or are we who our families and environment have made us to be?A Little More about the PlayDinner and Sex Upstairs was originally written in a span of 18 hours over three days for a college workshop where it was given two weeks to get on its feet for one performance. With a little more time and experience under their belts, Greg, Rebeka, and the rest of The Dotted Elk crew feel it's time to rework the play and bring it to an outside audience. With some rewrites in the books, some old faces returning and some new faces gracing our stage, this promises to be an off-off-Broadway show you won't want to miss this season.
Ingredients: $4,500
Every contribution brings us one step closer to our goal! As a contributor, we'll keep you updated regularly on our fundraising and production progress until we open. We'll even clue you in to exactly what part of the production process you helped make happen. How neat is that?Here's where your contribution will go:$2500- $3000: Performance Venue$450: Rehearsal Space$120- $150: Audition and Callback Space$55: Casting Notices (Backstage and Playbill)$200: Stage Manager$200:PR$375: Promo Stuff (videos, posters, postcards, programs, etc.)$175: Set$100: Lights$100: Sound$75: CostumesSprinkle in some Perks!If you just can't wait to see Dinner and Sex Upstairs, you can purchase presale tickets right here through IndieGoGo. If you're one of the first, you'll get an early bird discount! This way we know you're coming, you know you've funded something tangible, and we get some of our production capital early.
And of course, there're more secret ingredients on top of tickets... Glance to your right if you're curious.

Other Ways You Can Help Us Get Cooking!Everyone can contribute to our campaign! We appreciate all forms of help:
Share, like, and follow. You never know who else might want to help us buy ingredients. The more people we reach, the better chance we have at serving all of our courses.Audition for our show! Apply to be our Stage Manager!Help us distribute flyers.Let us know if you have any other cool ideas!All of the above are sweeter than cherry pie.Serving Soon!
Dinner and Sex Upstairs will run for two weeks in April 2014 in Manhattan. In 2013, the company produced Last Man Out at Theater for the New City; it hopes to replicate that success in a smaller, more intimate venue with Dinner and Sex Upstairs. The Dotted Elk is currently reviewing New York City theatres to determine a space that will best fit our production's unique recipe.

Check us out:
http://www.thedottedelk.com/
https://www.facebook.com/TheDottedElkTheatreCompany
Thanks!
The Dotted Elk Theatre Company

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT:

A workshop produced by Studio 501 at Pace University

The Metal Children 

Written by: Adam Rapp

Directed by: Lindsay Olson

"In small-town America, a young adult novel about teen pregnancy is banned by the local school board, igniting a fierce and violent debate over abortion, religious beliefs, and modern feminism. When the novel's directionless New York City author arrives in town to defend the book, he finds that it has inspired a group of local teens to rebel in strange and unexpected ways. A timely and unforgettable drama about the failure of the urban and heartland America to understand each other."

Featuring:

Dominick Pate as Tobin Falmouth

Sean Potter as Bruno Binelli

Robyn Frank as Kong/Tami Lake/Boy X

Austin Klich as Lynne/Roberta Cupp

Maren Lavelle as Edith Dundee

Jordan Lemmond as Stacey Kinsella

Maggie Borlando as Vera Dundee

Lindsay Milligan as Cooper/Nurse/Boy in the Porky Pig Mask

Emmanuel Polycarpe as Otto Hurley

Female Ensemble: Schuyler Doemling, Grace Duffey, Cydnie Hampton, Devin McCall, Madelyn Wiley

Production Staff:

Assistant Directors: Sydney Currie & Camila Perez

Stage Manager: John Moore

Production Manager: Spencer Armstrong

Musical Director: Travis Rothschild

Fight Choreographer: Patrick Pribyl

Dance Choreographer: Michael John Hughes

Casting Assistant: Jesse James Keitel

Lighting Design: Ciaran MacArtain

Make-up Design: Stefani Vivian

Props: Jacob Lebowitz 

Costume Design: John Moore & Lindsay Olson

Set Dressing: Jesse James Keitel

Performances:

April 11th & 12th at 8:00PM

April 13th at 5:00PM

Schaeberle Studio

41 Park Row, 10th Floor

New York, NY 10038

Tickets are free of charge.

WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO?

Set Construction: $400

Props: $300

Sound: $25

Lighting: $25

Make-up: $150

Costumes: $200

Photography: $200

Contingency: $100

Total: $1400.00

Every dollar that you donate will directly fund one of these items! Every little bit can make the difference! Any extra money would go to Studio 501 in order to produce more free theater for the Pace community. 

Please note: If we do not reach our goal, we will not receive any of the money!

NOTE FROM THE DIRECTOR:

Dear Friends, 

It is my final semester at Pace University and this is my most ambitious project to date! Making this show/dream of mine come to fruition will require unending support from you all. Rehearsals are heating up and the cast is more talented than I could've imagined. With an all-star design team and creative team beside me, this show is already promising. 

Due to this being a student production, many expenses will be taken care of for me, such as rehearsal space, venue costs, lighting equipment, etc. However, this show requires so many other elements to really make it come to life. Costumes, props, and various furniture pieces are the key pieces of the puzzle. 

Please take a look at our rewards when making your donation, consider the options, and give what you can. Anything and everything is appreciated. 

Much love, 

LINDSAY

Video created by: Sydney Currie, Camila Perez, and Travis Rothschild. Many thanks!

story:
Do you love to dance? Join us on Saturday June 14th and bust a move during our free Soul Train style dance party in Halifax! The fun takes place in Victoria Park, where we will gather to party like it’s 1999. Prizes for most creative dance moves and most interesting costume will give bragging rights to those who truly deserve.

Who are we?

Start with a Smile is a Halifax based volunteer organization that is dedicated to making people smile by reminding everyone that beautiful, unique individuals surround us. Our goal is to bring people together and create positive influence and change in the world… through the power of smiles!

The Impact

Everyone can smile.  Smiles are quick, they are free, and they affect both the giver and receiver. Smiles can change lives.

Most importantly, smiling is a choice that each of us makes. When we choose to smile, we are choosing to share our hope in a better world.

Here’s some other stuff we’ve done:

The Crosswalk Dance Party (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TlVaNYQLnOE)

The Giant Group Hug (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pYFVnwGxqpk)

Smile on Spring Garden Road (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HuWtz1hbqC0)

Flashmob Dance for Kindness (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yzSTa3nSHxk).

What We Need

Public parties require permits, insurance, and a whole bunch of other boring paperwork that takes time and money. They also require marketing to get the word out and get as many awesome people on the dance floor as possible.

Here’s a rundown of the costs behind this fabulous party:

Permit, Insurance & Rentals = $700

Marketing Materials & Give-a-ways = $700

Campaign Admin Fees = $100

Total Costs = $1,500

What You Get

$10    We’ll thank you with a social media shoutout

$25   We’ll feature your name in the event video credits

$50   We’ll feature your picture on the dance aisle of fame at the event

$100   You’ll receive all of the perks!!

If we don’t reach the entire goal, the funds will first go toward the necessities of park rental, insurance and rental costs. Following that, any remaining funds will go toward marketing. Extra funds we raise will be put away for a rainy day when we really need to do something and get people smiling.

Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer!  We always appreciate people who:

- can help build the set
- know how to decorate for a party
 - share their lives on social media
 - love to dance, dance, dance 
- are great organizers 
- protect the green green grass all around 
- get excited meeting and greeting (and much more...)

Email lorelei@startwithasmile.ca if you want to lend a hand!

Shout Out Loud! 
You can make some noise through your social media by sharing this campaign and spreading the word about this awesome event!!    

Show Up! 
Whatever you can do is appreciated and be sure to join us on June 14th in Victoria Park, Halifax!!

Wishing you peace, love and smiles!!

story:
Synopsis

Socially awkward Mexican American teenager Coco has no trouble talking to his blog follower “Minions”. Talking to his mother is a bit more difficult, especially as she makes him sit in his special chair.

El Ultimo Coconut is a coming of age tale about a young man navigating many different worlds. The massive multiplayer role playing game World of Warcraft, the Arizona/Mexico border, and the family dinner table all provide canvas for his incredible journey as he carves out a sense of identity and tries to get into MIT.

In this solo show, Gerald Alejandro Ford takes on the both family politics and cyber-nerdom with humor and humanity. Ford embodies all the characters, from the polar opposite twin brothers at the story’s core, to vigilante border patrols, Mexican strippers and the boy’s protective emotional mama.


What The money is for.

$250 for the Hollywood Fringe Festival Registration 
$750 for the theater space for 5 performances
$200 for Stage Manager/Crew
$150 for Posters and Postcards
$150 for other costs. Set, props, transportation ect.


History 

Coco started as my Senior thesis at Cornish College of the arts and since then has flourished. It was the inaugural production of Seattle’s Latino Theater Collective, eSe Teatro and has been performed at Annex Theatre, ACT Theater, and 12 minutes Max at On the Boards in Seattle as well as the The Miracle Theatre in Portland. 


Reviews

“Ford shines in his own work. He nails a broad spectrum of comedy, leaping in and out of multiple characters in seconds, managing to make them all sympathetic but skewering all of them for their weaknesses—including the occasionally frightened and self-entitled coconut. El Ultimo Coconut feels a little rough-hewn in spots (it is an extension of a student project, after all) but is consistently entertaining and even shows glimmers of brilliance.” –The Stranger

“Ford’s work is well written and was executed with bold energy. Three seconds in and I wanted to hug him. SO ADORKABLE! …. If you ever tried to go against the grain of your heritage because the deep longing in your heart wouldn’t settle for anything else – you will relate. If you ever renounced your family, your past, your skin, your roots to save your own ass (or face) – you will relate to this show. Good art is like that… and ‘Coco’ is beautiful like that.” –Theater & Its Trouble

“[Ford's] fish-out-of-water antics and double-takes provide many of the laughs, which burble forth throughout, but the howls of laughter come from his mom’s demand, when she has something weighty to say, that Coco sit in his chair. Without going into it, the chair has a way of symbolizing the way moms the world over fight the future in which their children have grown…. The strength of the show lies in how packed it is with candid observations of daily life for a Mexican-American family living in Arizona, and the multitude of borders jammed into a single living room.” –The Sunbreak

story:
Summary

Please help me launch my High School Theatre Operations Consulting company.

My name is Beth Rand and I am launching my business: Rand Consulting and Design (RCD).  My Associate Consultants and I provide services for safe, functional, self-sustaining, and empowering learning environments in high school theatres.

These days many high schools are building state-of-the-art theatres, and a lot of these double as educational facilities and “road houses”.  After the theatres are built the keys are handed over to school administrators and teachers who are not trained to manage theatres and to teach students technical theatre.  I am launching this business to fill this gap.

RCD’s purpose is to help high schools get their theatres up and running; set up operating systems, scheduling, create a safety program, and work with the staff and students to provide a functional, safe, and educational environment.

We are those rare Theatre Consultants who are actively working in the high school theatre environment, giving us first hand knowledge about current operational issues.  I myself began my technical theatre career in my own high school theatre.  I have worked in educational and professional technical theatre for over 30 years, and I have worked in over 20 theatres.  My primary background is in Stage Lighting, and more recently Theatre Management.

This campaign is to pay for the costs of running a booth at the CEFPI Annual Conference in Portland in October 2014. 

CEFPI (Council of Educational Facility Planners International) is a worldwide non-profit association whose mission is to improve the places where children learn.  CEFPI members are involved in planning, designing, building, equipping and maintaining school facilities such as theatres.

CEFPI is one of the primary organizations with whom I expect to be working in order to achieve my goals of making high school theatres more functional, safe and educational. 

The Impact

Many people have performed in a theatre at least once during their high school days.  Many people have children who have performed in a school theatre. Many people have a high school in their community with some sort of performing arts program.  When we go to events in school theatres, we as audience members just see the magic.  We don’t see what goes on to create this magic.  And, unfortunately, we are not aware of how mismanaged or how unsafe it can be behind the scenes.

It’s my purpose, through my business’s services - and also through “The High School THEATRE OPERATIONS MANUAL”, which will be published soon - to help high schools positively answer these questions:

Is the staff comfortable and knowledgeable about the theatre’s functional operation?

Is learning enhanced through the theatre operations?

Is the theatre ergonomically functional?

Are operational policies and procedures in place?

Is the theatre self-sustaining financially?

Is the school protected from liabilities and lawsuits?

Is the theatre being used to its full potential?

A functional, safe and educational theatre can have an impact on student learning, facility operations and overall safety.

What We Need

The cost of having a booth at the CEFPI conference includes, but is not limited to:

$1250  Booth fee

$445  Booth furnishings (chairs, carpeting, electric. not included) (estimated)

$2160    4 nights hotel for myself and 2 of my Associate Consultants (3 rooms)

$600  Booth signage, supplies (estimated)

$925  Conference fee for 1 Associate Consultant (conference fees for 2 people included in booth price)

$200  Gas to and from Portland (estimated for 2 cars)

$720  Meals – 3 people, 4 days, 3 meals (estimated)

$1200  Stipend for 2 Associate Consultants to help staff the booth for 3 days

$300  Cost of 6 (2 per person) company shirts to wear at the conference

$200  Certificate of Insurance (required)

$8000

Partial Funding

If the entire goal is not reached, here’s what will happen:

1.  If not enough money is raised to have a booth at the conference, I will attend the CEFPI conference by myself for networking and marketing opportunities, and any remaining funds will be applied to other start-up and marketing costs of the business.

2.  If not enough money is raised for me to attend the conference at all, the funds will be applied to other start-up and marketing costs of the business. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donation amount would really be appreciated.

Also really appreciated would be help in getting the word out about my campaign.  Please help me spread the word to your friends, family and colleagues through word of mouth, Facebook and other social media, and by forwarding this page link in your e-mails. 

Thanks for believing in my cause and for supporting my campaign!

story:
Shakespeare up close and personal.  We want to bring the incandescent splendor of the language of (in the view of many) Shakespeare’s greatest play.  Shakespeare’s Antony and Cleopatra: UNDONE offers a brisk, seventy-minute thrill ride of passion, power plays, deception, and death on an intimate storefront stage in Chicago. To be produced Sept 5 - Oct 5 2014.

We (Patricia Henritze – director/writer and Shawna Tucker – actress/writer) came together to collaborate on a piece that had fascinated us.  Why does Shakespeare’s version receive relatively few productions? And why, over the years, have so many actresses and actors failed at this play?  We wanted to create a version of the play that would be easier to produce by smaller companies – those with the passion for Shakespeare, but not the budget.  This scaled-back adaptation will allow for greater flexibility in staging and artistic interpretation, leading to greater accessibility for one of the Bard's greatest works.  Both Patricia and Shawna have been involved in theater as actors, playwrights, producers, and directors for over 25 years.  We’ve worked in Chicago, St. Louis, Atlanta, Washington D.C., and New York.  We bring mature experience to a mature play.

This will be the inaugural production of Skyline StageWorks, a company to create an organic engagement with audiences by actors and playwrights, to bind them together with an experience that will touch the mind and heart in a meaningful way.   Getting started is always the tricky part, and we’re inviting people from the Chicago area (and beyond) to be part of something unusual – and to help collaborate with a genius… Shakespeare!

Three quarters of the $4000 we hope to gather from this fundraising effort will go toward space rental, the rest will go toward artist fees.  Our artists are graciously agreeing to contribute their services for far less than they deserve, and we will use box office receipts to add to their compensation, in addition to pay for building materials, props and costumes.

We have not yet received not-for-profit status, so unfortunately, contributions are not tax-deductible.  You'll be giving out of pure love for the art, and you will be heartily thanked for it!

W.H. Auden described Antony and Cleopatra as Shakespeare’s greatest play.  That it isn’t performed more often, and the beautiful language isn’t aired more frequently is mostly due to difficulties in producing such an epic play.  (Forty-four characters!)  With the creation of our piece, we will have something that can be produced at all levels:  college, community theater, storefront theater, professional and non professional.  The lushness of the language will be heard.

ANY contribution, large or small will be of help.  This includes monetary contributions, contributions by sharing our story and our link, and if you are in the Chicago area… come to the play!!!

For his bounty,

There was no winter in't; an autumn it was

That grew the more by reaping.  Antony and Cleopatra

story:
ONE ACT Wants to Rock Chicago!

Hi, Potential Contributors!

ONE ACT, a Boulder-based improv theater group, was recently accepted to perform at the prestigious Chicago Improv Festival in April. TWO PERFORMANCES on April 4 and 5, 2014!! Wow, are we excited (and freaking honored) to bring our fully improvised one-act plays to Chicago, the home of improv. 

Meridith (our esteemed director) and I started ONE ACT in 2012 because we LOVE improv and the idea that it can be way more than slapstick comedy (brilliant and funny as that is). Our talented and skilled cast is thrilled to perform at the festival.

As typical starving artists, we're looking for assistance with travel, food and lodging. Mostly the travel and lodging (we can eat tofu). Your contributions--however large or small--help ensure we aren't going into more debt for our beloved improv passion. 

What we need and what you get!

Why $5,000? Here's the breakdown:

  • Roundtrip flights for seven people
  • Lodging for three nights for seven people (we will share beds!)
  • Per diem for three days (we'll eat like sparrows)
  • Tickets to our Boulder shows (vary by contribution level)
  • Personal thank-yous on our FB and home page
  • Your name (or company) on our Chicago program
  • Likes on your FB page--we'll like you up and down your timeline
  • Free Applied Improvisation for Communication workshop (it's a BIGGIE)

Our track record is solid.

  • We've gotten city grants to support our season here at home in Boulder.
  • Received excellent reviews and success at the 2012 Fringe Festival.

Can't contribute? Spread the word!

If you simply don't have the dough, please spread the word about our exciting trip and fundraising effort via your social media wizardry. Tell your friends in Chicago to come see our shows!

story:
Help us take our show to The Melbourne Fringe Festival 2014, Toot Sweet!!

We need your help to produce our first ever show, The Ultimate, where we take a behind-the-scenes look at the 'reality' of reality TV. We incorporate our audience by not only making them apart of our show, but by letting them in on the secret lives of our characters.

Toot Sweet Productions is a newly formed theatre company comprising of young and emerging artists. Based locally in Melbourne our company is staging its first professional production!!

The founding members of the company; Amanda Goode, James Goode, Justine Cammerino, Emily Goode and Holly Bohmer, met studying Drama at Deakin University, where their love of comedy and exploring social themes led them to the creation of Toot Sweet Productions. 

We are in it for the art, not the money. That's why all the takings from our 9 performances will be donated to a charity close to our hearts...Animals Australia. (I mean..who could say no to a kitten, right?)

Our show will be staged at Club Voltaire, smack bang in the middle of the Fringe belt; North Melbourne. 

With your funding we can get this (WARNING: cliché ahead) show on the road. 


What We Need

We are raising $2,000.
$1,500 will go towards the venue hire and technical production (the hiring of a sound and lighting guy).
$400 will go towards promotional material, allowing us to create higher quality material (promotional videos and flyers) that will aid us to be seen among the other shows in Melbourne Fringe Festival. Having a good promotional pack will allow us the best possible future for our company.
$100 will go towards costuming.
Your help is crucial. Even a small donation would be great.
All donations will go towards the venue hire if we don't get our target amount.

The Impact

We want to help animals through the money we raise from ticket sales.
We want our thoughts and ideas heard.

Risks & Challenges

We don't get sponsored.

Because we are a newly formed theatre group no one comes to see our show.

Friendships will be destroyed.

We have no money to give to the animals. 

Oh, sad.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Hear ye, hear ye! Tweet all about it!

    Please slug our campaign on your social media sites: Twitter, Instagram, Facebook  and Youtube.

    Or use the Indiegogo share tools!
