story:
Short Summary

  • Hello!  If you don't already know me, my name is Courtney.  I am a dancer, choreographer and roué cyr performer based in New York City.  I hold a BFA in dance from Fordham University and Alvin Ailey.  My other training, affiliations and performance experience include Kirov Ballet, American Ballet Theater, Joffrey Ballet, Martha Graham, STREB, Diavolo, Buglisi Dance Theater, Svindelic, Spinnovation and  Company XIV.  Most recently, I was a soloist in the off-broadway show, presented by Company XIV," Nutcracker Rouge".
  • I am a roué cyr artist , performer and world competitor for Team USA in wheel gymnastics.  What is roué cyr?   See here: http://instagram.com/p/lvrwBICbow/  
  • I have been internationally recognized by Burgundy Dance Festival, and Napoli Danza, a nominee for the Rolex Mentor Protege Initiative, and a recipient of Bindlestiff First of May award, STREB Emerging Artists Commission & Dance Magazine Video Competition.  
  • I am a movement instructor of cyr wheel, GYROTONIC, GYROKINESIS and the Lester Horton Technique.  I have also taught gymnastics and STREB's POP ACTION. 
  •  Feel free to ask me questions.  It would be my pleasure to respond.


  • This campaign is very important to me because it grants me the opportunity to manifest my vision.  The funds are essential to my project's existence and success.
  • By making a contribution, you are bringing my project to life, which employes about 30 people, entertains 130 audience members,  and supporting Dixon Place's mission, a state-of-the-art theater that proceeds to house dance performances (a rarity).  Most importantly, by making a donation, you are helping dance survive as a legitimate art form and therefore countering the the erroneous stigma that dance is dead.  Dance is highly depreciated as an art form in the United States.  It is the most challenging medium of art to fund.  Your contributions are paramount to the continuation of my career as well as the other artists and crew involved in my production.  We must keep the arts and artists alive, and you can make a difference simply by making a contribution.  


What We Need & What You Get

  • I must raise $15,000 If I reach my goal of $15,000 I will actually receive: 
    $15,000 - Indiegogo & Paypal fees = $13,950.  These funds cover space rentals for rehearsal, theater rentals for aerial rehearsals, tech rehearsal and dress rehearsal, as well as costume materials, video documentation of the process and performance, technical requirements such as 2 video projectors, rigging, props, advertisements, and artists fees (11 performers, costume designer, lighting designer, stage manager, video projection designer, tech crew).  If I do NOT reach my goal of $15,000, indiegogo takes 9% (!!) instead of 4% of my total funds received!  So please please, help us reach our goal of $15,000!
  • We have unique perks for our contributors!  Scroll down to see what you get!
  • If we do not reach our goal, we will spend the received funds on the video projectors, but all artist fees will have to be cut, in which case, we lose many of our team members and ultimately perform without lighting, costumes, or documentation.  Also, indiegogo will take 9% of whatever funds we do receive.  A show of this nature would be incomplete and less rewarding for everyone involved, including the audience.

The Impact

Last year I held a successful fundraiser for another production of mine, "Keller:  A dance with plywood boxes".  The impact of the fundraiser was outrageous!  I am still receiving public recognition for Keller.  Thanks to the funding, I had a successful performance.  Now I have new, professional video content for demo reels which is paramount for future opportunities.  

Again, by making a contribution, you are helping sustain the dance world.  You are helping artists thrive.   You are fueling creativity and peace.  Movement is our mother tongue and universal language.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us make some noise about our campaign!  Share this with your friends and family to help us get the word out about our campaign and show!  Even if you cannot make a contribution, you are helping us advertise and sell tickets by sharing our campaign via social media, email and in person.
  • Use the indiegogo share tools!  It's so easy!

story:
What Are We Doing?

My lovely artist friend, Laurie Zabele Cawley, shot me a message one day and asked if I'd like to collaborate on a split bill concert with her at Union College in November. I was BLOWN AWAY. I was being asked to work with one of my favorites and the next best part? I didn't have to pay through the nose to do this. After receiving a grant from Dance Alliance and working with Union College's Theatre and Dance Department, we're putting on a FREE show open to everyone in the community.

We are working to bring more art awareness and modern dance to the community that already houses some pretty incredible programs through Union College and The National Museum of Dance. 

We'll be performing at the Henle Dance Pavilion at Union College. A new 7,000 square foot facility that is absolutely stunning with a 2,000 square foot performance space, 20-foot tall ceilings, beautiful sprung marley flooring and garden views.


What We Need & What You Get

We've put a lot of our own money into this process already, but I'd love to actually give these women something more for their time. Did I mention I have been feeding them an absurd amount of M&Ms and Swedish Fish?

Here's where the money will go:

  • $1,000 will go to pay the dancers. They really deserve it.
  • $200 will go to the composer of 5+1, Kyle Sorensen
  • $200 will go to the car we're renting to drive up to Schenectady, NY and back.
  • $200 will clothe them. This is an all-ages show, so we'll need costumes.
  • $200 will cover the rest of the space rentals.
  • $200 will feed the company on our trip.

Like I said, we've already put a lot of time and money into this project so far, but we need help. And if you bust out your calculator, you'll notice the amounts above surpass our $1,500 mark. Making work and showing the world isn't cheap, but we do it everyday. And we'll keep doing it tomorrow.

Aside from the immense satisfaction of supporting the arts, you can select from an array of perks based on your tax-deductible donation. Wait, what? Tax-deductible? YES! As a sponsored artist of Fractured Atlas, any amount you donate is tax-deductible by the furthest extent of the law. 

What happens if we don't reach our goal? Easy. Any amount we do raise will go straight to the dancers and collaborating artists. None of this work could happen without them, and they deserve the best!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Low on cash? We get it. But there are other ways you can contribute if you're interested in helping us reach our goal. Here are a few ways:
    • Share our campaign with your friends!
    • Use the easy links on Indiegogo to spread the love to Facebook, Twitter, and beyond!
    • Send us good vibes!
    • Show your love of art by taking your friends and family to a show, and come see us when we're in your 'hood!


    Lastly, as director of this company, I do everything I can to support my amazing artists. But sadly, there aren't enough M&Ms and Swedish Fish in the world to give these women what they deserve for their time and breathtaking dedication. I couldn't make the art I make without them, so I'm asking you if you wouldn't mind helping me out. Thank you for your time, and dance on, lovers!

story:
Naiad Productions

Presents   

in Collaboration with Shift     and     Co Presented by  HKRep 

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

By Dale Wasserman
From the novel by Ken Kesey

Who we are

Naiad Productions aims to magically give life to stories through fascination, power and charm.

Nymphs who presided over fountains, wells, springs, streams, Naiads were ancient creatures of Greek mythology. Delicate and strong, they embody mystery, beauty, art, poetry, water, elegance, determination, the founder's traditions and name.

www.naiadproductions.net 

like us on FB and follow the rehearsal process! 

https://www.facebook.com/NaiadProductions

Plot

Randle P. McMurphy is a brawler, found guilty of gambling and rape, who contrives to serve a short sentence in an airy mental institution rather than in a prison. This, he learns, is a mistake. He clashes with the head nurse, a fierce martinet. Quickly, he takes over the yard and accomplishes what the medical profession has been unable to do for twelve years: he makes a presumed deaf and dumb American Indian talk. He leads others out of introversion, stages a revolt so that they can see the world series on television, and arranges a rollicking midnight party with liquor and chippies. For the first offenses, the head nurse has him submit to shock treatment. For the Party, to horrid for her, she forces him to submit to final correction of frontal lobotomy.

Directed and Produced by  

Lara Genovese

Details

9th- 12thOCT 2014 (Thu – Sun) at 8 pm

11th-12thOCT 2014 (Sat – Sun) at 3pm

HKRep Black Box

8/FSheung Wan Civic Centre  HONG KONG
URBTIX Internet Ticketing: http://www.urbtix.hk

Credit Card Telephone Booking: +852 2111 5999

Production Team

Producer, Director, Art Director/Set- Lara Genovese

Assistant Director, Prop Master- Namrata Bindra

Light Designer- Felix Brown

Costume Designer- Lisa Frain

Sound and sound technician- Jim Brockman

Original score- Fabrizio Manicelli

Deputy Stage Manager- Naomi Harvey

Stage Manager- Linda Davy

Makeup- Leena Lempinen

Hair Stylist- Asia Chu

Assistant and crew- Garbiella So

Video Cinematographer and Editor- Joseph Angelakis

Cast

    Randle P. Mc Murphy- Rob Archibald

   Nurse Ratched- Candice Moore

   Chief Bromden- Melvin James

   Dale Harding- Damian Coory

   Billy Bibbit- Ben M Swift

   Scanlon- Guy Russell

  Cheswick- Joseph Angelakis

   Martini- Hamish Campbell

   Dr Spivey- Henry Coombs

   Aide William- Timothy Daniel Selby

   Aide Warren- David Tsim 

   Aide Turkle- Earl Young

   Ruckley- Jim Brockman

   Nurse Flinn- Namrata Bindra

   Candy Starr-Jane Archibald

   Sandra- Heather Cooper


Your Contribution

Having the opportunity of expressing ideas through art, allows one to live a magical experience and journey. It is through you that our community has voice and it is you who we, theater enthusiasts, have to thank, as your cheering, support and participation opens the stage doors for us
As an experience is one to be sensed 360', the more all the talents on board have the availability to play with more resources, the more the end product will be one to have an impact.
The contributions will support us in financing more aspects of the show. We are seeking a total of 10000 USD to cover some of the expenses.
Estimated figures:
- Set and installation   3000 USD
- Costumes 800 USD
- Marketing 1500 USD
- Music and Lights 400 USD
- Author rights  1000 USD
- Theater rent 3600

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Spread the word and share the links!
story_txt:
Naiad Productions

Presents   
in Collaboration with Shift     and     Co Presented by  HKRep 

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
By Dale WassermanFrom the novel by Ken Kesey


Who we are

 
Naiad Productions aims to magically give life to stories through fascination, power and charm.
Nymphs who presided over fountains, wells, springs, streams, Naiads were ancient creatures of Greek mythology. Delicate and strong, they embody mystery, beauty, art, poetry, water, elegance, determination, the founder's traditions and name.
www.naiadproductions.net 
like us on FB and follow the rehearsal process! 
https://www.facebook.com/NaiadProductions


Plot
Randle P. McMurphy is a brawler, found guilty of gambling and rape, who contrives to serve a short sentence in an airy mental institution rather than in a prison. This, he learns, is a mistake. He clashes with the head nurse, a fierce martinet. Quickly, he takes over the yard and accomplishes what the medical profession has been unable to do for twelve years: he makes a presumed deaf and dumb American Indian talk. He leads others out of introversion, stages a revolt so that they can see the world series on television, and arranges a rollicking midnight party with liquor and chippies. For the first offenses, the head nurse has him submit to shock treatment. For the Party, to horrid for her, she forces him to submit to final correction of frontal lobotomy.

Directed and Produced by  


Lara Genovese

Details
9th- 12thOCT 2014 (Thu – Sun) at 8 pm
11th-12thOCT 2014 (Sat – Sun) at 3pm

HKRep Black Box
8/FSheung Wan Civic Centre  HONG KONGURBTIX Internet
Ticketing: http://www.urbtix.hk
Credit Card Telephone Booking: +852 2111
5999

   Aide William- Timothy Daniel Selby

   Aide Warren- David Tsim 


   Aide Turkle- Earl Young

   Ruckley- Jim Brockman

   Nurse Flinn- Namrata Bindra

   Candy Starr-Jane Archibald

   Sandra- Heather Cooper

Having the opportunity of expressing ideas through art, allows one to live a magical experience and journey. It is through you that our community has voice and it is you who we, theater enthusiasts, have to thank, as your cheering, support and participation opens the stage doors for us
As an experience is one to be sensed 360', the more all the talents on board have the availability to play with more resources, the more the end product will be one to have an impact.

story:
A Description:

Hi, I'm Gabe Milligan-Green and I am putting together a theater piece that is called Chaos Theory as Taught by an Aboriginal Male.  At its most basic level, this piece is about a man who has become trapped in his own head, and in trying to find a way out only delves further into his subconscious.

This piece began as an experiement in creating theater from a purely imigistic standpoint.  I had these images in my head, specific events and pictures that I felt would be compelling and interesting to stage and to watch.  And the question I had for myself was, when putting together these vibrant, but incongruous, events what sort of narrative would emerge?  In creating a piece of theater without starting some grand message or purpose at its core, what would it end up saying?  And in the process of developing it something definitely began to unfold from it.  One of the ideas that has grown from it has been the clash between two these two worlds: reality against the subconcious, the literal colliding with the absurd.  And how do they come to terms with each other?

In creating this world in the mind, or worlds really, we use a lot of costume and prop pieces.  It's about creating rules and then suddenly breaking them.  Nothing ever stays stable, it is always constantly shifting, and in order to do that we use a lot of devices in the show.

Your Donations:

The donations that we receive from you are going directly into funding the show.  The money will go towards purchasing a number props and items that have had to be tracked down, as well as towards costumes and other set items that we have had to build and create, as well as advertising for the show.

Can't Help Monetarily?  You Can Still Help!

And if you can't help by donating money, that's alright, you can help in other ways too! Spread the link around to some other people you know that may be interested and generous, and if you're in New York or have friends here, spread the word about the show!  Come out and see what it becomes!  Having people in the seats is ultimately what we want the most.

story:
Imagine this: You are part of a live studio audience, witnessing and participating in an extravaganza celebrating the 1930s. Milton, your charming host, guides you through from sketch to song to sketch, making On The Air a fun and exciting SNL-style romp through the decade.

The show is peppered with popular songs of the 1930s: Gershwin, Irving Berlin, and Hoagy Carmichael certainly don't escape our clutches. From knock-knock jokes to Superman to the World's Fair, we have got you covered!

Since October, the Creative Motion Players Team has been collecting songs and writing sketches based on 1930s culture. And now we're ready to share our work with the world.

We're asking for $500 dollars to put towards venue rental fees. Our total budget is below. If we don't reach our goal, we can still surely use every penny we get.

Every dollar counts. For just 10 dollars, you can enjoy your name on our website as a Person We Love, receive a handwritten Thank you note, and have a haiku about you written just for you! You will also be invited to follow the production's progress via a secret behind-the-scenes blog featuring interviews with the cast and crew, photographs, and videos.

If you really want to see the show, you can reserve a seat and pay for your ticket now by donating 15 dollars!

On The Air will be presented on Saturday, January 5th, 2013 at the Monroe Theatrespace in Hoboken at 7pm.

 

About Us

Creative Motion Players is a new community theater company based in New Jersey. CMP, as we affectionately call our company, focuses on staging original works, producing the shows that just don't seem to get done enough, and doing projects that include and benefit the community. 

You can read about us and about our last project The Space Within on our website: CreativeMotionPlayers.com

story:
Who We Are

Our mission and structure

We are committed to researching, examining, and embodying the political and economic history of the United States in the last 100 years. We take continual inspiration from Marguerite Young's life work Harp Song for a Radical, dedicated to early 20th century labor activist Eugene Debs. We know that to know history is already to embody it. We rehearse and work rigorously in our struggle to understand more. We want to provide an understanding of our history by way of performance that is empowering, that is entertaining, that is precise, and that is living. We will create original work with original voices in a diverse, multi-generational community. 

Our history

Harp Song for a Radical was originally conceived as an academic project completed by participants in the University of Washington's B.A. and MFA programs in Drama Performance, Production, and Design, with assistance from the History department. After a 6-month workshop period, the Harp Song ensemble presented this first version at the Meany Studio Theater in October 2011. Small segments were later performed at the Seattle Labor Temple Association and the Voices of Occupy stage at the Folklife Festival in 2012.

Harp Song reorganized itself following the Folklife festival with a new concept and time period. It was performed as a twelve-minute vignette in March 2013 as part of the regular Twelve Minutes Max festival organized by On the Boards in preparation for its later expansion at the upcoming Northwest New Works festival in June 2013.

 

What We Are Asking For

We are asking for $5,500 from whoever can contribute even one. 

We are raising this money to fund our Northwest New Works production.  We have pared down all our costs to the bare minimum, and receive some in-kind support from the University of Washington school of Drama. However, we want to also provide the professional artists involved with a stipend to compensate them for their time; each of the ensemble has made very real fiscal sacrifices by taking time off work or from other projects. Additionally, we would like to provide each of the designers with a modest budget so that they have as many options as possible for attaining their vision. If we are unable to achieve our goal in fundraising, we pledge modify our project to the resources we have received from you.

Our Goal

Collaboration, Education, Opportunity

Harp Song for a Radical has always been a collaborative project. In the first iteration teachers worked closely with their students to discover and refine techniques of devising historically based theater. Now, the ensemble has expanded into an even split between students, recent graduates, and professionals. It is our goal to remain a project based company following this next production and to continuously provide the opportunity for young artists to work with established artists towards the greater goal of refining strategies to create new and exciting work. 

How You Can Help

Monetary Donations

Contributions can be made directly through this campaign: every little bit helps us achieve our mission.

If you would like to receive a tax-deduction for your donation, please visit Jeffrey Frace's sponsored artist profile and made a donation through The Field, a 501(c)3 organization serving the performing arts community. 

To make a tax-deductable donation, please click here.

Jeffrey Fracé is a Sponsored Artist of The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for Jeffrey Fracé are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906; New York NY 10038, 212-691-6969, fax: 212-255-2053, www.thefield.org. A copy of The Field's latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

For more information or if you have any questions, please email dylan@harpsongforaradical.com with the subject line "Harp Song Donation." Please allow up to 2 business days for a reply. 

In-Kind Donations

If you would like to offer a service or item that will assist in our production, we can also offer tax-deductions for their value through The Field. Please speak up! You and we may be surprised by how we can incorporate your assistance. 

For more information, please email dylan@harpsongforaradical.com with the subject line "Harp Song In-Kind Donation." Please allow up to 2 business days for a reply. 

Social Support

If you are unable to make a donation but can talk to those who may, please spread the word to them via mouth, Facebook, email, twitter, blog, carrier pigeon, or what have you. We appreciate you and your support immensely. It is the very reason we are here. 

 

Special thanks to Tim Summers for the above photos.

story:
Who?

We are the ACT ensemble

Anna-Helena, Chris-Gerard, Danny, Rudy, George, Ragnhild and Sean

an ensemble of actors, musicians, movers and shakers who have been working on our distinct approach to making theatre for between 2 and 10 years, each of us at slightly different stages of our journey with it. Our leading director Anna-Helena has named it 'Actor - Chorus - Text' due to the way the system has evolved. A C T for short.

(Click HERE for more details on ACT)

What?

We are ready to make the leap to commit ourselves fully to our shared work, become a collective and realise our first production STORM combining our ACT training with topics and texts that move us and the communities we want to support in a big way. Communities particularly associated with Youth work, International Exchange, Disabilities in the arts, Collaborating with freeing the voice of women in Palestine with music, Sustainability in arts and Education for social change. However our company live between New Delhi, Los Angeles, Warsaw and London and our work base is in Kent and it is proving insurmountable to cover the costs of our travel to work together in the way we need for this particular project, at this moment. Our passion to make theatre together, though, is unstoppable and we have faith that together we can make some thing that's never been seen before.

Recent feedback after three of us worked just 4 days on a demonstration in USA follows:

"It was a great honor to see the work in progress showing of Moon Fool's Storm... Rarely are we graced with such skilled performers and creators of new work that is equally dedicated to the text, the body, the voice and the music. I wish to applaud them for their ambition in covering so much material and fearlessly presenting it. It was an honor to host these beautiful artists from afar who are walking the very real path of the international working artist with such humility and confidence".

Director of FoolsFURY San Francisco and a potential producer for the full production

STORM

We see STORM as something fresh, magic and powerful and that will go far beyond us and our limitations. Practically speaking, we envisage that four key actors will lead audiences on a promenade performance into a theatrical world designed by Paddy Molloy, where they will share in the company's fantastical powers of physicality and music, following a story about building life on a new found island and enquiring about the nature of our changing climate. It is a piece that through exchange and collaboration we wish to open to inclusive and variegated audiences in UK and abroad. We will devise our story through improvisation and in collaboration with Sean's choir Gre Badanie and with several key researchers.

“I've dreamed of being close to an Ice Shelf when that collapses... something that’s never been witnessed first hand”

Connecting with scientists in climate research

“I have always argued that the post reformation division of science and art is one of the worst transitions in human history. Art and nature are hand in hand and I've longed for making my dreams reality on the topic. Your idea is very much akin to how I perceived something but I lack all of the production skills you have. Anyway to cut a long jibber short I'd love to meet up and let this evolve however it may. My dreams are vivid”

Dziga Walker

For our showcase project this summer, the ACT ensemble named above will be joined by Production Manager, Designer, Dramaturge, a collaborating actor, two researchers, Technician, Caterers, Film makers as well as Sean's amazing Experimental Choir called 'Gre Badanie'.

The full creative team make 26!

We have been exploring ideas for this new piece over the last year and some of the results are in the heading video (home-made) edit above. We now want to finally bring the full team and production crew together for the very first time to create a showcase and give ourselves the chance to take this exciting idea into production and make a trailer and marketing pack that can secure the work a future and build on the community that will help propel this work into a shared future.

"Moon Fool's embodied training is evident in the company's latest ensemble piece in development, Storm. With company members Anirudh Nair and Chris-Gerard Heyward the work offers tension and release you can cut with a knife. Original musical composition and percussive gestural sequences collide with Shakespeare's Tempest which brought new insights to me on the themes of power, imprisonment, and personal choice. I look forward to seeing more work from this exciting company".

Debórah Eliezer, Associate Artistic Director, foolsFURY Theater, San Francisco www.foolsfury.org

To make this happen we need your support.

Your pledges will help:

  • pay for our travels,
  • toward hiring the sustainable living centre and space we love supporting and working in in Kent,
  • pay caterers fair fees to work all hours of the day to feed us during our rehearsals so we can use the time optimally to make a good showcase,
  • cover the cost of our food for 12 people at £7.50 per day for 8 days of the rehearsal period,
  • hire a film maker to make a professional trailer of our work to promote to producers and programmers,
  • market our work to the relevant industry members on effective online marketing sites with inbuilt mailing lists for future use make a design and print it for direct distribution at all our events between now and then to invite people to see our work and get word out about what we do.

... all this in order to present a high quality showcase on the 13th July at The Quadrangle Trust in Kent, that will help us make vital work toward the full production... We need to showcase the work in order to bring our training and investment to fruition and market a production to accompany our ongoing education and community work.

By donating to this, you are not only helping us but creating opportunities and exchange with/for artists, theatre ensembles, children, adults, activists and enthusiasts all over the world - in England, Ireland and Scotland, Norway, Sweden, Poland, Brazil, India, Malta, USA, Israel and Greece. This work breaks boundaries and invigorates the power of being human.

Here is some feedback to give you a better idea what we mean:

"[The workshop] truly has made a huge difference to me as a person because I think the biggest learning from it was that one CAN overcome one’s blocks if one works at it. But the realization that it is possible was a huge take home. I still sing Za Li Zome, Bella and Jovano almost everyday as I walk home from work. And that is also sometimes the best part of my day. Thank you for that."

"So I'm currently doing this play called Norway. Today, and we have this wild cliff scene, at the edge of a precipice and all so I used some of yours and Rudy's moves. The Delhi University crowd was in awe so I owe you a BIG thanks : )".

Youth and Adult Participants - both students from different parts of India

"The soul of McLean’s work is not the physical feats which performers seek to accomplish but finding the Truth of the moment and its genuineness."

Key Moon Fool collaborator Athena Stevens of Aegis Productions who has the physical disability, Cerebral Palsy

We have some great ideas as to how to get you involved and show our enormous gratitude for your support. Back the campaign and check out all the amazing treats and hospitality rewards Moon Fool has to offer including free tickets to join our A Festival of Moon Fool at The Quadrangle Trust in Shoreham, Kent 13th July 6pm till late. This will be the culminating event of three weeks rehearsing for STORM and hosting an international workshop residency with participants from Norway, India, Malta, Sweden, USA, Poland and UK.

See you soon!!!!

Original musical composition and percussive gestural sequences collide with Shakespeare's Tempest which brought new insights to me on the themes of power, imprisonment, and personal choice. I look forward to seeing more work from this exciting company".
Debórah Eliezer, Associate Artistic Director, foolsFURY Theater, San Francisco www.foolsfury.org 
To make this happen we need your support.
Your pledges will help:

pay for our travels,
toward hiring the sustainable living centre and space we love supporting and working in in Kent,
pay caterers fair fees to work all hours of the day to feed us during our rehearsals so we can use the time optimally to make a good showcase,
cover the cost of our food for 12 people at £7.50 per day for 8 days of the rehearsal period,
hire a film maker to make a professional trailer of our work to promote to producers and programmers,
market our work to the relevant industry members on effective online marketing sites with inbuilt mailing lists for future use make a design and print it for direct distribution at all our events between now and then to invite people to see our work and get word out about what we do.

... all this in order to present a high quality showcase on the 13th July at The Quadrangle Trust in Kent, that will help us make vital work toward the full production... We need to showcase the work in order to bring our training and investment to fruition and market a production to accompany our ongoing education and community work.
By donating to this, you are not only helping us but creating opportunities and exchange with/for artists, theatre ensembles, children, adults, activists and enthusiasts all over the world - in England, Ireland and Scotland, Norway, Sweden, Poland, Brazil, India, Malta, USA, Israel and Greece. This work breaks boundaries and invigorates the power of being human.
Here is some feedback to give you a better idea what we mean:
"[The workshop] truly has made a huge difference to me as a person because I think the biggest learning from it was that one CAN overcome one’s blocks if one works at it. But the realization that it is possible was a huge take home. I still sing Za Li Zome, Bella and Jovano almost everyday as I walk home from work. And that is also sometimes the best part of my day. Thank you for that." 
"So I'm currently doing this play called Norway. Today, and we have this wild cliff scene, at the edge of a precipice and all so I used some of yours and Rudy's moves. The Delhi University crowd was in awe so I owe you a BIG thanks : )". 
Youth and Adult Participants - both students from different parts of India
"The soul of McLean’s work is not the physical feats which performers seek to accomplish but finding the Truth of the moment and its genuineness." 
Key Moon Fool collaborator Athena Stevens of Aegis Productions who has the physical disability, Cerebral Palsy
We have some great ideas as to how to get you involved and show our enormous gratitude for your support. Back the campaign and check out all the amazing treats and hospitality rewards Moon Fool has to offer including free tickets to join our A Festival of Moon Fool at The Quadrangle Trust in Shoreham, Kent 13th July 6pm till late. This will be the culminating event of three weeks rehearsing for STORM and hosting an international workshop residency with participants from Norway, India, Malta, Sweden, USA, Poland and UK.
See you soon!!!!

story:
FRIENDS, THESPIANS, COUNTRYPEOPLE, LEND ME YOUR CASH!

And story does need to be told. Here. Now. At this time. In this city. We need to keep telling women’s stories and raising women’s voices.

I know what you’re thinking… is this play going to topple the patriarchy? Is this a revolutionary piece of dramatic political theatre that will change the cultural zeitgeist forevermore?

Well, um….no.

Other than the fact that women are speaking and being... like… people. Which, unfortunately is still an act of rebellion in some circles- or at the very least an act of annoyance, but at the risk of being interrupted by John McCain I’ll move on…

Or, tells the story of one fictional night in the life of real-life 17th century playwright Aphra Behn. She was a playwright, a spy, a lover, a widow, a traitor, a patriot, and SO MANY OTHER THINGS. LIKE ALL WOMEN. We are not just one thing. In a time when society seems more obsessed with putting us in boxes than ever, this play explores the depth and breadth of what we can be. Who we can be. How many different people we can love in an infinite number of ways.

The play is set at the beginning of the restoration after a long period of darkness, war, and Puritanical values. The theaters are about to re-open for the first time in over a decade, women are onstage for the first time ever, playing both male and female parts, and hope and change are in the air. Sound familiar? This play premiered at the beginning of Obama-era America, but don’t we need a story like this now more than ever?

Also it’s funny, and don’t you need a laugh right now?

FRINGE IS BETTER TOGETHER!

Maiden Phoenix Theatre Company and Simple Machine are two Boston fringe theatre companies committed to bringing art to a wider community. OUR POWERS COMBINED… we bring you: Or, by Liz Duffy Adams. Making art in the Boston Fringe has always been a labor of love, and sometimes you need a little help from your friends.

Since 2013 MPTC has been committed to telling stories about women: past, present, and future and Simple Machine believes character, language, and action are the essential elements at the heart of all theatre. By focusing on these fundamentals, Simple Machine makes theatre that is engaging, accessible, and affordable.

Or, explores the spectrum of what women can be: Tease or traitor, hero or harlot, or all of the above? And asks the question, to quote Sondheim, "Is it always 'or' is it never 'and'?"  Although most people who know the play think of it as a story about England’s first published female playwright, when we meet Aphra she is far from her goal of being a famous playwright. She has to fight tooth-and-nail to get out of the dangerous spy trade once and for all and to re-invent herself as a poet for the ages. Or, shows us a woman on the brink of change who is willing to do whatever it takes to step into her new life.

This campaign will help us continue our commitment to paying our artists a fair stipend, and in this production we will be working in a brand new theatre space. The issue of available and affordable space in the Boston theater scene has been an important one since our inception. Most of our budget will go toward space requirements and we are thrilled to be serving a new community in Chelsea, MA and bringing women's stories to a wider audience.

FRINGE AIN’T ABOUT THE MONEY… BUT WE DO NEED SOME…. PLZ?

Our total budget for the project is $7,900 and we are trying to raise $5000.  But we’ve already raised $2900!

Due to the success of our Pants Role Nation fundraiser we have already raised $1900 dollars!! (Ladies! Pants! Vegetables! Guess you kinda had to be there) and due to the continued support of The Bob Jolly Charitable Trust we have received another $1000 dollars to put towards this production.

Our main cost is the space at Chelsea Theatre Works (The BRAND SPANKING NEW BLACK BOX THEATRE!) that we will use for rehearsals and performances for $3550.

Our Staff costs are $1450 for our professional Designers, Actors, and Staff.

Design Budgets for Set, Costumes, Props, Lighting, and Sound equal $1200

Publicity will be $400 (because we gotta get people there or really… what are we doing?)

Show rights total (yay, paying playwrights!) is $900

Insurance (no fun, but necessary, since being sued is even less fun) is $400

We have wiggle room of $200 for unexpected costs (there’s always something) for a total of: $7900

 

In these troubled economic times, it is the fringe and small theaters that need your financial support more than ever. We don’t have a subscriber base or generations of donors to fall back on. All we have is our belief in this story and the support of people who want to take a leap of faith. Despite all the challenges, we are coming together to do what needs to be done in order to share this story with an audience. We believe in its power to move, entertain, challenge, shock, and re-contextualize the past and present. Above all, we believe in the hope and freedom of expression that this story champions, especially in these times of political and artistic crisis.

story:
Short Summary

 

  • Lee Berger is a theatre-maker/producer from South Jersey, but calls Brooklyn his home now. He received both a BFA in Acting and BA in Philosophy and Religious Studies from Pace University, and has found that his devised theatre is the best way of combining both of his passions.
  • Frie(dman) Berger has been in the works, at least on paper, since 2010 when my mother was diagnosed with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease), beginning as a collection of poems, and becoming the massive movement piece/exploration it now is, with terrific influence from, theater-makers past and present, as well as my production team Chad Chenail and Ellen Maynard, the piece has finally found its legs in the language of dance and movement, all that my mother lacked during her time sick.
  • When our goal is reached, we will be able to raise awareness of ALS through the little used conduit of art, and not just tell the story of my mother, but also share stories together, hope together, laugh together, cry together, and together ask the question: Are we enough? When our goal is reached we will provide a means of connection to two small audiences in the Beaverkill Studio space in the Catskill mountains.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • $500 to pay the director, $500 to pay the choreographer, $200 for each of the actors (4 - 6, $800-$1200), $500 for food during the 1 week intensive/workshop/incubator period (November 5th- November 10th), $250 for accommodations/venue (only such a great price because the owner is a friend), $400 travel expenses (moving 7 - 9 people from NYC to Parksville, NY), $250 (set/props/costumes), $275 for indiegogo fees. Total goal: $3,675
  • Please note: none of the funds generated by this campaign go to me, I am paying my performers and production team, and covering costs of the production, any money I make will be from ticket sales only (not including the perk tickets given out for donating).

 

The Impact

 

  • We aren't here just for my cathartic experience though, please don't misconstrue this piece for something selfish, patronizing, or  pretentious. I want everyone to feel like the experience was shared. At the end of the show, people will feel connected, to me and each other, because we will all have shared something unique together, and participated in something deep and felt. It will be an exploration into the depths of human emotion, NOT just mine but those of everyone's present. We will have laughed and cried, and even danced like no one was watching. And we will have asked whether it was all enough or not, whether we were enough or not, if we are enough or not?

 

Risks & Challenges

 

  • We are doing it all very fast; the magic (good or evil...) of the process. This piece is about connecting, and asking if we are enough for the loved ones in our lives or ourselves. It's about knowing how we all ask ourselves this everyday, and that that's what brings us together. I have chosen to work on a very quick timeline to emulate the speed of a show for an audience. We will be work intimately still to keep the closeness intact. We will be working for 9 hours a day for 6 days devising the one-hour work whose backbone/spine currently exists as a 26 page script. But how can we write what the audience has yet to write? How do we write our improvised response to that audience? The script shapes itself around discussion questions and jumping off points about our saddest and happiest moments of life; love, loss, grief, joy, humiliation, fulfillment, and micro-love, a concept introduced in the play. The hurdles mostly lie in balancing the tight timeline and still being able to put something together that is audience-ready without sacrificing the art. But deadlines create urgency, and urgency drives passion.
  • Working with these  tight sort of timelines, however, became, not only part of my wheelhouse, but almost my specialty in grad school. Almost exclusively working in this fashion allowed us to keep the ideas from going stale or flat. 
  • Often times artists don't know when the piece is finished, when to say "enough." Ours will be finished in 6 days!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute it doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Pass this around to your friends and family, get the word out
  • Check out the ALS website 

Thanks for your support,

Lee
story_txt:
Short Summary
 


Lee Berger is a theatre-maker/producer from South Jersey, but calls Brooklyn his home now. He received both a BFA in Acting and BA in Philosophy and Religious Studies from Pace University, and has found that his devised theatre is the best way of combining both of his passions.

Frie(dman) Berger has been in the works, at least on paper, since 2010 when my mother was diagnosed with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease), beginning as a collection of poems, and becoming the massive movement piece/exploration it now is, with terrific influence from, theater-makers past and present, as well as my production team Chad Chenail and Ellen Maynard, the piece has finally found its legs in the language of dance and movement, all that my mother lacked during her time sick.
When our goal is reached, we will be able to raise awareness of ALS through the little used conduit of art, and not just tell the story of my mother, but also share stories together, hope together, laugh together, cry together, and together ask the question: Are we enough? When our goal is reached we will provide a means of connection to two small audiences in the Beaverkill Studio space in the Catskill mountains.  

 

What We Need & What You Get
 

$500 to pay the director, $500 to pay the choreographer, $200 for each of the actors (4 - 6, $800-$1200), $500 for food during the 1 week intensive/workshop/incubator period (November 5th- November 10th), $250 for accommodations/venue (only such a great price because the owner is a friend), $400 travel expenses (moving 7 - 9 people from NYC to Parksville, NY), $250 (set/props/costumes), $275 for indiegogo fees. Total goal: $3,675
Please note: none of the funds generated by this campaign go to me, I am paying my performers and production team, and covering costs of the production, any money I make will be from ticket sales only (not including the perk tickets given out for donating).

 

The Impact
 
We aren't here just for my cathartic experience though, please don't misconstrue this piece for something selfish, patronizing, or  pretentious. I want everyone to feel like the experience was shared. At the end of the show, people will feel connected, to me and each other, because we will all have shared something unique together, and participated in something deep and felt. It will be an exploration into the depths of human emotion, NOT just mine but those of everyone's present. We will have laughed and cried, and even danced like no one was watching. And we will have asked whether it was all enough or not, whether we were enough or not, if we are enough or not?
 

Risks & Challenges
 

We are doing it all very fast; the magic (good or evil...) of the process. This piece is about connecting, and asking if we are enough for the loved ones in our lives or ourselves. It's about knowing how we all ask ourselves this everyday, and that that's what brings us together. I have chosen to work on a very quick timeline to emulate the speed of a show for an audience. We will be work intimately still to keep the closeness intact. We will be working for 9 hours a day for 6 days devising the one-hour work whose backbone/spine currently exists as a 26 page script. But how can we write what the audience has yet to write? How do we write our improvised response to that audience? The script shapes itself around discussion questions and jumping off points about our saddest and happiest moments of life; love, loss, grief, joy, humiliation, fulfillment, and micro-love, a concept introduced in the play. The hurdles mostly lie in balancing the tight timeline and still being able to put something together that is audience-ready without sacrificing the art. But deadlines create urgency, and urgency drives passion.
Working with these  tight sort of timelines, however, became, not only part of my wheelhouse, but almost my specialty in grad school. Almost exclusively working in this fashion allowed us to keep the ideas from going stale or flat. 
Often times artists don't know when the piece is finished, when to say "enough." Ours will be finished in 6 days!

 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute it doesn't mean you can't help:

Pass this around to your friends and family, get the word out
Check out the ALS website 

Thanks for your support,
Lee

story:
Hi

My name is Caroline Nash and I set up Next Page Productions in Northampton to enable new writing to be produced and performed around The Midlands, England.

Firstly - the non- exciting bit:

We present high quality new writing and are pleased to have nurtured relationships with writers with strong credentials and innovative ideas.

We strive to attract first time theatre goers and  those who may be new to writing, by promoting our work widely as well as engaging with writing organisations and more traditional theatre audiences. 

We want our audiences to be able to explore the truths of constructed storytelling, that doesn’t have to lead them to a decisive ending. The talents of East and West Midlands based artists must be witnessed and we want you to be a part of it.

By making a contribution, you will enable us to get the show to production state. We will do our utmost to take it forward from there to even bigger and better things.

What We Need:

And now for the fun stuff.

Your support will enable us to:

  • contribute something towards a Director for a rehearsal period - she has already agreed to waive her fee as a support to the cause, because she is a very good egg
  • contribute a fee to 2 actors for the roles of Sid and Joan for a rehearsal period -  so they can at least afford to eat and keep their strength up
  • contribute to a fee for a Stage Manager as they actually hold the entire thing together and it would be impossible without them
  • create marketing material - well how else will you know where we are ?
  • support the cost of props and costume - we aren't pretty when we're naked
  • ensure a professional production that is ready to tour on a profit share basis
  • support the venue cost for the first 2 nights of production to be presented locally - we will personally pay for all other venues
  • cover the cost of a rehearsal space so that we don't all REALLY annoy our significant others by rehearsing in front of the tv.

If you cannot donate at this time, please do come along to our performances.

Check out the tour dates as soon as they are published at www.nextpageproductions.co.uk

The Impact

Caroline Nash has produced 4 successful tours to date. Please check out her website for Next Page Productions at www.nextpageproductions.co.uk

Each tour has brought something a little new and a little different to the theatre world and she hopes to continue to bring this new work to life for as long as she possibly can.

Steve Dimmer presents society talks on the Carry On films called 'Ooh Matron !' and these are extremely popular. It has demonstrated the fondness that people have for these wonderful characters and also the passion that Steve Dimmer, the writer, has for these people. But what about behind the screen ? What were they really like?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like the sound of the show and you aren't in a position to be able to contribute, then there are lots of other ways that you can help.

  • Share the 'Sid & Joan' out of the link for this crowdfunding - not just once, but lots of times.
  • Tell your friends, especially those that have an interest in theatre, new writing and British Legends. You could just be sharing it with the one person that is looking to support us.
  • Use the Indiegogo free share stuff and help us get this show on the road.
  • If you want to volunteer your time to help in any way, let us know and we will see which of your many skills we can utilise.

In advance, Steve and Caroline would like to take this opportunity to thank you for whatever you can help us with, in order to make this dream a reality.

Please do email us on carolinelnash@hotmail.com if you would like any further information.

story:
Me:

My name is Sarah Robertson. I am an actor, dancer, choreographer and rapper!  I have recently completed a 4 year dance program and now (almost) a 4 year acting program!  I'm almost there!

My Project:

In order to graduate, I need to produce my own show and I need some support to do it! 

I am doing a show that involves 3 fantastic professional directors (Graham Percy, Kris Marushy & Andrew Legg).  As I move forward in my acting career it is so beneficial to have worked with such stellar directors and to learn more acting styles in the process.  This project, most importantly, allows me to graduate.  Secondly, it sets me up for more success in my future acting career!

What I Need & What You Get:

But it's not cheap having these professionals on board!  We need $950 for:

  • A mask workshop with Graham Percy
  • Transportation for all my directors (all over Southern Alberta)
  • Licensing & Production Costs
  • Marketing
  • Refreshments for after the show

Perks include:

  • Tickets to see the show
  • Personalized Raps
  • Thank you Postcards with show shots
  • Shout Outs on Facebook
  • Special Drinks at our Mocktail Party TalkBack!  (you have to come to the show to enjoy these!)

What It Means To Me:

I would be so grateful for your support as I do my last hurrah (this show) after four long, hard (and amazing!) years of acting school.  I have felt so much support and would love to share this project, this show, and my acting work with all of you.

This show is also an expression of how important I believe it is to try and fail and experiment in life.  With choices, with dreams, with communication, with EVERYTHING!  I am learning to let go and make more mistakes and fail more, which is why I've chosen to do an experimental project. 

I think it will be FUN, I think it will be HILARIOUS, and I think it will INSPIRE others to think outside the box more and try and fail more in life, so we can learn.

Thanks for considering supporting this wacky, experimental and ultimately, GRADUATION project!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come to the show!  September 15th-18th.  $10 at the door.  Short Mocktail Party after to Mingle & Talk About the Show!

To Reserve Tickets, click on this facebook page here, Or email thelesson@gmail.com

Thank you ever so much!

Sarah Robertson, Producer & Actor

Tickets to see the show
Personalized Raps
Thank you Postcards with show shots
Shout Outs on Facebook
Special Drinks at our Mocktail Party TalkBack!  (you have to come to the show to enjoy these!)

What It Means To Me:
I would be so grateful for your support as I do my last hurrah (this show) after four long, hard (and amazing!) years of acting school.  I have felt so much support and would love to share this project, this show, and my acting work with all of you.
This show is also an expression of how important I believe it is to try and fail and experiment in life.  With choices, with dreams, with communication, with EVERYTHING!  I am learning to let go and make more mistakes and fail more, which is why I've chosen to do an experimental project. 
I think it will be FUN, I think it will be HILARIOUS, and I think it will INSPIRE others to think outside the box more and try and fail more in life, so we can learn.
Thanks for considering supporting this wacky, experimental and ultimately, GRADUATION project!

Other Ways You Can Help
Please come to the show!  September 15th-18th.  $10 at the door.  Short Mocktail Party after to Mingle & Talk About the Show!To Reserve Tickets, click on this facebook page here, Or email thelesson@gmail.com
Thank you ever so much!
Sarah Robertson, Producer & Actor

story:
We are Invictus Theatre, a new nonprofit theatre company focusing on heightened language in Chicago. We believe in the power of language to express the nuances of the human condition. We believe language empowers our communities to share their stories, create connections, and tear down barriers based on race, religion, gender, or sexual orientation. 

    In the fall/winter of 2017 we will produce our first full length production of William Shakespeare's Othello: The Moor of Venice. A play still relevant 400 years after its inception; dealing with issues of race, gender, identity, and discernment of the truth.

      100% of the funds we raise from this campaign will go towards our rental fees for performance and rental space. Even if we don't reach our goal, your contribution will aid us in putting Othello onstage (literally!).

       At Invictus Theatre, we believe that mastery over language connects our communities. Participating in language-based theatre such as Shakespeare's Othello either as an actor or an audience  member invites us to share our stories and our experiences. It gives words to the wordless, and makes what is within, without. 

    Please help us bring Othello from the page to the stage. Invictus Theatre is a 501 c(3) non-profit theatre company so all donations are 100% tax deductible. Even if you are unable to make a financial contribution there are other ways you can help, either by in-kind donations, volunteering, or passing along our campaign to your friends on Facebook!

   If you would like to know more information about Invictus check out our website at:

https://www.invictustheatreco.com/

     Or you can send us a message at:

Invictustheatreco@gmail.com

Thank you for your time and consideration!

story:
WHAT IS GLORIA ABOUT? 

Soon after New Zealand had farewelled 20,000 brothers, sons, and husbands in WW2,  the arrival of 45 000 handsome and charming young American servicemen became much needed escapism out of the fear and deprivation of war.

Based on a true story, GLORIA follows the heartache, secrets, and bravery of NZ war-bride; Gloria Schmidt, whose marriage to an American serviceman made waves in New Zealand when she stood against the tide regardless of social disapproval.  GLORIA is the story of a woman facing adversity, struggling to find herself in exceptional circumstances.

GLORIA  is a fascinating and fearless one woman show that leaps into flickering war-time romances, swing time dance halls and lost sons to foreign fields.

“A fascinating story and unique piece of theatre about one of New Zealand’s war brides”                                 -- NZ HERALD

“Amy Waller does an amazing job as solo performer, holding a very slick 70 minutes together with panache and style”  -- THEATREVIEW

“Visually and stylistically this production is extremely engaging and fascinating… A superbly crafted portrait of one war bride’s exhilarating journey – a truly inspiring story”   -- KEEPING UP WITH NZ

A LITTLE BIT ABOUT ME AND THE PLAY'S BACKGROUND

Born and raised in New Zealand by my Cincinnati born parents, I received my acting training at Toi Whakaari: NZ Drama School where I also learned how to structure stories in the form of solo theatre. My love for devising theatre and writing evolved post graduation while working as an actress in film and TV.  I am now based in my parents homeland where I continue to dedicate and channel my creative efforts to empowering myself and other women though creating and sharing female driven stories.

GLORIA  originally premiered in Auckland, New Zealand in the Auckland Fringe Festival and due to it’s overwhelming popularity, the New Zealand arts councils funded GLORIA to be developed further and go on tour in 2013.

The play received sold out houses and rave reviews. The show made waves in New Zealand not only for it’s theatrical brilliance and originality but because it is so richly steeped in relatively recent historical context. I received letters, emails and phone calls from all over the country expressing interest in my nana’s story; it also inspired many people to share their own war stories. Thus, it became immediately apparent to me that there is a demand for stories like Gloria’s to be told and that it is important.

WHY THIS IS IMPORTANT TO ME and WHY IT IS RELEVANT.

The reason why I am a US/NZ citizen, is a direct result of my nana’s marriage to an american marine. It is a document of NZ's and the US's history so I always had the intention of bringing the show here to America . After strong encouragement from mentors and industry professionals I have decided that it is well overdue time to share this play with you all here in LA. Since its last season, much has changed and happened. I am really looking forward to filtering this experience into the story and shifting the voice from being not only my grandmothers but now also my own.

It is a story about a woman who is struggling to find her voice amongst the personal displacement and  geographical displacement of war. 

It is a story that is relevant and important at any given time but especially now. I feel incredibly inspired by the women's movement that has been happening around the world and my nana would agree that now is the perfect time to voice this female empowerment story here the US.

It is important and vital that we tell and hear more stories about women told from the perspective of women especially stories from my grandmothers generation that will soon disappear forever.

By contributing to my campaign you will help me to continue to create and tell stories about the secrets, struggles and bravery of women in our history which will hopefully empower women today.

HOW YOU CAN HELP.

In order to make this happen I need to raise $3875 which will go towards venue rental, set/props, marketing materials and technical requirements.

GLORIA BUDGET

Space Rental 5 performances @ $200 each $1000

Theatre Insurance Flat Fee $175

Rehearsal Space (first 4 weeks) 4 weeks/6 hours $480

Production Week Rehearsal Space 1 week/18 hours $360

Tech Rehearsal Production Week - Technician18 hours $360

Production Technician - Actual Show 5 performances @ $40 each $200

Graphic Designer Allow $200

Set Decoration & Props Allow $500

Sound DesignAllow $300

Hollywood Fringe Registration FeeFlat Fee $250

Printing CostsAllow $50

 TOTAL $3875

 I am also looking for a table, 4 chairs and vintage suitcases like the ones in this image.

Please show your support by sharing this campaign and donating in any way you can!

Thank you! 

Amy Waller xox

story:
My name is Teddy Fatscher and I am a local Philadelphia Choreographer and Creator. I moved to Philadelphia in 2010 to further my dance studies at the University of The Arts from which I now possess a BFA in Modern Dance Performance and Choreography. Throughout my career I have been blessed with the opportunity of working with and learning from choreographers such as Brian Sanders, Roni Koresh and Moses Pendelton. I started Matter Movement Group in 2018 to not only create an outlet for my creative energy but also to provide a platform for other artists to share their artistry and creativity with a receptive community. This years project "HABIT@" is a vision that is going to require hundreds of hours of creation, fabrication, choreography, rehearsal and building. These are the reasons why this campaign is integral in MMG creating the vision of "HABIT@" to the fullest. I would be a fool to say I could do this all myself which is why I am asking you, my friends and family, to help today in achieving our goal. This set alone will be unlike anything we have ever constructed before. It will display all four seasons and geography spanning from the barren deserts to the deepest depths of the ocean. The choreography work has already begun. It draws inspiration from the most profound plant and animal life that exist all over the world. 

Last year was extremely challenging for me. I had recently left my job and was transitioning into another. I wasn't financially stable enough to take on the task of creating an entire Fringe Festival production...but I had to. It was something that seemed like a no brainer to me. I was so blinded by my goal I literally spent my last dollar on the production of "UNHINGED". It was a real eye-opener to how committed I actually was to this project and this aspect of my life. I can promise you, as contributors, will see a repeat of last years commitment, if not more.

We at MMG are setting a fundraising goal of $10,000. This amount of money would allow MMG to compensate performers a livable wage for their hours of creation and rehearsing this project. It will also allow MMG to purchase building materials necessary in constructing the immersive set that we envision. Our costumes will transform human bodies into flora and fauna animated by the performers themselves. With that being said, it is defintely going to be expensive. You can give what you can or claim one of our amazing perks to get more from us in return from your contribution.  If you can't contribute, we at MMG understand and hope that you will share this with friends and family who are advocates for the arts. We also hope you come experience the production as a patron. Trust us, you do NOT want to miss this.

story:
Help us Breath Life into the Words of the Black Panther Party

  • Iron Age Theatre has been producing theatre focused on the common man and justice for almost 30 year and Theatre in the X has been making theatre available to the common man in underserved communities for the past five years. Iron Age's diverse approach to theatrical work has offered opportunities for progressive stories to be shared with audiences to shake their preconceptions. Theatre in the X brings African American theatre with new and veteran Philadelphia talent to West Philly in Parks for free. Both groups share a common vision of working with under appreciated actors, playwrights an communities. The production is directed by Eric Carter, Walter DeShields, and John Doyle and will feature Philadelphia Actors.
  • The Black Panthers have been presented by the media as violent extremists and by history as a lost movement with little lasting impact. Truly, this could not be farther from the truth.  We need the voices of the panthers to help us more forward in these challenging times. The Panthers ideals, and their efforts to build community support must be reexamined. The call for observation and participation can only work if people are able to observe the actions of the panthers and this production allows people to feel the emotion behind the lives and missions of panthers at the ground level.
  • Today as people struggle to find ways to protest, looking at the lives not of the leaders of the party but the ground soldiers can offer examples that contemporary citizens can observe and include in their efforts to better our nation and our world.
  • This is about making great art, engaging people in social change and action. We want to provide local performers  the opportunity to present great stories to our community and to engage in a conversation about the powerful ideas and the personal stories of the Panthers. We want to build community by connecting like-minded artists in a creative process about real people.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to pay actors, directors, designers and rent some space for the production. We need support to help advertise the show to assure people know and engage in the production. The production is only a few nights but we want to fairly compensate the team. We hope to include two musical performances and so will need funding to compensate the musicians and to assure the sound quality is excellent. We have chosen to present the show in a community theatre building rather than a big Philly theatre and so are pushing the funding back into underserved communities. Your donations will all go right into the production allowing more words to be heard.
  • Our perks are all representative of the panthers. Buttons, stickers and tickets to the performances. We want people to hear the ideas, and put them into practice and our perks help people do that as well as allow you to show your panther pride or believe in the power of the people.
  • We will find a way to make this event happen. We will drive the money we gather into the event whether we reach our goal or not.

The Impact

  • Our world and our nation is becoming steadily less humane and more corporate. Iron Age and Theatre in the X want to change the world and getting these ideas out can make a difference set by step.
  • Iron Age has been challenging the community with progressive ideas for year. We just completed an acclaimed run of a new one man show about Black Panther Fred Hampton which will begin touring the country in April. We have produced productions like this, Voices of a People's History, bringing a more diverse cast to the stage focused on progressive literature and speeches from history as curated by Howard Zinn and Anthony Arnove. We have brought walking tours of local communities populated with actors presenting African American stories on Juneteenth in association with the NAACP.
  • Theatre in the X has been making theatre in Malcolm X Park for four years, Theatre in the X uses well established and novice playwrights and actors to perform FREE theatre in the black community in West Philly. They are developing new work all of the time.

Risks & Challenges

This is the first collaboration between Theatre in the X and Iron Age and we are learning to work together.

  • One of our biggest challenges is recruiting actors for a single performance. We have done this effectively in the past over and over.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • If you can't donate....Please help us get the word out. Tell people about the production and about the possibility of donating. You can make our work possible by helping people find this campaign. Observation and Participation.
  • Indiegogo has many tools which with you can share this project and PLEASE DO!!!!
  • And COME TO THE SHOW in February!!!

And that's all there is to it.
